TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) raised as a matter of privilege the action of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in authorising distribution of information contained in an answer to a question on notice asked by him before the answer had been submitted to the Clerk of the House and transmitted to him. My duty in such a matter is to decide whether or not I should accord precedence to a motion in respect of it. To determine this I need to be satisfied that the matter has been raised at the earliest opportunity and a prima facie case has been made out. In respect of the first criterion, I am satisfied that in the circumstances of yesterday's proceedings the matter was raised at the earliest opportunity.

INTERJECT.PARA: The question of substance is whether or not the facts as stated reveal a prima facie case of breach of privilege. There are two elements here. First there is a traditional head of contempt or disobedience of general rules or orders of the House. I refer to pages 145 to 147 of May's Parliamentary Practice and pages 653 and 654 of House of Representatives Practice. The precedents cited relate to matters such as disobedience by witnesses ordered to attend, refusal to withdraw from the House when ordered to do so and obstruction of orders of a House or committee. Breaches of the Standing Orders or practices of the House are not ordinarily dealt with as contempts. Presumably this is because such matters are better dealt with as matters of order, rather than as matters of privilege.
The second aspect, and one alluded to by the honourable member for Dawson, is whether or not the actions taken have obstructed him in the discharge of his duties.

I have given the matter careful consideration, and have concluded that, whilst he may consider the actions of the Minister a discourtesy and an annoyance, they do not constitute actions which would actually obstruct him in the course of his duties. In addition there is a general reluctance by the Parliament either to extend the limits of contempt or to resile from the principle that the House should exercise its penal jurisdiction as sparingly as possible and only when satisfied that to do so is essential in order to provide reasonable protection for the House, its members and committees from substantial interference with their functions.

In all the circumstances I am of the opinion that the matter raised does not constitute a prima facie case of breach of privilege, and I cannot accord precedence to a motion in respect of it. I have no wish to enter further into the merits of the particular case, but I remind the House that it has adopted Standing Orders, and it follows practices and conventions, in order to discharge its business in a proper manner. I believe it is incumbent upon all members to observe the letter and the spirit of these rules and conventions.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 23 May.
Consideration of Senate's amendment.
Senate's amendment-
Clause 11, page 10, line 16, omit ``3'', substitute ``4''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 10, page 4, after proposed new sub-section 33F (2) insert the following sub-section:

``(2A) In nominating a person for appointment as a member of the Board referred to in paragraph 34 (1) (d), the Committee shall have regard to the requirement that at least one of the members referred to in that paragraph is to be a wheat grower.''.
(2) Clause 11, page 10, lines 16 and 17, omit proposed new paragraph 34 (1) (d), insert the following paragraph:
``(d) 4 other members, each of whom has had extensive experience at a high level in finance, marketing or grain movement logistics and at least one of whom is a wheat grower.';''.

The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1985 is concerned primarily with the restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board and the establishment of the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee. The Government proposed that the Australian Wheat Board comprise 11 members-a grower chairperson and a government member selected by the Minister, five grower members, one from each mainland State, and four members with specialist skills, all nine of whom were to be selected by the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee. Under the Government's proposal growers, including the chairperson, were a majority on the Board, occupying six of the 11 positions. Growers also had a majority on the Selection Committee.

The Bill was introduced in the Senate in the 1985 autumn sitting and passed with amendments, one of which was to reduce the number of specialist members of the Board from four to three. The Senate did not agree to a subsequent amendment passed by the House to restore to four the number of specialist positions on the Board on the grounds that the growers selected by the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee did not constitute a board majority.

The Government is firmly of the view that, to protect the Government's underwriting and growers' interests, the Australian Wheat Board needs to comprise members with appropriate specialist skills to guide Australian Wheat Board operations. The Australian Wheat Board is involved in funding and marketing a wheat crop worth around $3 billion annually in an increasingly complex financial environment and a depressed world market. It was not considered sufficient to rely on three members to provide guidance to management. Consultations have been held with the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation to resolve the issue of the extent of the grower majority on the Australian Wheat Board. It is now proposed that the 11-member Board will include one grower who also satisfies the criteria for selection as one of the four specialist members, in addition to the other five grower members and the grower chairperson. This proposal is incorporated in the amendments before the Parliament. The amendments have the support of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation and they meet the Government's requirements. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has seen the light and has agreed to amend the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1985 to give the wheat growers a more substantial voice on their own marketing board. In the autumn session, wheat growers were threatened with a grower selected grower minority on the new Wheat Board due to be operative from 1 October. The Opposition, with the support of the Australian Democrats in another place, sought to restore a grower majority by amending the Wheat Marketing Bill. Our amendments were unacceptable to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) but our action resulted in the Minister having to return to the conference table with the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation. This action gave the Federation the breathing space that it needed to seek a more acceptable resolution to this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to stress that the existing Board, with its responsibility for grower production with more than $3 billion a year, as the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) indicated, is under the direct control of grower-selected grower members who comprise 10 of the total Board of fifteen. The Minister for Primary Industry faced a hostile reaction in trying to ram through his original Bill allowing only five growers to be selected for the new 11-member Board by the selection committee. Of course, the industry was not prepared to wear this loss of control over its own product, and nor should it. It is a $3 billion crop, grown by wheat growers, held in trust by a board, and it would be ridiculous for there not to be a grower majority on that board to ensure that the growers' interests were properly taken into account.

It is encouraging that our actions in the other place have resulted in a far more rational result for wheat growers. It may not have been the most satisfactory result, but it is better than the original intention of the Minister. When returned to government, the Liberal and National parties will confer with the wheat industry on the form of board that is most suitable to the industry. However, this amended Bill provides for at least a majority of grower members placed on the Board through the selection committee because the amendments specify that at least one of the four specialist members will also be a wheat grower. There remains some loss of direct powers for the rank and file to elect their own members. What was a full voice now becomes a muffled voice in the selection process. The compromise solution, though, is far preferable to the Bill which came before this Parliament in May.

This Bill is one of four sets of legislation brought forward by the Minister for Primary Industry in the 12 sitting days of May which provoked antagonism in the farm sector. The Opposition was particularly concerned to assist the wheat industry achieve at least a majority of growers appointed by the selection committee. Our parties do not dispute the need for specialist expertise in such areas as finance and marketing on the Wheat Board, particularly now that the industry is 90 per cent export oriented and faces a very difficult world market outlook. At the same time the best way to equip the Board to meet these present day challenges is to continue vesting clear power with those who produce the crop. The most constructive role which government can play is to support the industry in its battle against high costs of production largely due to selfish, sectional self-interest actions rather than enhancing the most efficient means of handling and transporting the wheat crop. No matter how one structures the Australian Wheat Board, unless the Commonwealth and State governments are able to achieve a more responsible attitude from the trade union movement at the grain handling authority levels and at the waterfront, the wheat growers and, indeed, all Australians will continue to suffer enormous losses of income and trade performance as a result of these activities.

Undoubtedly, in New South Wales the level of industrial disruption is by far the worst in the Commonwealth. It is outrageous that the Australian wheat growers should be losing hundreds of millions of dollars in markets because of the irresponsible industrial actions being taken by certain trade unions in New South Wales whose members--

TALK.START.PARA: —And they acted up to Queensland.

—Absolutely. Those members are in some instances amongst the highest paid workers in the Commonwealth. Simply rearranging the structure of the Australian Wheat Board is like rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic unless the New South Wales Government comes to grips with the seriousness of the industrial disruption being caused to the wheat industry.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is borne out by Mr Sandow, of the Australian Wheat Board, who recently lamented the fact that the Board had to revise downward its export tonnage because of industrial disruption and the declining world market. Mr Sandow said that on the industrial front the wheat industry has so far this year lost the opportunity to load in excess of one million tonnes of wheat because of strikes, with more than half of the loss due to disputes in New South Wales.

Unfortunately the wheat growers of Australia generally are bearing the cost of this industrial irresponsibility. It is an outrageous state of affairs, and the actions of the irresponsible trade union leaders cannot be excused in any way. Notwithstanding the industrial disputation, Australia is expected to export a record 14.25 million tonnes of wheat this year. Unfortunately, there is a contraction of the world market. A number of factors have contributed to that contraction in recent months, including the United States-European Economic Community trade war and the high levels of production amongst some of the major importers. The villian in the piece is, of course, the EEC which is continuing to subsidise export sales heavily and is selling its product at well below the traditional floor price established by United States wheat prices. The United States has responded with its export enhancement program. This instability is contributing to a continuing decline in prices. Argentina has also drastically undercut prices, and it is alleged that that country is offering wheat prices well below the $US110 per tonne price level.

The world fall in wheat prices has not increased the level of wheat sales. The excellent seasons experienced by major importing countries, such as China and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, are largely responsible for the lack of growth in world sales. Some years ago we used to talk of the likely green revolution in the Third World and developing countries. That situation is now upon us. Therefore, we need a Board that is capable of making the right decisions, not only to hold existing markets but also to penetrate those new markets. Fuel is also a very heavily taxed commodity and that contributes to the problems facing Australian wheat growers at present.

The Opposition will not delay the passage of this Bill, and it is to be hoped that the Senate's approval can be gained this week to ensure that the new Board is operating upon the expiry of the present Board at the end of next month. Clearly the Bill has been poorly handled by the Government, and if delays occur the Minister for Primary Industry need look no further than his own Cabinet room to sheet home the blame. The Minister is on notice that the new Board structure will have to prove advantageous to the industry. As I said earlier, the Opposition will commit itself to entering into negotiations, when it takes over government, with the Australian Wheat Growers Federation to ensure that the industry has operating at the Board level the right structure, the right Board, the right type of system necessary to satisfy the interests of Australian wheat growers generally. The wheat industry does face difficult times and it must not be saddled with an unco-operative government or with a Board that does not satisfy the best interests of Australian wheat growers and the Australian wheat industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill provides for a restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board, to take effect on 1 October this year, and for a level of grower representation acceptable to the industry while at the same time meeting the Government's requirement of four specialist members. I am pleased to see that the Opposition supports this amendment although one gains the distinct impression from the comments of the honourable member for Gwydir and Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) that he is not particularly enthusiastic about the Opposition's support for this amendment. He referred this morning to fuel costs but he seemed to forget that there was some interesting news last night on excise rebates for diesel fuel. Those rebates are very important in the wheat growing areas of Australia. Those of us who know something about the wheat growing industry would be aware that fuel costs are a very important component when it comes to grain production in Australia. I am sure that this move by the Government to make a positive step in coming to grips with the question of the diesel fuel rebate will be welcomed, particularly by people in the grain growing areas.

SPEECH.PARA: One important point that the honourable member for Gwydir mentioned in his speech-something that I would like to dwell on for a few moments this morning-was the green revolution and the effect that it has had on trading nations such as Australia. Ten years ago it was very easy to talk about the green revolution and its effects on agricultural production in Third World countries. We can look at the effects of the green revolution from two points of view. From an humanitarian point of view what has happened in some of those underdeveloped countries is a marvellous achievement. For the first time many of those countries that previously faced great famine and had enormous difficulty in feeding themselves are able to grapple with that problem. But from our point of view, as a trading nation, it has been absolutely disasterous. As the honourable member for Gwydir mentioned, the green revolution, coupled with the effects of corrupted marketing policies, particularly of the European Economic Community with its common agricultural policy, and with the effects of the involvement of the United States of America in trying to influence world wheat prices and world wheat markets in the last few weeks, mean that Australia will face enormous difficulties, not only over the next few months but indeed over the next few years. That is why it is particularly important, when we look at the question of a restructured Wheat Board, to take into account the effect of the changing world scene when it comes to marketing agricultural commodities.

Without meaning any disrespect to growers-we have to admit that our farmers are among the most efficient in the world; there is no question about that-if a person is an efficient primary producer, in this case an efficient wheat farmer, it does not necessarily mean that that person is an expert in the area of marketing. I think it is important that we realise this and that growers concentrate on what they are best able to do; that is, to grow agricultural products in an efficient way, so that our products are available on world markets at the most competitive prices. That is why the Government, through the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), looked seriously at restructuring the Australian Wheat Board to take into account the changing world scene and the difficulties facing the world market with the intervention of the EEC and the United States, given some of their agricultural marketing policies. That is why I said, without meaning any disrespect whatsoever to growers, that it is important to realise that if a person is an efficient, able grower of wheat it does not necessarily mean that that person has tremendous marketing expertise. Some growers obviously do. But we need to make sure that those people whom we appoint to commodity boards such as the Australian Wheat Board have the sort of expertise that enables a major trading nation such as Australia to come to grips with some of the enormous difficulties which it is facing in world trade.

The honourable member for Gwydir mentioned that 90 per cent of Australian wheat is oriented towards world markets. Very small amounts are available for domestic consumption. I believe that that further adds to the case that the Government has been pursuing; that is, that on a restructured Board we need people with financial expertise. We need people who are able to recognise the changing situation with respect to marketing and to recognise that the effects of the green revolution that we talked about a few years ago are now coming home and, as I said before, have the potential of having disastrous effects on a major trading nation. I say that without taking anything away from the humanitarian side of that breakthrough.

I am pleased that the Opposition is being co-operative in the passage of this amendment Bill. It is important that we get the restructured Wheat Board in operation by 1 October. By co-operating in the passage of the Bill this morning, the Opposition is ensuring that the Minister will be able to make the necessary appointments so that the restructured Board will be in operation by 1 October. We do face enormous challenges. The world scene is in a constant state of flux. The ball game in marketing seems to change from day to day. All major countries that traditionally have been very efficient with respect to the production of grains are under enormous pressures because of the intervention of the European Economic Community and the United States of America with some of their grain marketing policies. It is particularly important that the restructured Wheat Board does come into operation as soon as possible because we want to make sure that the efficient wheat producers in Australia are in a position to be governed by a board that is not only representative of their interests as producers but also understands the changing needs of world commodity markets. The problems we face in marketing this agricultural product over the next few years will be fully taken into account by the new Wheat Board.

Once again, I thank members of the Opposition for their support of the amendments to the Wheat Marketing Bill. I take the opportunity of wishing members of the restructured Board which will operate from 1 October every success. They are going to need great support because the issues I have outlined mean that the changing world market place will place enormous difficulties on the growers in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising this morning to support the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), I am happy to join the Opposition and the Government in giving the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill passage. However, it struck me while the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) was delivering his speech that he was even more hesitant in his endorsement of this legislation than was the honourable member for Gwydir, whom he accused of being too reluctant in his embrace of this legislation. In fact, the honourable member for Calare was, if anything, rather reticent in endorsing the very legislation that is currently before the House. This legislation is in fact a victory for reasonableness. Had the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) been prepared to be less the twisted ideologue and a little more reasonable in dealing with this legislation when it was before the House earlier, the Bill would have been in place already.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the honourable member for Calare has made a plea, a plea for marketing representation on the Australian Wheat Board. I think we ought to bear in mind the simple fact that if the Wheat Board were freed from the present restrictions placed on it by the Public Service Board it could employ in the wheat growing executive the best brains in the industry or in the marketing world. But it is not free to do that. So currently we have this exercise in balance. How do we go about appointing a board that can, in fact, effectively market the Australian wheat crop without denying the wheat growers a voice on that board? That compromise has brought this legislation into the chamber this morning.

I contend that the shuffling about-face that we have seen from the Government on this legislation is the least the Government can do for the wheat growers of Australia. Like last night's Budget, in many ways the legislation before the chamber is a case of too little too late, but it is better than nothing. As everyone in this chamber knows, rural Australia is in revolt. According to the leader of the revolt, the President of the National Farmers Federation, Ian McLachlan, that revolt is likely to continue in spite of and, in some ways, because of last night's Budget. Most of Australia's wheat growers are in revolt. They are up in arms not because of some sort of political motive, but rather because of the economic climate in which they are forced to operate. The wheat farmers of Australia are acutely aware. They have the uncomfortable personal knowledge that things are slowly getting worse, in spite of the fact that during the term of this government there has been no nation-wide drought. In spite of the good seasons, still their plight becomes intractably worse.

No one has ever suggested that the Hawke Government invented rural poverty. The sad, inescapable fact is that under the Hawke Government it has been exacerbated, in spite of good seasons. Last night the wheat farmers of Australia, who are waiting for this legislation to pass, saw the Government bring in a Budget that made some effort to reduce marginally our deficit. However, the national debt under which this nation labours is still in place. There is still the increase in the public sector which has been characteristic of this Government. It is those two factors that add principally to the exporters' burden. The wheat farmers of Australia, who are the key exporters of Australia, face an interest bill on borrowed money-which has risen from 5 per cent of the value of the goods they exported-to 12 per cent. It is that sort of burden from which the wheat farmers seek some relief. In five years the farm costs under which these growers labour have gone up by 44 per cent, while the prices received for their produce-farm gate prices-have gone up by only 12 per cent. Worse than that, the taxes and charges foisted by this Government upon the men towards whom this Bill is projected have risen six times faster than have their returns.

All the wheat growers of Australia want is a fair go, not subsidies. All they seek in this legislation is reasonable representation on the Board that markets their produce. The point that ought to be addressed by the Government is that, were it prepared to free the Australian Wheat Board from the restrictions of the Public Service Board, it could employ the very expertise it needs in its executive. All the farmers seek from this legislation is a fair go, fair representation. However, from this Government it has been a long time coming. All the farmers seek is a fair go and a government that will take action when farmers are being illegally denied access to facilities that they should rightly have access to.

The honourable member for Gwydir has referred to the dilemma that faces farmers as a result of the disaster in regard to the Grain Handling Authority of New South Wales. Madam Chair, I will not wander very far from the Bill-certainly no further than did the honourable member for Calare-when for five seconds I draw attention to the Mudginberri abattoir dispute. Wheat farmers who are facing the dilemma of trying to export primary production without support from this Government face the same dilemma as producers in the Mudginberri area who do not have the support they are entitled to from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are taking a liberty there.

—As the honourable member for Melbourne wishes me to return directly to the wheat growing issue, I point out that it has been the very fact that the farmers of Australia have not had the support that they have sought from honourable members opposite which has meant that a million tonnes of grain has not been exported from Australia that should have been exported in the last year. Everyone on both sides of the House knows that selling grain is tough and likely to become increasingly tough in the world marketing climate. However, the present advantages we have are being eroded by the inaction of the Government to protect farmers from illegal disputes.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, the Government has claimed some credit saying that, as the dollar has fallen, the opportunity to export has increased. Of course we accept that. However, this very improvement in the state of the dollar as a result of its being floated has rapidly been eroded by action the Government has taken recently in introducing a dumping duty on diammonium phosphate which increases farmers' costs by $70 a tonne.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I trust that the honourable member will now return to the clause before the Committee.

—Absolutely, Madam Chair. As you would appreciate, the application of this phosphate is essential to the growing of grain in Australia, which is what the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill is all about. On precisely the same line, the fuel that is used by grain growers affects their costs-these costs are an important factor-as is representation on the Wheat Board. Honourable members may recall that the honourable member for Calare was anxious to point out to the House that the Government had taken action by reintroducing a fuel rebate. I ask the honourable member for Calare: If last night's proposal relating to the fuel rebate was such a positive step, why do we have to wait until 1 November for its introduction? What will the Government do about the $55m that it has picked up from the farmers as a result of its having denied them that rebate over the last 18 months?

SPEECH.PARA: Australian grain growers have enjoyed a long term growth of 2.8 per cent per annum. The number of people employed in growing Australia's grain has fallen by 7 per cent. The number of farms involved in growing Australian grain has fallen by 4 per cent per annum. Australian wheat farmers are producing more wheat, although fewer people are involved. It is, in fact, these people who now seek adequate representation on their wheat marketing board. I am prepared and happy to rise in support of this legislation, because it will give this dwindling number of Australian farmers better representation on the board that markets their produce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill before the Committee provides for a restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board. It represents a hard but fair debate between the industry and the Government over the composition of the Board. The Government has long held the view that a high degree of specialisation is required on a body like the Australian Wheat Board. We are talking about an industry which markets a crop worth around $3 billion annually. To perform this task successfully, the Wheat Board must have access to a high degree of expertise.

SPEECH.PARA: The world for primary producers is becoming increasingly complex and difficult to predict. The wheat crop this year, according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, is predicted to be the second highest on record. Eighty per cent of that crop will have to be sold for export. This will happen at a time when grain is becoming increasingly over-supplied on world markets. The United States of America and the European Economic Community will place enormous competition on our grain growers in the coming years. This will come at a time when the EEC has already distorted price movements on world markets. The devaluation of our dollar has helped lessen the burden on our primary producers but it has also led primary producers into a highly complex financial world. Expertise in money markets and overseas transactions is required if our farmers are to market their crop successfully. More than at any other time our wheat products need and require sound commercial judgments and intimate knowledge of overseas fluctuations. It is therefore desirable to have members on the Wheat Board who specialise in understanding these problems.

Under the terms of the 1984 Wheat Marketing Act, the Wheat Board is required to make advance payments to growers at a guaranteed minimum price. Grower payments for handling, storage and freight are all met by borrowings which are repaid by sales receipts over time. For instance, in 1983-84, the Wheat Board borrowed and turned over on short term domestic and international commercial money markets in excess of $6.5 billion. Moreover, borowings of the Wheat Board involved the establishment of domestic and overseas funding facilities totalling over $4 billion to cover the current season's payments and to service outstanding debt on wheat of previous seasons. These large sums of money must be accounted for by the Wheat Board. This can be successfully achieved only by the presence on the Board of people with a good knowledge of international currency arrangements.

The best illustration of just how simply an organisation can get into trouble on international money markets is the Queensland Grain Growers Association. This Association's problem began on 15 August 1983, when it was forced into voluntary receivership because of huge debts as a result of undisclosed foreign currency transactions. At a time when it believed that it was the soundest of all Australian farmer organisations, it suddenly found that it had liabilities exceeding its assets by millions of dollars. The depth of the problem is revealed by the following figures. Secured creditors were owed $13.6m of which the National Bank was owed about $11m. Of the unsecured creditors, six merchant banks were owed $8,042,000, the State Wheat Board was owed $1.75m, and the remaining $25.377m was owed to 3,200 members of the organisation. I am pleased to inform the House that in May of this year, the grain growers were able to come out of the receivership. They were eventually able to send their creditors 73.25 cents in the dollar.

However, the Queensland grain growers organisation did not emerge unscathed. A company was formed called Elders-Queensland Graingrowers Pty Ltd. Its new board membership will be of interest to the House. It comprises three representatives from Elders and three from the Queensland Grain Growers Association State Council. The Chairman comes from the Grain Growers Association but has no additional voting rights. I mention this example because many of its features are in this Bill. Even with every best intention, the growers own organisation was unable to avoid getting into serious financial difficulties because of the international monetary situation. Obviously, a specialist knowledge of international currency was needed and the growers association has achieved this. The new growers organisation, like the Australian Wheat Board, needed to be reshaped to ensure that this occurred.

The current Bill has been revamped and I believe is acceptable to the Australian Wheat Growers Federation. Previously, the Federation objected to its lack of a grower-selected majority because the chairperson was selected by the Minister for Primary Industry. The Government originally proposed an 11-member board comprising a grower chairperson, a Government member, five growers-one from each mainland State-and four specialist members. The Government's proposal provided for a grower majority, counting the chairperson, of six out of 11. In discussions with the Minister, I have been informed that the Australian Wheat Growers Federation has accepted the Government's proposal that one of the four specialist members also be a wheat grower. Therefore, the Wheat Board has increased grower representation while meeting the Government's requirements that the Board consist of members with the necessary skills to carry out its duties effectively.

As I indicated, the Bill enables the establishment of a selection committee for selecting members of the new Wheat Board. The committee will be chaired by Mr F. W. Millar, Chairman of Thomas Nationwide Transport Limited and L. J. Hooker Limited and a member of other major Australian public companies. Mr Millar is Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Selection Committee. Sir Leslie Price, Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, is also on the committee, together with five nominees of the Australian Wheat Growers Federation and two nominees of the National Farmers Federation. This legislation needs to be passed without further undue frustration from the Senate. The new composition of the Wheat Board is to apply from 1 October. The Committee, therefore, will have to have the names of any new members available to the Government before then.

The Bill demonstrates the continuing willingness of the Hawke Government to introduce policies which are good for the rural sector. I notice that the Minister recently announced $11m for rural research in 1985-86, of which $5.777m has been allocated to the wheat industry for 58 new and 113 continuing projects. These amounts form part of $68m which will be contributed by the Hawke pro-farmer Government and industry on a dollar for dollar basis.

Following discussions I have had with grain growers during the recess, I believe there are a number of points which need to be raised. I would like to see all governments continuing to address the very sensitive issue of soil conservation. I visited a property near Killarney in my electorate and I must tell the Committee how impressed I was with the variety of methods the farmer there was prepared to use. Soil conservation is one of the great issues facing all primary producers. I know the Minister is concerned about it and I would ask all members to familiarise themselves with the problem and look to solutions to it. The grain growers also want Government imposts kept down during these difficult times. This was addressed in the Budget last night. In this context, on behalf of all primary producers, I condemn the Queensland National Party Government for imposing an 8 per cent increase in freight charges and up to 100 per cent increases in third party insurance. These have been an unnecessary burden on wheat growers and farmers in general.

I am pleased to be able to support this amendment. This is a classic example of how the Government is prepared to listen to farmer organisations and to do what is in the best interests of the rural sector. It indicates that the Government has shown that it is prepared to listen. I am sure that the amendment will be supported by this House. I thank the Opposition for its support of the amendment and I am sure that it will have a speedy passage through the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this amendment, I first remind the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) of a couple of facts. He was rather keen to point out the losses of the Queensland Grain Growers Association due to the change in the exchange rate. He said that that Association got itself into financial difficulty. I can assure him that in Victoria there are quite a few government statutory bodies that have made very substantial losses, on paper at least, as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar. One of the bodies which springs to mind is the State Electricity Commission. At one stage that loss was well over $100m. I think there are quite a few others as well, which shows that statutory authorities can lose money on the exchange rate just as easily as anyone else.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that the honourable member seemed keen to make was that the Queensland Government had been raising freight charges. As I understand it, the Victorian Government will be raising freight charges in the next couple of weeks. The Government delayed the announcement until after the by-election-or re-election-that I am sure that we all heard about last week. Despite an undertaking that no government charges would increase faster than inflation, I gather the Victorian Government will be increasing freight rates by more than the rate of inflation, so it does happen in other States as well as Queensland.

To return to the amendment, it is interesting to look at its history. When the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) first proposed the changes to the structure of the Australian Wheat Board in October 1984, he made a rather curious threat to the Opposition. He said:
But I remind the Opposition that this is a package of legislation and, if it is held up, growers will not be paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is scandalous.

—That is right, it is scandalous. I thank the honourable member for Wakefield for that observation. The point is that the Minister came to this House and told us that either we support his package in total or he would hold the wheat growers of Australia to ransom. We called his bluff and he had to back off on that. But that shows the attitude that the Minister has towards primary industry, and we could cite many other examples. I think that the debate yesterday showed what he thought about the efforts of people up in the Northern Territory at Mudginberri.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has vacillated. It is now 10 months since that threat was made to the Opposition and now we have finally seen the Minister come to his senses and realise that we have an industry that is completely funded by itself, an industry that quite rightly can say that the growers should have the overall say in what is happening in their industry. No one is suggesting that they are the complete experts; there is still provision to have people with special expertise on the Wheat Board, and this compromise that the Minister has finally come to is very welcome, even though it has taken 10 months.

It is worth reminding honourable members of the size of the industry and its level of efficiency. It has already been said that it is an industry which has exports in excess of $2.7 billion in the coming year, which is 20 per cent of Australia's export earnings. It is a big industry. It is also an efficient industry. I remind honourable members of what the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said about the Australian wheat industry in the February 1984 Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy. It said:

Wheat production is one of the most efficient of all Australian industries. The level of assistance to the industry in recent years has been low (or even negative) and, except in occasional years of drought, the industry has continued to grow.

It is an industry that can hold its head up with pride and one which has succeeded. When that industry comes to the Government and says that it wants a grower majority on the Board, I think it can rightly claim that it has some justification for that.

The problems facing the industry have already been mentioned by the honourable member for Wakefield and the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). In real terms the price of wheat has increased by only about 2 per cent over the past five years. Over that same period the terms of trade of farmers have fallen by 20 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does the accord tolerate that?

—Unfortunately, the prices and incomes accord does not take that into account. That is why farmers are getting so restless. That is why we have seen marches all over Australia with over 100,000 farmers coming out in peaceful, orderly demonstrations to make the point that they are getting a little sick and tired of the increases in charges and costs and of the mindless pursuit of centralised wage fixing with no regard being paid to the capacity of an industry to pay wage increases. These are the sorts of things that I feel the Government ought to take into account when looking at primary industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the wheat industry. It is not just a question of farm costs. I think the members of the Wheat Board have been extremely frustrated over the last year by the sheer waste and inefficiency that have been going on in some of the State Government operated grain handling authorities. In my State of Victoria the Grain Elevators Board is being used as a tax collector. That is costing all Victorian grain growers another $5m a year. But that is nothing compared with what has been happening in New South Wales. The headline in the Australian of 12 January 1985 was `The $100m scandal'. That referred to the Grain Handling Authority of New South Wales. If we look at some of the other newspaper reports we will see in a bit more detail what has been going on. The Sydney Morning Herald of 7 August-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair has allowed a certain degree of latitude to all speakers. I realise that most people like to bring events in their own States into debates in the chamber, but I suggest that the honourable member has had enough latitude and should return to the matter before the chamber.
—Thank you, Madam Chair. I thought I could go on to grain handling as the honourable member for Rankin was talking about soil conservation.
—Each of you has had a bit of latitude in different directions.

—I will finish this point. As I have already said, the grain handling problems which are directly affecting the wheat growers and the Wheat Board have cost growers an awful lot of money in New South Wales. The New South Wales Minister, Mr Hallam, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The direct cost of the strike action represents hundreds of thousands of dollars in additional interest and demurrage charges . . . The loss of Australian reputation in the international marketplace is, however, incalculable.

I think those words sum up some of the real problems that the Wheat Board is facing. These are the sorts of problems which it will have to deal with now that the structure of the Board has been decided by this Government, and I hope it will be successful. The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir, said in his address that when we are returned to government, which I guess will not be too long now, the Liberal Party and the National Party will confer with the wheat industry on the form of a board that is most suitable for the industry. I think it is important to remind any wheat growers who happen to be listening that the Opposition parties are very mindful of the importance of the industry and that the Opposition is prepared to discuss the structure of the Wheat Board when it is returned to office and review its performance. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1985 I am struck with the fact that it is a compromise. Instead of having simply four members with expertise on the Australian Wheat Board we are going to have four members with expertise, at least one of whom is also a wheat grower. Obviously a limitation has been put on the membership. It has been put on, I think, by people of limited intellect. That should be apparent to everyone. We simply have a compromise which is not going to get the best possible result. That is not really surprising when we consider where this Opposition has come from. The truth is that amongst the ranks of the Liberal and National parties these days there are very few real farmers. It is a coalition of hereditary wealth. The National Party in particular is a party of lawyers, accountants and assorted drongos. Very few of us-
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. I ask that that statement be withdrawn. It is offensive to members of the National Party in particular.
—It is up to the Chair to decide whether the remark is unparliamentary or not. The remark was unfortunate but not unparliamentary.

—On the contrary, I thought the honourable member for Maranoa fitted admirably into the last category. It is true that very few of the people who sit opposite know what it is like to be a farmer. Very few of them have actually experienced the trauma of drought. Very few of the present honourable members opposite have had the sand and dust in their eyes as well the flies. That is something that should be remembered. My mind goes back to the rural outlook conference in January when the Chairman of the much-vaunted Board got up and said, I thought in a most doddery fashion: `We have always sold the wheat crop in the past and, if the farmers go on producing wheat, I suppose we will sell it in the future'. That was an outlook which failed completely to come to grasp with the complexities that farmers face today and it contrasted very markedly with the expertise of the Australian Wool Corporation. This is something that should be brought home to all wheat farmers. By getting the expertise on the Board we are going to be able to do for wheat farmers things which they desperately need to have done. There is no doubt that, as the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrews) pointed out, the cost pressure on farmers is rising and the terms of trade have been moving against farmers in the wheat industry since 1974. That is not due to the specific action of any government; it is simply an effect of the world situation. But there are things that can be done to counter that. I suggest that if members of the Board have expertise in marketing, finance, transport, storage, research and industrial relations, which is an element which honourable members opposite never give any consideration to-
—Stick to the Bill.

—I am dealing pertinently with the Bill because I am telling those opposite, as they obviously do not know, the advantages that will come from having a Board which has more expertise. There are very big dollars to be saved by farmers by enhancing this expertise. This is one area where the cost pressure can be contained and where farmers can benefit by many hundreds of millions of dollars. I am sure that in the long run farmers will appreciate that more than they appreciate the barren, sterile ideology which honourable members opposite go on with.

SPEECH.PARA: Other factors affecting farmers are not being addressed. We hear so much about cost pressure but we hear very little about market prices. Market prices are going to be down next year, despite the fact that we devalued the Australian dollar. That is an action which the Opposition now gives us credit for, but which it never had the nerve to take. We also benefited the farmers by providing for the introduction of foreign banks, a thing which the Opposition said for years it would do but never had the nerve to do. This will introduce more expertise into the rural areas. There will be more imaginative financial packages. Many farmers are facing a desperate situation. I say for the benefit of the honourable member for Wakefield that the fact is that it is immediately after a drought that the cost pressure is on farmers as that is when drought loans have to be repaid. No matter what the rate of interest, if the capital is being repaid in very large lump sums the cost to farmers is very hard to bear.

The farmers of this country are facing mortgage sales. Those sales are never proposed by the banks, which are the friends of the Opposition; they are always proposed by the vendors or by the hire purchase companies. It should be recognised that behind every hire purchase company in this country stands a bank. We hear-and we have heard it from this side of the chamber, too-that the farmers in this country are efficient. It was true but it is not true today. While farmers may be efficient, if they are operating in very marginal country the effect of their efficiency is lost.

It is interesting that last year for the first time in Australia a 10 tonne per hectare crop was grown. It was grown in Tasmania on land which was classified by our agricultural experts as marginal grazing land. The farmer said that he grew it entirely with British expertise; he used nothing else but expertise which he had gleaned from the British. He drained his land and grew that 10 tonne per hectare crop. That farmer is an efficient farmer who will survive in these years of high cost pressure.

I think we will see wheat growing in the future moving into the wetter areas with the introduction of wheat varieties more suitable to high rainfall areas. This is an area that has been neglected in Australia, for very little work has been done in this country on productivity increases. That is a fact. That does not indicate efficiency in the industry. It may very well mean that we collectively, as a nation, have to look again at plant variety rights, because I believe the present system has failed us. We talk about the green revolution in Third World countries. That is not where the pressure has come from. The green revolution that has affected us has come from the dynamic increase in productivity in developed countries.

Let us look at marketing. I have said in the House many times that it always amazes me that those opposite who support the free enterprise system, the great champions of free enterprise, simply have no idea how the market works. Their counterparts in the United States sought to gain a greater share of the world market by offering a 20 per cent discount on wheat. If 100,000 tonnes were bought, 20,000 tonnes would be given. They thought that this was sure to enhance their market share. It did not, of course, and predictably it would not, because people simply took. The purchasers simply said `This is a 20 per cent discount', and went into the market and extracted it from everyone else. This action in the United States, as much as anything, is going to force down the price of wheat next year; it stands as another monument to the sterility of those who so avidly support the free enterprise system.

Another thing we need to look at here is the fact that farmers, despite the fact that they are very big producers of an export commodity, are a minority in the community. One of the great problems facing Australia today is that so much of its population lives in the cities. This problem is not recognised by many people. I have heard repeatedly in this place, and particularly in the toy parliaments that abound in the States, about the inefficiency of the transport system. One of the reasons that the transport system in this country is inefficient is that nobody lives in the country any longer. Freight tends to go one way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It behoves me to point out to the honourable member that, while considerable tolerance has been allowed by occupants of the chair in the debate, I would appreciate his returning to the amendments before the Committee.
—Mr Deputy Chairman, I would be delighted to do that. I thought I ought to take the same liberties as everyone else so that you would not feel embarrassed.
—That tolerance has already been allowed.

—Right. In conclusion, I would say that this is a compromise amendment. I am quite happy with it. I believe that it will enhance the operation of the Board, but I think that farmers have to look to themselves to make sure that this Board works efficiently. They have to cast off many of the shibboleths attached to the industry and approach these areas of marketing, transport, storage, research and industrial relations with a much more hard-nosed and pragmatic outlook.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In opening my speech I remind the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), who unfortunately has left the chamber, that today the Government does not put any money into the wheat industry. The wheat growers of Australia finance their own industry totally, and the only taxpayers' funds that go into the industry are approximately 8 per cent of the research moneys spent. No other money is expended by the Government. In actual fact, all the Government is interested in is ripping funds out of wheat growers by way of fuel levies and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Committee that only six weeks ago 50,000 farmers stood outside this building in the biggest rally we have ever seen in Australia to breathe down the necks of this Government and to breathe down Bob Hawke's neck. He went out to address those people and not one of them gave him a clap or a cheer. Fifty thousand people booed him. It was not until those people were prepared to leave their farms and spend some money to get down here that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) was prepared to make any adjustment. I remind the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) that I am a farmer, that I go home and plough my paddocks and that I know a little of what I am talking about. SPEECH.PARA: One of the major problems for the wheat industry in respect of the export of grain is the dissatisfaction of the Japanese Government which will not take one grain of wheat out of the corrupted New South Wales Labor-controlled outfit. Because of the inspectors wheat is going out of New South Wales so contaminated that the Japanese Government has told the New South Wales Government that it will not receive a grain of wheat from that State. There have been 11 cases of contamination. Snails and all sorts of things have been found in the grain from a Labor-controlled State.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard a lot from the honourable member for Kalgoorlie about farm costs and so on. Of course, last night we saw a reduction in the excise on fuel. That should have happened long ago. Last night it gave them back $21m. That leaves a net take of $64m in the last 12 months. If that is not increasing taxation, I do not know what is.

—It is true. Farmers use 1,300 megalitres of diesel, 16 per cent of total use in Australia, and they use 5 per cent of the petrol used in Australia. If the honourable member for Kalgoorlie does his figuring, and we might be drongos but I regard him as a buffoon--

—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will resume his seat. I point out to honourable members speaking to these amendments that they are not making speeches at the second reading stage. SPEECH.PARA: We need more money for research. Of its total outlays the Government is spending only 8 per cent on research for the industry. Australia also needs exports, because our balance of payments position is a disaster, and those exports include buffalo meat as well as wheat. As to Mudginberri, the Commission has ruled that the unions must not be allowed to get away with what is going on there. Farmers are suffering. The real increase in taxation last night was 8 per cent for farmers, and that increase is over and above other costs such as insurance, fuel, and so on. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak in support of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1985. This amending legislation, as you have pointed out, Madam Chair, concentrates on the wheat industry, so I propose to keep my remarks broadly in line with the legislation, as you have suggested. Before I touch on the legislation, however, I should like to make a few points about the importance of the wheat industry to the Australian economy. It has been pointed out by previous speakers that the wheat industry is one of Australia's largest export industries. My recollection is that exports of about $2.7 billion are gained by our sales of wheat in the international market. It is an industry which accounts for 20 per cent of our exports and it makes a major contribution to our export earnings. As has been pointed out in many reports on the wheat industry, it is one of our most efficient and most productive industries. All Australians can be proud of the productivity gains made by the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The wheat industry is very important in my local area. I have large grain-growing and wheat-growing areas surrounding my electorate of Bendigo, and within my electorate St Arnaud, Donald and Charlton are major wheat-growing areas within the Victorian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good areas, too.

—As the honourable member for Mallee points out, they are good areas. I was delighted to pick up two of those areas in the redistribution of electoral boundaries that occurred last year. I have been working very closely with the citizens and farmers of those areas since my re-election last December.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned that the wheat industry is one of Australia's most efficient industries, and that brings me to the specific point of this legislation. Its aim is to ensure that the industry becomes even more efficient, in the sense that the returns for the industry as a whole are maximised, from the point at which grain is sown to the point at which it is sold overseas. This particular aspect of the legislation deals with the establishment of the Australian Wheat Board and the representatives who will sit on it. As honourable members are aware, this amending legislation has come back from the Senate because amendments were made to it by the Senate. Since the Bill was considered by the Senate, the Government has had further discussions with the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation in an attempt to resolve the main issue, that is, the extent of the grower majority on the Board. Extensive consultations have taken place, and I think we have resolved that issue satisfactorily. The 11-member Board will now include one grower who also satisfies the criteria for selection as one of four specialist members, in addition to the other five grower members and the grower chairperson. Except for the chairperson, all growers will be selected by the Australian Wheat Industry Selection Committee, which also has on it a majority of growers.

The agreement which has culminated in the amendments before the House has the support of the Wheatgrowers Federation, and, importantly, it also meets the Government's requirements that the Wheat Board structure allows for the appointment of members with specialist skills which are necessary to respond most effectively to the present-day challenges facing the Wheat Board. There are many challenges indeed. the financial world has become exceedingly complex. It is for that reason that the Government has moved to provide more expertise in this area, so that the Board itself is best suited and best arranged to maximise the possible returns for Australian wheat growers.

As previous speakers have said, an element of compromise is entailed in this amendment. On the one hand, the Government is satisfying its objective of providing a greater degree of expertise in the new structure of the Wheat Board; on the other hand, the Government is satisfying the interests of wheat growers who have been concerned about the extent of the grower majority on the Board. From my discussions with local pastoral councils and grain councils of the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association, and through recent visits by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to my electorate, when we had discussions with many farmers, I know that this issue has been one of concern. I am now sure that wheat growers can be satisfied that a satisfactory resolution has been found by the Government in the spirit of proper co-operation and consensus for which this Government has become renowned in most of its activities.

I have emphasised that through this legislation and through all of our policies affecting primary industry, it is the Government's intention to provide a greater degree of specialist skill so that we can maximise the returns available throughout an industry and, particularly, the returns available to our farmers. As I think all honourable members would know, Australia's primary industries, particularly the wheat industry, have been experiencing and will continue for some time to experience difficult circumstances in terms of their rate of profitability. World stocks of wheat are again increasing. This year the European Economic Community will be subsidising wheat production by some $5 billion a year. The United States of America is subsidising wheat production by some $2 billion per annum. In an international setting it will be extremely difficult for Australian farmers, no matter how efficient they are, to compete. We simply cannot match the degree of subsidy which large industrialised countries with much larger industrial and population bases, such as the countries of the EEC and the United States of America, can provide for their farmers. So it is crucial that our farmers remain efficient and that the boards we establish to market their products have the best members available and are specialist and skilled enough to capitalise on and to maximise the benefits that exist overseas in marketing and financial opportunities.

It has been mentioned that over recent years the terms of trade have moved against Australian wheat growers to the tune of 20 per cent. That simple statistic simply reinforces the need for the establishment of a new Board such as is proposed in this legislation, so that we can improve our efficiency. That is one side of it; the other side, touched on by a number of speakers, is that whilst we can maximise our marketing skills and financial skills through the Wheat Board for the sale of wheat overseas, we must also ensure that every possible incentive is given to our wheat growers to reduce the rate of increase of their farm costs and to ensure that they are given every opportunity to become even more efficient.

In the context of those remarks and in the context of the remarks of some Opposition speakers, I want to mention briefly two matters which have been raised by many speakers in this debate. They relate to the cost aspect of producing wheat in Australia. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) concluded by saying that perhaps two things were paramount to our wheat farmers. The first was that there was a greater need to reduce cost pressures on wheat farmers; the second was that the Government should be doing away with the system of centralised wage fixing. These matters relate indirectly to the establishment of the Australian Wheat Board. It does stick in my craw a little to hear Opposition members in this House attack this Government for its alleged failure to take action on farm costs, because no government in the last 15 years has a better record of reducing farm costs than this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, John!

—The simple fact is that under the previous Government-of which the honourable member for Mallee, who now interjects, was a member-the average rate of increase in farm costs exceeded 12 per cent per annum. For each of the eight years of the Fraser Government the average increase exceeded 12 per cent. There is not one member of the National Party of Australia-the Party that purports to have the interests of primary producers at heart, though of course it does not; that is a fraud-or one member of the Liberal Party of Australia who can deny that figure.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up this debate where the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) left off, by saying that his Government has abolished income equalisation deposits and tax averaging provisions for farmers, and that has resulted in a direct add-on cost to wheat growers in particular. It has taken a range of lowest common denominator political measures as part of its so-called consensus approach and that has done nothing but add to the costs of wheat growers, especially in isolated areas where the fuel component has a much greater effect than it does for people who use fuel in Sydney and Melbourne. The honourable member for Bendigo must come to see these things in proper and true perspective by examining more fairly the record not only of this Government of lowest common denominator politics but also of the previous coalition Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill with the proposed amendment. I draw attention particularly to the commencement of the Senate's message, which says:
Having regard to the fact that the Australian Wheat Board is an entirely self-funded body that is wholly and solely responsible for the disposal of its product . . .

That highlights the fact that the Australian Wheat Board is about its own business. The Wheat Board is self-funding and, following the most recent amendments to the Board of just a few years ago, it has even lost certain Reserve Bank of Australia facilities associated with financing the crop. I contrast that with the situation in Western Australia. That State's Co-operative Bulk Handling Ltd organisation under the chairmanship of Mick Gayfer has a tremendous record in shifting the Western Australian crop. I highlight CBH because it is also an efficient, self-funding organisation. How many government representatives are on the Board of Co-operative Bulk Handling Ltd? Nil; none whatsoever. That should be considered by people such as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who weighed into this debate with an insulting attack on the efficiency of Australian farmers, and it ought to be considered by the other Labor members who have reflected on the Australian Wheat Board and its marketing assessments. I know that the likes of Hendy Cowan, Monty House, Crawford Nalder and others will be sheeting home in Western Australia the comments of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie as they approach the next election in that State. The Bill before the House is central to the structure of the Australian Wheat Board in these crisis times for the wheat industry.

All honourable members have made reference in this debate to the role of the European Economic Community. It is right that members on both sides should mention the EEC, because the world is awash with grain. I want to highlight three key factors in relation to the EEC. First, in July-at last-the EEC produced a Green Paper on the common agricultural policy, and for the first time it used dialogue which injected market reality into the operation of the CAP. It is to be hoped that it moves further down that path. Secondly, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural Economics is to launch a seminar in Europe later this year to highlight the cost of the common agricultural policy to European consumers and governments. That is also a step in the right direction. Thirdly, seven of the EEC's commissioners at the moment-including Andriesson, the agricultural commissioner who I understand will be visiting Canberra in the week commencing 9 September-are former Finance Ministers. We know how tough and cranky former Finance Ministers are in respect of subsidies and it is to be hoped that having seven former Finance Ministers in the EEC might lead to some restructuring of the common agricultural policy along fundamental lines. That will help the Australian wheat industry and, in turn, it will help the vital work carried out by the Australian Wheat Board. It will now be able to continue to carry out that work following the passage of this Bill through the House of Representatives and the Senate. This legislation finally provides for the Board's restructuring along proper lines. It is only because of National Party of Australia senators and other senators constituting a majority in the Australian Senate that this victory has been achieved and the Federal Government has changed its mind on the important matter of the composition of the Australian Wheat Board. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill with the proposed amendment, but I must say I am not too happy with this outcome. It is not a satisfactory result. We sought in this House to implement in the legislation Australian Wheatgrowers Federation policy, which of course demanded that two growers from each State, elected by the growers, be on the Australian Wheat Board. It is a formula that over the years has proved to be highly satisfactory. The Board is one of the most successful wheat marketing authorities in the world. When I was in America some months ago the American wheat growers looked at the Australian wheat marketing situation with envy, particularly at the way it produced equity between growers no matter what their geographical position may be. Such a situation will not be retained under this Bill. We tried to amend the original legislation by suggesting that the 11 members proposed for the Wheat Board be reduced to 10 and that growers be given a majority. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), to his credit, has achieved that aim in a different manner, by ensuring that one of the four specialist members on the 10-member Board will be a grower.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the serious problems still facing the Australian Wheat Board is the appointment of executive staff. There is no reason why such a board should not be able to appoint experienced people, from any walk of life, with the talents it requires. The Board is restricted in that it still has to appoint under Public Service restraints. Therefore, the Government's response to the request of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation is still only a muffled one.

I am disturbed that in almost every piece of rural legislation introduced into this House over past months three major things seem to be happening. The first is that the Government is attempting to take control of rural marketing structures. In some cases it has been successful; in others it has not. The second problem is that the Government is trying to remove from government itself and from the taxpayer in general any risk in relation to marketing products. The impact upon the industry of underwriting schemes is being reduced, as is the safety net they provide for our agricultural industry. The third thing that all agricultural legislation under this Minister is trying to do is bring about a cheap food policy. This has occurred in almost every area: In dairying, where the dairy farmers cannot get a satisfactory price for their product; in dried fruit, where the Government is trying to reduce the price of dried fruit on the domestic market; and in wheat, where the Minister in his earlier speech said he hoped to reduce the price of bread on the domestic market, despite the fact that our domestic costs are increasing at an enormous rate. These are the three policies that the Government is attempting to impose on rural industry in this country. I am very disturbed about that.

Why should an industry that is self-funded lose control of its own affairs when it has performed so admirably in the past? I believe also that the Government is trying to suggest to the Australian wheat industry that the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation should be able to perform the same role as the expanded Australian Wheat Board did in the past. I think this is entirely wrong. The Australian Wheatgrowers Federation is the agropolitical arm of the wheat industry, whereas the Australian Wheat Board, which is quite separate, should be the marketing arm. This valuable industry is bringing in something like $3 billion annually to the Australian economy. I am very concerned that the Government is attempting to make changes that will have a dramatic effect on the marketing of our products.

As my electorate of Mallee has produced all the Wheat Board members from Victoria over many years, I would like to pay tribute to four people in particular in relation to the Wheat Board. I mention firstly Mr Jim Nuske of Katyil who, for many years, has been the outstanding member of the Australian Wheat Board. He has been responsible for so many of the dramatic changes and initiatives that have taken place. I mention secondly the late Miles Bourke of Donald, who was also a very valuable member of the Wheat Board for a number of years. Mr Vin Delahunty of Murtoa and Mr Barry Bishop of Waitchie are the present Victorian members of the Australian Wheat Board, although this will change as a result of the change in the structure of the Board. All those people were from the Mallee electorate-the electorate that produces up to 60 per cent of Victoria's grain harvest.

I wish to refer briefly to some of the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby). He referred to past years. I remind him that farm costs have increased by 44 per cent in the last two years, whereas the average prices that have been received by primary producers right across Australia have risen by only 12 per cent. I remind him that during the 1970s average annual farm incomes were in the vicinity of $25,000, whereas the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has calculated that this year average annual farm incomes in Australia will be as low as $6,000. When we have the impact of these figures and have the enormous domestic regulations and costs they have to bear we can notice the vast difference in the rural situation. This is the reason why 40,000 rural people marched in the streets of Melbourne and 40,000 rural people protested outside Parliament House some weeks ago.

The major problem that the wheat industry faces is fuel prices. It is pathetic for the Government to say that it did anything last night in the Budget for fuel prices. All it did last night in the Budget in relation to fuel was to restore the exemption for the use of diesel fuel off-road-something that it imposed. We had in place an exemption for the use of diesel fuel off-road for years prior to Labor coming to office. All this Government has done is restore that exemption. In fact, this Government has not even restored it because indexation on fuel still applies every six months and this impacts on rural and country people, who are major users of petroleum and diesel fuel on-road.
This Government has made much of the fact that it has removed the tariff on headers. It should remember that it imposed that $14m tariff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable member to return to the amendment before the chamber. The Bill is not before the chamber; just the amendment.
—Madam Chair, these things were mentioned by the honourable member for Bendigo.

—I realise that. I have given the honourable member a fair go in replying to quite a few of the extraneous matters that were brought up. I suggest that he use the rest of his time on speaking to the Bill.

—Madam Chair, in deference to you, I refer finally to the enormous burdens that are being created in the wheat industry as a result of the problems that exist in the Grain Handling Authority of New South Wales. Two hundred and seventy million dollars has been lost because of strikes. Today the Japanese are refusing to buy wheat from New South Wales because of the unreliability of shipping. They have demanded that the high quality wheat, the hard wheat, be shipped only from Queensland as there is some reliability in the industrial situation in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude simply by congratulating the new Chairman of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation, Ron McLeod, for the strength he has shown in his negotiations with the Government. It is a far cry from the position last year when we were faced with the situation where the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) resorted to blackmail and said that he would not pay the growers if the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation did not agree with him and where he tried to cajole and seduce the leadership at that time into accepting what was not the best outcome for the wheat industry. It is an acceptable outcome but it is not the best. If problems develop in the wheat industry, as they probably will over the next few months because of the world market situation, I am very concerned that we will not be placed as well as we should be to meet those problems and to ensure that the Australian wheat industry remains one of our major primary industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those members of the Government and the Opposition who participated in the debate. Whilst it was a wide-ranging discussion, in many ways it was an inconsistent type of discussion, particularly from members of the Opposition. Last evening the Treasurer (Mr Keating) made it very clear that the Government is concerned about the difficulties being faced by the rural sector and is determined to assist the rural sector in meeting the problems that it is facing in competing in a market that is heavily subsidised by governments abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: That being said, we do rural Australia no service by looking for the quick fixes and the easy ways out of the National Party of Australia of old, of buying people off and of leading people to believe that they can stay on the land and that they can always do the things they used to do in the way they used to do them. We are not in that business. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is not in that business. The Minister for Primary Industry has been concerned about the development of a sound economic and marketing base for rural Australia so that not only are our products produced efficiently but also we are taking maximum advantage of the opportunities that are available in the markets abroad.
