We all recognise that the European Economic Community is making inroads into traditional markets for our rural products.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia and the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), referred to problems with the movement of grain. A number of speakers from the other side of the chamber also made some mention of these problems, including the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher). The problems with the movement of grain are not new. In fact, they hark back to the inclusion in the Constitution of the Inter-State Commission. Obviously at that time the founders of the Constitution had in mind the problems of grain movement between States, freight rates and services. So it goes back that far. If one looks at the amendment before the chamber one will see a reference to these problems. The amendment states:
. . . 4 other members,--
referring to members of the Board-
each of whom has had extensive experience at a high level in finance, marketing or grain movement logistics and at least one of whom is a wheat grower . . .
The concern expressed by the Deputy Leader of the National Party and by others about those problems is meant to be addressed--

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Wheat Board does not do it; it is the Grain Handling Authority.
—I thought the honourable member would assume that I was aware of that.
—I am reminding you.

—I thank the honourable member. The problems in that area are problems that need to be addressed by governments. We certainly need on the Board people with that kind of expertise. What the Minister wants from the Board is the best possible performance in the interests of rural Australia. In the area of finance, the obtaining of finance and the use of finance, we need people with competence and experience. This situation applies similarly to marketing and, as I said, grain movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the discussion from members of the Opposition has centred upon fuel prices. I find those comments the most hypocritical of all. Never let the farmers of this country ever forget that the founder of the import parity pricing policy was the former right honourable member for Richmond, the then Leader of the National Party. Members of the National Party should never come into this chamber and belabour us with the results of their doings. The National Party Leader trumpeted around Australia for years that the price of fuel was too low. He fathered that policy. Honourable members opposite have to carry it. This country is stuck with it. In seven disastrous years the previous Government managed to treble the price of fuel. Yet honourable members opposite have the temerity to raise these matters in this debate, having been allowed great latitude by Madam Chair. They are of their own doing. It is their own child. They should look after it. This Government recognises the problems that we have there. Last night's decision to extend the full rebate on diesel excise to primary producers recognises that problem. But it goes much deeper than that; it goes to the strength and planning of the economy, the development of growth and the maximisation of marketing effort if we are going to give rural Australia the kind of growth, certainty and security that it is entitled to and that Minister Kerin wants to see developed.

The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) referred to the national debt. This is another one of the lines now being hawked around by the National Party. Sixty-five per cent of the national debt is in the private sector. The growth in national debt has not been in the public sector, it has been in the private sector, much of it to do with company takeovers and corporate expansion, not to do with the expansion of productive capacity. Opposition members should get that one right. If they are going to peddle that line they should make sure their facts are right.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Whitlam debts that have to be rescheduled now?

—Look at the explosion, my friend, in Government debt when the Opposition came into office in 1976-77. Look at the explosion in these years straight after 1975. But suffice to say the growth in national debt has been in the private sector, not in the public sector. As Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation I find it rather galling to sit and listen to debates-there would be hardly a member of the National Party who has not written to me at some time asking for major projects and major works that involved expansions in public expenditure-in which honourable members say: `But public expenditure is too high'. I describe the National Party members as political schizoids. In the morning they want less expenditure, but after 12 noon they want more expenditure. Honourable members opposite should make up their minds on this matter. They cannot have it both ways. If they are going to criticise public expenditure they ought to be setting an example by not making representations for more airports, roads and bridges; they should do one thing or the other. So there is no substance to that comment.

SPEECH.PARA: The real issues are in the quality of representation on the Board itself and the expertise and competence of the people who are represented. That was originally embraced in the Bill put forward by Minister Kerin. The Board would comprise members with appropriate specialist skills and expertise in finance, marketing and movement logistics.

Whilst I have listened to criticism of Minister Kerin, some of it not very complimentary, I just want to say that he is recognised across this country as the most competent primary industry Minister. If that hurts Opposition members, they should remember that he is certainly recognised as the most popular. It is his determination to develop a sounder economic and market base for rural Australia. This legislation is part of his plan. I commend the amendments to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be supporting the Building Industry Bill 1985 and will be assisting the Government in its expedition through this House and the other place. We do so despite the extremely limited time given to us by the Government to scrutinise this Bill. We were led to understand that the office of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) would deliver a copy to us on Monday morning but we did not get a copy until just over 24 hours ago. In the interim we had to rely on a copy of the explanatory memorandum which is hardly a substitute for the Bill itself. The Minister is not here, but I must say that this is not his style and I do not lay the blame at his feet. We all know why. Despite the months-in fact, the years-of outrageous Builders Labourers Federation behaviour on building sites around Australia, the left wing of the Australian Labor Party staged a desperate last ditch stand to stop this Bill coming through even their own party forums. Caucus went to a vote and Australia should know that this Bill appears in this House with the barest of Caucus margins. The situation is even worse in Victoria. In that State the stronghold of the BLF is also the stronghold of the Socialist Left. We see moves within the Labor Party in Victoria to, of all things, establish an inquiry into the conviction of Mr Norm Gallagher and to have the State Government repeal its own legislation providing for the deregistration of the BLF. Make no mistake about it; large sections of the Labor Party are being dragged to the barrier on this question of BLF deregistration by Labor governments no longer able to withstand the weight of public and industry pressure to do something about this union. Let this Federal Government know that we, in the Opposition, will be watching its action every step of the way.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time allotted to me I would like, firstly, to consider the history of deregistration proceedings against the BLF during the 1980s. On 17 February 1981 Andrew Peacock, in his capacity then as Minister for Industrial Relations in the Fraser Government, sought and gained Federal Cabinet approval to commence deregistration proceedings against the BLF. On 26 September of that year the deregistration proceedings initiated by Andrew Peacock were commenced. On 8 November 1982 a Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia started hearing the joint application of the Federal Government and the National Construction Industry Council for the deregistration of the BLF. Shortly afterwards the Hawke Government was elected to office. Its first and current Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations applied to the Federal Court for an adjournment of proceedings, which was granted on 21 March 1983.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you, honourable members and in fact the Australian community should note how high a priority de-activating the deregistration proceedings was for the Hawke Government, with the adjournment being obtained, when the Government had only been in office for just over a fortnight. Two and a half years later with the appearance of this Bill in this place we can hardly resist the opportunity to say: `We told you so'. A futile series of efforts to bring Hawke-style consensus to bear in the building industry followed and it was a crashing failure. In April 1983 the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations established the national building and construction industry conference. He did this ostensibly to pursue `solutions' to the industrial relations problems of the building industry-solutions which did not include the deregistration of the BLF. On 12 December 1983 the Minister announced the Government's withdrawal from the deregistration proceedings having supposedly obtained undertakings of good behaviour from the BLF which were underwritten by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. However, the employers did not withdraw from the case at this time, which undermines the Minister's assertion that they, the employers, were reluctant parties to the deregistration proceedings dragged in at the behest of the Fraser Government. From the time that the Federal Government withdrew from the deregistration proceedings there was virtually ceaseless BLF disruption in the building industry.

The Minister has accurately and capably outlined the BLF's specific crimes of industrial delinquency in his second reading speech on this Bill which we heard in this House yesterday. It was tough going for the employers left in the deregistration proceedings on their own. They finally withdrew from the case in the middle of 1984. They did so in exchange for undertakings from the Federal Government that it would take effective action against the BLF if that union failed to comply with the building industry peace agreement, finally signed by the BLF a few months after the cessation of the deregistration proceedings. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations both gave their personal guarantees that the building industry peace agreement would be observed by the BLF. Subsequent events proved how worthless the imprimatur of those gentlemen was in regard to this industrial relations agreement. I hope that when next employers hear of a special relationship this Government has with the trade union movement and when they hear this Government say `Trust us' in respect of industrial relations agreements, they will remember this exercise with the BLF.

The Minister alludes to the BLF's long list of sins: The limitations, the bans, the spoiled concrete pours, the walk-offs, the homers, the thuggery, the violence and the intimidation. There can be no doubt that all of this was and is true. The Minister makes the point in passing that often it has been other workers, as much as employers, who have suffered at the hands of the BLF. I can confirm how true this has been. In my wanderings around construction sites across Australia there has been no end of BLF members who plead with someone to take action against this union. As individual men with wives and family responsibilities they have found it beyond their wit and capacity to stand out against the thuggery of the BLF elite and leadership.

It is difficult to find words to express the downright outrageous breaches of common human decency and fairness the BLF has prepetrated and will continue to prepetrate while it survives. Right here in the city of Canberra there has been a terrible instance of just such an injustice. A skilled and experienced tradesman has had his career effectively terminated because of a BLF black ban which made him too hot to handle for the construction companies around town. His sin was to call for a secret ballot about strike action on site. However, despite being guilty of nothing more than honesty and application to his job, the BLF ban has led virtually to complete economic and emotional ruin for this man. An industrial relations system which tolerates such an injustice is truly deficient and must, as a matter of urgency, be changed. The Minister says, in his second reading speech:
The time has passed for yet another `last chance'.

We agree that the time has passed for yet another last chance. More accuractely, we believe that point had been reached by early 1981, when the previous coalition Government decided to begin deregistration proceedings. As I stated in opening my remarks, we will support the passage of the Bill. However, the question still remains: Why did the present Federal Government terminate the deregistration proceedings in the first place? Was it terminal industrial relations naivety? Perhaps. Was it the belief that the mighty word of the messiah would turn the BLF bad boys into good guys? There is probably something in that suggestion. I do not wish to explore further possible explanations for the Government's stupidity in terminating the deregistration proceedings in the first place. I simply wish to point out that the Government was wrong, that the BLF did over the Government, and that the BLF made the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relation look foolish in relation to the building industry peace agreement.

This Bill is a much belated attempt by the Government to restore its credibility on the BLF question. As an attempt to do so, it is not without flaws. It is not our intention to move amendments to the Bill. However, I wish to make some comments on its clauses. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is not in the chamber, and I understand and accept without hearing a reason that there are probably good reasons for that being so. I would be grateful if his adviser could note the eight points we make and, at the conclusion of the debate, they may be addressed.

I turn first to clause 4 of the Bill, which deals with an application to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a declaration in relation to the BLF, or `the Federation' as it is termed in the Bill. The application is to be made by the Minister. I note this statement at the conclusion of the Minister's second reading speech:
As soon as the legislation is passed, I will be applying to the Commission for the declaration which is required under the Bill before any action can be taken against the BLF.
I refer to section 143 (1) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904, which states:
Any organisation or person interested, the Minister, the Bureau or the Registrar, may apply to the Court for an order directing the cancellation of the registration of an organisation . . .
Various grounds for doing so are then set out. Section 106 (2) of the Act states:
The last preceding sub-section shall not be construed as limiting the power of the Court to grant leave to a person or organisation . . .

I cite those sections of the Act only to contrast the Act with the situation under this Bill whereby only the Minister is able to make application to the Commission to make a declaration in respect of the Federation. We support this Bill. We accept what the Minister has to say about his intentions in regard to its passing. However, we would be much happier if the power to apply to the Commission to make a declaration were given to others, in the way that a similar power is given in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. However, while making that point we look forward to the Minister acting speedily and promptly next week.

Clause 4 also details the criteria by which the Commission will determine whether grounds exist for its making a declaration in respect of the Federation. Clause 4 (4) defines prescribed persons. I ask: Why is it limited to executive members of the Federation or members performing executive or representative-type work? The coalition would be much happier if this clause were widened to mirror the grounds one finds in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, and I refer specifically to section 143 (1) (h). Running through the grounds for an order directing the cancellation of the registration of an organisation, it states:

the conduct of the organisation (either in respect of its continued breach or non-observance of an award or its continued failure to ensure that its members comply withy and observe an award or in any other respect), or the conduct of a substantial number of the members of the organisation . . .

We would have been happier to have in this Bill a clause which said something like: `A substantial number of the members of the Federation have, whether before or after the commencement of this Act, engaged in industrial action that prevented or hindered the achievement of an object of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.' I would be grateful to hear the Minister's comments on that suggestion.

Clause 4 (3) deals with the need to prove that the Federation is engaged in certain conduct. I would be grateful if, in the Minister's summing up of this debate, he would state how this proof is to be obtained. Clause 4 (5) deals with the evidence that can be considered. I ask: Is the Minister satisfied that the Bill, as written, covers all the evidence that may be available? Clause 5 ofthe Bill deals with the orders by the Minister in relation to the Federation should a declaration be made by the Commission. It uses the word `may'-the Minister may do something and he may do something else. the word `may' is used throughout the Bill. We ask the Minister why he will not replace that word with the word `shall'. Given the record of the BLF, given the litany of strife and industrial disruption that the union has engaged in, given its record and given the Minister's recognition that the time has passed for one more chance, why will he not replace that word with the word `shall' and require that action be taken should the Commission make a declaration?

We are also concerned about the partial geographic, as I term it, deregistration of the BLF. We share the publicly stated view of the Master Builders Federation of Australia Inc. that the BLF should be federally deregistered nationwide. That would leave open the possibility for State branches of the union, if they are so deserving, to obtain State registration if they do not already have it.

In regard to clauses 9 and 10 of the Bill, which basically deal with the carving up of the BLF body, we make the point that the Minister would be well advised to consult and deal not just with employee representatives and organisations but also with the wider building industry, which would undoubtedly have some constructive suggestions to make on the carving up of the BLF body, as it were. In dealing with the specifics, I would like the Minister to answer this question. If all proceeds as he wishes it to proceed, how long will it take before the BLF is effectively deregistered? The Opposition has raised these questions in lieu of moving amendments because we have given our commitment to facilitating the speedy passage of this legislation through the House. I hope that the Minister will be able to answer the specific points that I have raised.

Having said that, I add that the fundamental point that the coalition wishes to make about this Bill, euphemistically titled the `Building Industry Bill', is that it deals only with the immediate problem of the BLF; it does not address issues within the industrial relations system which give rise to such problems, as are manifested in the actions of the BLF, and which allow unions such as the BLF to rampage through the system unchecked and without correction. Even if this Bill is passed quickly through both Houses and even if it quickly brings about the deregistration of the BLF, it will not make up for the millions of dollars that have been lost and for the hundreds of man-hours that have been lost on building sites around the country. It will not make up for nearly four years of time wasted since deregistration proceedings were first started against the BLF, and it will not guarantee that this sort of union activity will not happen again within the building industry.

It is not enough for the Minister and the Government simply to proceed to deregister the BLF. Even if this Bill effectively deregisters that union, nothing will have been done to prevent another union from pursuing the same very successful tactics of industrial brinksmanship. We could have another union, possibly headed by the same sorts of individuals as those who head the BLF today. We may be able to legislate the BLF out of existence, but what is to stop a BLF clone again in the building industry or in any other industry from acting in a similar way in the future? The short answer is: Nothing. This is the fatal flaw underpinning the thinking behind this Bill and in the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems.

Deregistration as a sanction against unlawful and unreasonable union action can achieve only so much. What the coalition is concentrating on, and we urge the Government to do likewise, is the contemplation of how to prevent the development ever again of such an industrial relations monster. We believe firmly and resolutely that the establishment of accountability between parties to industrial agreements-the minimum requirement of responsible behaviour before and under the law-is necessary for this aim to be achieved.

While, for obvious reasons, the Government may not be interested in the accountability question, given its union power base, we in the coalition are working on it, and in the coming months we look forward to announcing details relating to our plans for achieving that aim when we are next in government. Thank God that we are doing so, for right now the Hawke Government is possibly in the process of helping to create a new BLF. I refer to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. As my colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) and I pointed out yesterday in a debate on a matter of public importance, the Government is providing tacit support for the AMIEU's vicious campaign against the owner of and employees at the Mudginberri abattoir.

In principle there is no difference between the tactics being employed by the AMIEU at Mudginberri and the central tactic consistently used by the BLF. What is that tactic? It involves upping the ante for as long as it takes until employers are pushed to the brink in order to break their resolve. In the absence of accountability and of any legal agreement requiring minimum, mutual and responsible behaviour, what choice do employers have under the present system but to give in to union demands in order to stave off bankruptcy? Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act are relevant sections that this Government wishes to remove from the statute books.

The BLF, with clinical skill and ruthlessness throughout its history, targeted the balance books of construction and building companies around Australia, relying on the fact that, for economic reasons, under the present industrial relations system those companies could not afford to stand and fight. That is exactly the strategy of the AMIEU at Mudginberri. Jay Pendarvis is on the verge of bankruptcy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Good.

—We have had that confirmed now by a member of the Government. Jay Pendarvis is on the verge of bankruptcy and only the awarding of full damages in compensation for the havoc that the AMIEU has wreaked on his business will save him from financial ruin. If the Hawke Government is so shortsighted that it cannnot see the parallel, there is no hope for us. Can it not see that the actions of the BLF are a symptom of a much deeper underlying malaise in Australia's industrial relations system? The process of reform and of achieving truly fundamental improvements in the industrial relations system is being slowed down immeasur- ably by this Government's refusal to recognise and act upon this fact. It has taken a small private employer in the back-blocks of the Northern Territory to say: `Enough is enough. On behalf of my company and my employees, I am going to stand and fight'. His struggle for justice, not just for him but also for his employees, who have most to lose if the union wins, is made that much harder by this Government's refusal to give even moral support to those who have right on their side in this dispute and who are acting lawfully and in compliance with Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission rulings. Whether we are dealing with the BLF or the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, deregistration is not the answer, and the Hancock Committee got it wrong. The restor- ation of accountability under the law is the answer, and we intend, when next in government, to restore that accountability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before addressing myself specifically to the Building Industry Bill before the House, let me say that this Government does not need any advice on the conduct of industrial relations from those honourable members on the other side of this House, who by their ineptitude brought about a situation of anarchy in industrial relations at the beginning of the 1980s and, if they were to have the opportunity, which they will not have, would reproduce exactly the same situation by the nonsense that they are talking about in industrial relations. They would scrap entirely the system of centralised wage fixation. They talk about Mudginberri-they would have a situation where the strength of trade unions and employers would be pitted consistently against one another around this country. That is the policy which brought chaos in 1981 and 1982. They have learnt nothing. They would inflict it upon Australia again. Neither this country nor this Government wants any advice from this collection of incompetents in the area of industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill now before the House is a unique and, I believe, especially important piece of legislation. It stems directly from the Government's conviction that no government can tolerate or in any way acquiesce in the forms of unionism perpetrated by unions such as the Builders Labourers Federation. As I said when foreshadowing this legislation last week, the BLF's complete disdain for the law, and frequent resort to practices of thuggery and physical coercion have no place in our society. The BLF has forfeited any claim it otherwise might have had, either on the community at large or on the trade union movement.

The Government believes that over many years the BLF has demonstrated nothing but contempt for the system and values of Australian society. There should now be no basis upon which it can hope to elicit any measure of protection or support from our society. I know of no sense in which the trade union movement can regard the industrial thuggery practised by the BLF with anything but profound disquiet. The BLF consistently now has put itself out of line with the mainstream of what legitimate trade unionism is about. It is for this reason that the Government expects that the legislation now proposed to this House will get, and indeed already has, the necessary level of support from the trade union movement.

The Government, for its part, is determined to create a new industrial environment in the building industry; an environment of greater peace and substantially improved industrial relations, with benefits for both workers and employers, and for the economy as a whole. The Government has not begun lightly this legislative initiative against the BLF. To propose, as we now do, measures which could result in the cancellation of the registration of the Builders Labourers Federation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, or the effective equivalent of such deregistration in parts of Australia, is a major step, not least for a Labor Government. But there comes a point at which government has to say `Enough', and we have done that. We and others involved with the industry have shown indeed considerable patience in the face of repeated failure by the BLF to adhere to industrial agreements.

The actions of the BLF have posed a continuous threat to the stability of the building industry, the employment of other building workers and the prices and incomes accord. Many aspects of the BLF approach are thoroughly reprehensible by the standards of contemporary society. It uses the strike weapon and other industrial tactics, such as selective bans and limitations, with the objective of `the most harm to the boss, the least harm to themselves'. That was a quote from Steve Black, New South Wales Secretary of the BLF, in 1979. Such action frequently is accompanied by the use of violence, damage to property, interruption of concrete pours and intimidation of fellow workers as well as employers to achieve BLF objectives. Stand-over methods and guerrilla tactics are common weapons of the BLF. It has used its central position in the industry with devastating effect through measures such as bans on strategic parts of jobs and equipment, one day and one week bans on concrete pours, breakage of concrete pours, bans on truck deliveries and unloading, and safety and overtime bans. Its action is not confined to direct industrial forays. Members of the BLF also have occupied buildings of insurance companies and private organisations and, at least on one occasion, the premises of another union. The sight of BLF members engaging in violent demonstrations and physical assault against fellow unionists has become commonplace.

The BLF's behaviour and tactics were addressed in detail in the 1982 Winnecke report of the Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation. I quote from that report in these terms:

These tactics find no support or condonation in any industrial legislation in this country. The conduct not only exceeds the bounds of industrial propriety but, in many instances, plainly transgresses the Criminal Law. In many, if not most, instances, demands are made accompanied by threats. Those threats are frequently implemented and the implementation has gone far beyond financial loss and has involved damage to property and person . . . The result has been to place the BLF in a unique position-a position of being above the law.

The Federation also has shown contempt for the processes of conciliation and arbitration. It has refused continually to abide by orders of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and consistently, despite many undertakings, has pursued claims outside the guidelines of the Commission. The disdain in informing the BLF approach to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission comes through clearly in remarks by BLF office-holders. I give just a few examples: `We are not prepared to accept any decision from the Commission on a demarcation between builders labourers and the AWU'-Mr Dalton in 1979; `Undertakings cannot be for ever and ever. We are not going to be held to an agreement for ever and ever'-Mr Gallagher in 1979; `The Federation will not abide by any decision or order that would follow. The Federation would pursue its claims outside the Commission in the field'-Mr Capogreco in 1980. Such expressions of attitudes by BLF officials unfortunately have not been idle threats. They have informed those very actions of the BLF which now make necessary the action proposed by the Government.

Activities of the BLF that the Government regards as far beyond the bounds of what is acceptable include the following: Breaking the fundamental undertaking to the Industrial Registrar regarding future conduct, which was a condition for reregistration in 1976. Between 1976 and 1982, the BLF repeatedly pursued claims outside the system, used violence and intimidation in pursuit of its claims, took industrial action over non-industrial issues, disregarded the moratorium on industrial action agreed in 1983 in return for negotiation towards a formal agreement which would replace deregistration proceedings commenced under the former Government. Despite the moratorium, the BLF mounted what the Chairman of the National Building and Construction Conference, Mr Vosti, described as `the intolerable action over the Fletcher Watts dispute'. The BLF breached its no further claims undertaking to the Commission in October 1983 as required to achieve the national wage increase. These breaches were flagrant. Two months after giving the undertaking the BLF engaged in a campaign for an extra $9 per week in 1984. It made demands for a 36-hour week at shopping centre sites, made claims for the 1984 2.6 per cent national wage increase prior to its ratification by the Commission and took industrial action in support of site allowance claims. So the list goes on.

In December 1983 the BLF gave undertakings to the Government, which were accepted by the Government as grounds for its withdrawal from the deregistration case, but by February 1984 the BLF had launched a national campaign for an extra $9 per week, rather than partaking in negotiations directed towards a superannuation scheme. In April 1984 the BLF engaged in a disruptive dispute over a demarcation issue at the Alcan Australia Ltd smelter site at Kurri Kurri. During this dispute the BLF picketed the site and damaged the cars of employees. The offices of the company's solicitors also were invaded. This period also witnessed the Melbourne Cricket Ground light towers demarcation dispute, during which the site was fenced off and police were required to counter the BLF picket outside the site. BLF members were arrested on a number of charges, including trespass and resisting arrest. Supporting bans were also placed on other Victorian Government projects. On two occasions the BLF attempted to invade the offices of the rival union, the Australian Workers Union. No government can ignore anarchy of this kind. While we have been preparing for the eventuality of such legislation, the New South Wales Government has now deregistered the BLF and the Cain Government in Victoria has taken legislative action which would amount to effective deregistration of the BLF from the Victorian industrial relations system. To be fully effective, these measures by Victoria and New South Wales need to be able to be complemented by Federal Government action, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria, where the federally registered BLF has been a source of major disruption.

In its determination to bring the BLF to account, the Government has remained mindful of community concern that the deregistration powers that it now proposes should not be used indiscriminately or capriciously. We see no basis, by way of either precedent or practice, for the present legislation being applied in a wider, totally crude exercise in union bashing. The circumstances posed by the behaviour of the BLF are genuinely unique. These concerns have been carefully weighed in the Bill that was introduced into the Parliament yesterday, having regard to the overwhelming need to take action against key elements of the BLF and the need to minimise the potential for abuse. Accordingly, a fundamental element of the Bill is the role of a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in determining whether the BLF has engaged in conduct which has prevented or seriously hindered arbitral processes. Such a determination by the Arbitration Commission would be a prerequisite of any Government decision to deregister the BLF. We are conscious of the overwhelming need to ensure that justice is done in this matter and also that justice is seen to be done.

The basis for the Government's introducing this special legislation is that it believes the BLF's conduct amounts to a repudiation of the Federal system for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes and of its responsibilities as a federally registered organisation of employees, as well as being utterly disruptive of industrial peace. As the Minister said yesterday:

In the Government's view, the action which is contemplated in this legislation is so serious that it is essential that there be impartial consideration by an independent tribunal of the Federation's conduct. This will occur against specific criteria which are appropriate tests of whether the Federation has behaved responsibly as an organisation registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and in a way which is consistent with the objectives of our industrial relations system.

The Bill before the House also provides for the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to be able to decide upon apporpriate action following a finding of misconduct by the union. Honourable members will also appreciate that this Bill provides for a range of Government actions which could be taken against the BLF, extending from national deregistration of the BLF under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to selective action against the BLF in relation to the terminating or suspending of rights, privileges or capacities of the BLF under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Honourable members will appreciate that deregistration, particularly in current circumstances, would be a potent action against the BLF. Any award applying to the BLF would cease to have any effect in relation to the Federation and its members. The BLF would not be capable of being a party to a proceeding before the Commission or to an award made by the Commission and the Commission would not have any powers under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in relation to an industrial dispute insofar as that dispute involved members of the Federation. It would also be open to the Minister to make orders which would have the effect of granting to other registered organisations coverage of work in an industry or in a location in respect of which the BLF is or has been registered.

The Government will require the assistance of employers, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and other building unions to ensure the success of its proposals. There will be a particularly heavy onus on employers in the industry to take a firm stand. Too often in the past employers have been prepared to do separate deals with the BLF against the best interests of the industry as a whole. Further, employers have adopted industrial relations practices which have facilitated the success of the BLF tactics. Employers can help not only by refusing to abide the behaviour of the BLF but, even more importantly, by doing nothing to give solace or succour to its position. The Government would also expect employers to honour their obligations in relation to an appropriate standard of industrial behaviour, including adherence to procedures of the building industry agreement, refusing to pay for lost time during strikes and other industrial action, ensuring that safe working conditions are applied and seeing that employees are enrolled in building industry superannuation. What builders need to understand is that in the longer term their interests and the interests of the community depend upon having a rational system of industrial relations within which there is, as there appropriately should be within a democracy, the opportunity for legitimate trade unions to put points of view and for there to be rational interchanges between employers and organised workers. This relationship obviously hinges on the parties to that relationship being able to rely on there being civilised behaviour within the industrial environment. Certainly, the community has had enough of the behaviour of the BLF and of industrial relations in the building industry as a whole. The community expects employers and all unions involved to respond to the clear community position on this. It is in this spirit that the Government is giving consideration to non-legislative measures designed to ensure that contractors on government projects adhere to government industrial relations practices. This Government believes firmly in leadership by example in this matter and will be approaching State and local governments to adopt similar measures.
It is well known that I would not always embrace what is in the editorials of the Australian newspaper--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?
—Because they are sometimes wrong. However, on this occasion they are pre-eminently right. On 19 July this year an editorial in the Australian said:

SPEECH.PARA: The BLF has shown absolute disregard for both the industrial and civil laws of Australia for years. It has ignored the orders of industrial courts, invaded private offices and destroyed property, employed what can only be described as standover tactics in negotiations with building companies and cost the country untold millions of dollars through questionable industrial action.

We intend putting an end to this situation. I suppose it does not need to be emphasised, but I make the point that with the background that I have in the trade union movement it gives me no pleasure to have arrived at this situation. But it is a necessary position that we have reached now and we intend to take the action which is necessary in the interests of this society. We do so in the name of the country as a whole and we look to this House for full and unqualified support for the action now proposed. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) concluded by asking for full support in this House for the Building Industry Bill and I indicate to him that the Opposition supports this measure introduced by the Government. I go to some of the words used by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in introducing the Bill. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government believes that the BLF has, on numerous occasions, breached undertakings to the Federal Court of Australia, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Industrial Registrar, the Commonwealth Government, building industry employers and even the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is now patently clear that the BLF leadership is utterly untrust-worthy and that it regards undertakings and agreements as mere strategems to achieve a momentary advantage which can then be disregarded at will.

Furthermore, its unprincipled, indeed outrageous, mode of operation has created havoc in the building industry, thereby causing extraordinary delays in building programs and crippling increases in costs. Its use of tactics such as breaking concrete pours, reckless application of work bans, resort to walk-offs or `homers' and claims for payment for time on strike have made industrial relations in the industry a nightmare.

Its resort to industrial blackmail, thuggery, violence and intimidation has added a further ugly dimension to its activities. Such behaviour cannot be tolerated and has resulted in the virtual alienation of the union from the rest of the trade union movement in some parts of the nation.
He also went on to say that the Federation has shown disdain for the processes of conciliation and arbitration and, interestingly enough, in other remarks he went on-I stress this-to say:
Mr Speaker, these activities of the BLF are not a recent phenomenon-Indeed, the Federation has been a major disruptive force in the industry throughout the past decade-and-a-half.

He traced its activities from 1974. He then referred to the deregistration of the BLF in 1976 and quoted Gallagher and the undertakings that Mr Gallagher made before the Commission in 1976 when the union was deregistered.
After quoting Mr Gallagher and this long record which the Minister referred to, with words such as: `These activities of the BLF are not a recent phenomenon', he went on to say:
The record shows that from this time--
that is 1976--
the union has had scant regard to these undertakings.
that is the undertakings of Mr Gallagher--
It has, on a multitude of occasions,--
his words, not mine--

engaged in the kind of conduct it repudiated before the Court, and its industrial record contains numerous examples of harmful demarcation disputes, broken concrete pours, violent conflicts with police and fellow unionists and disruptive campaigns over non-industrial issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The Minister said that and the thrust of those remarks is that this activity, this anarchy and this thuggery has gone on and on from the time that Gallagher gave undertakings to the Commission in 1976.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the record as the Minister described it-industrial anarchy, industrial thuggery for years and years. What did this Government do when it came into power in 1983 after these years or turmoil that were described by the Minister? It shrank from deregistration, it walked away from the proceedings before the Court, moving the Court to pass remarks that were recalled in the Canberra Times editorial of 25 July 1985 in the following words:

. . . it was a Full Bench of the Federal Court that chortled in judgmental disbelief at the flimsiness of the BLF undertakings that were the basis of Mr Willis's withdrawal from the deregistration proceedings.

It chortled in disbelief at the flimsiness of the undertakings by Gallagher, the man that the Minister says has been head of a union that for year after year has engaged in thuggery and abuse of the type I described. Let me recall the statement that was issued by this Minister in 1983 in the parsimonious weakness of this Government in dealing with industrial affairs. The statement issued in his name in 1983 said:
In the Government's view--
this is the man who has talked of the years of industrial anarchy--

a sound basis had been established for the industrial stability in the building industry; that the BLF had submitted a comprehensive undertaking to the court in relation to its future industrial activity; that it recognised its obligations as a registered organisation to operate within the Conciliation and Arbitration system; that it reaffirmed its undertaking to make no extra claims outside the national wage procedures; that it confirmed its commitment to abide by the terms of the Building Industry Agreement; that the Australian Council of Trade Unions had supported that commitment and had resolved to take all reasonable steps to ensure its observance by the union; and that--
the Minister went on to say in his own form of tranquility--
the recent industrial record of the industry has been greatly improved and the way is now open for a sustained period of industrial peace.

Shades of Chamberlain with his letter-peace in the union, withdrawal from the proceedings, leave the employers before the court but walk away. He was a sucker and it is symptomatic of the weakness and connivance of this Government in industrial affairs. Not only could this union have been deregistered in 1983, had it gone on with its action, but let me give honourable members a little more background information. They will remember that the Minister said in his statement that from the time Gallagher made his undertakings in 1976, 1977, 1979, 1980, 1981, 1982 or 1983-you name it-the union had created industrial turmoil. My political opponent came in here a short time ago and ranted and raved about the performance of the BLF. He said it had to be deregistered, that this action was outrageous and that we could not tolerate what was happening. I remind honourable members that in 1981 I determined that the BLF ought to be deregistered. Do honourable members know who was spokesman for the Labor movement as well as the Australian Labor Party? It was the man who was in here sounding off today. Do they know what he said?
Opposition members-No!

TALK.START.PARA: —He said I was wrong. He said we ought to sit down and have a chat with the BLF, that deregistration did not mean a thing.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, he even went so far as to say, as was reported in the Sun-Pictorial newspaper on 18 February 1981, that it was straight out confrontationist tactics. Shades of today I think. He must be a seer. He went on to say:
. . . it was `designed to divert attention from the Government's own inadequacies.'

Then he went on numerous television programs with me and said that we have to talk with Norm. He said: `That is the way to settle industrial disputes. We will have a chat.' He said: `Deregistration is useless'. I heard him say today: `We are taking a firm stance and deregistration indicates that'. Let me tell honourable members what he said about deregistration on the Nationwide program when he was in debate with me on 18 February 1981. He said:

Well, if Andrew is saying that success is to be measured whether he gets the application granted then he may well succeed in getting the union deregistered but I don't think that that's the measure of success.
Then he went on to say:
`Look, let's sit down and talk about this'.
He suggested we put everything on the table and have a chat. On this question of deregistration he said:

I'm sure that he's got a very good chance of winning his case for securing the deregistration of the building union and he seems to think that that is success. What I'm saying is that that's not success.
He later on said:
The measure of your success is not whether you succeed in getting them deregistered.

The importance of those remarks today is that we have had a history of industrial anarchy and the man who has fought against the deregistration of this union is none other than the Prime Minister himself. He has wheeled, dealed and connived year in and year out. The so-called tomato left in Victoria are the ones who got him up as president of the ACTU in the first place. He comes in here today with his Government in disarray and says: `This is a measure of success. We are going to deregister the BLF.'

In his own words deregistration is not a success. So the real test has to be: What is going to happen in the post-deregistration days? What is the Government going to do? Have a look at what the Government is going to do in the terms of the Bill. Honourable members will not find that. All they will find is that the Minister may do this or the Minister may do that. Is there a commitment in the Minister's speech to allow the poaching-let us put it bluntly-of members of the Federated Ironworkers Association, the Australian Workers Union or the members of the BLF? If one is fair dinkum about destroying a union one does not just knock out a couple of office bearers; one obliterates that union and allows the Federated Ironworkers Association or the Australian Workers Union to take over its members. Do not fiddle about on this. Those opposite have already told me, year in and year out, that deregistration does not mean a thing and that it is what is done after the deregistration that counts. Despite all these words today about the BLF, is the Minister going to ensure that employers on sites are protected? Is he going to assist the unions who seek to take over the membership of those areas that may, give or take a little, be destroyed?

May I inject a broader political view, because I have to look at what this Party as a whole says. The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) correctly said that this legislation came into the Parliament after being passed by the barest of Caucus margins. The tomato Left is at it again down in Victoria; they have called a special conference this coming weekend. We heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in here. It is interesting that there is no broadcast today. He gave an undertaking that this legislation would be brought in, it will be recalled, on the first day of Parliament. Hang on a flash; the first day of Parliament, they told him afterwards, is on air. They said: `The fellows in Victoria will hear what you say. Do it the day after the Budget when it is not on air. With all the news of the Budget they may not know'. Will the Prime Minister give a commitment to this House to fight resolutely this case at the special conference of his own Party in his own State next weekend? Will he be down there defending Cain, defending the cause of the Federal Government, in the deregistration? Will he tell them what he has told us in quiet tones today about what he thinks of Norm Gallagher? I tell the House now that he will not be there and he will not be saying what he said in the Parliment today.

I come back at the reality of this measure. In the words of this fulminating Prime Minister himself, deregulation is not the test and deregistration is not a success. So we must ask: What lies down the post-deregistration scene? Is the Government fair dinkum or not? I say to the House now: The Government is going to fiddle with a few people in the labour movement and nothing more, but the BLF will continue to exist. It will not support the poaching of its members. The Government will not back up the employers. It has been revealed for nothing but a sham and a facade, not in my words but in the words of its Leader.
Sitting suspended from 12.43 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised by the Principal Parliamentary Reporter that delivery of yesterday's daily Hansard by the Government Printer has been delayed by difficulties experienced in the Government Printing Office overnight in adapting to the new typesetting equipment installed during the winter recess. The Government Printer expects the House of Representatives Hansard to be available late this afternoon.

—I address my question to the Treasurer. I refer the honourable gentleman to the opening sentence of his mini-Budget Speech in May, where he said that the expenditure reduction measures were `a progress report' and `a first and major instalment'. Is it not correct that, instead, the Budget Papers delivered last night show that the Government's net cut to the Forward Estimates this year was 40 per cent less than the May figure-that is, $764m-and that the 1986-87 effect of the so-called cuts is actually a net increase in spending of $169m against a claimed saving of $1,250m in the mini-Budget?

—I do not understand the point of the question. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has missed it again. The fact is that outlays growth is 1.3 per cent. That would not be the case had the $1,250m of cuts not been made. I just remind the honourable member that abstracting for public debt interest, which accounts for one percentage point of the 1.3 per cent, and abstracting for ongoing defence commitments, which account for 0.3 per cent-that is, public debt interest and defence accounting for all of the growth in outlays-the fact is that there has been restraint across the board amounting to a zero real increase in all other outlays. The fact is that there was spending before the May exercise and there was spending after it. Some of it is technically new policy, such as the temporary assistance by which the Commonwealth accommodated the States of South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland at the Australian Loan Council, which otherwise would not be counted as new policy. But the point is just immaterial. The fact is that the outlays growth figure is there. It is no good selecting a set of numbers and saying: `You have made a certain deduction against that set of numbers'. Such sets of numbers are irrelevant now. What is relevant is the outlays. The Forward Estimates are irrelevant. They become irrelevant as the economy changes. But we indicated that we would save $1,259m off the Forward Estimates, and we did; and without that we would not have a 1.3 per cent real growth in outlays.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. What are the reactions of the major industry groups to the housing and construction measures contained in last night's Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Banks for his question. I am very pleased to say that there has been an extraordinarily good reaction from the housing industry groups. For instance, the Housing Industry Association had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The significant reduction in the Budget deficit is good news for home seekers. The greatly reduced deficit in the lower level of public sector borrowings will help to moderate pressures on interest rates.

The Association went on to praise the first home owners scheme and said that it had been an outstanding success and that it could play a key part in underpinning new housing activities. Those remarks are, of course, correct, because the very low deficit as announced by the Treasurer last night, particularly the low domestic deficit of $1.4 billion, will have the consequential effect of lowering presssure on the public sector borrowing requirement, and that, of course, is good news with regard to general interest rates, and that means it is good news for housing interest rates also.

I will mention some more good news. Just before I came into the House I was informed that the rate of growth for savings bank deposits had risen somewhat during June, so that we are running now at an 8.5 per cent growth factor for savings bank deposits. It is in this responsible budgetary atmosphere that I am very pleased to be able to say that the mood of the housing and construction industry is buoyant indeed. That is due to the high funding of $654m under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and another possible $492m available under the nominated loan funds arrangements. One can add to that the sum of $290-odd million which is available for the first home owners scheme in this Budget.

By the end of June 1986, we would expect to have over 226,000 families and single people who have benefited from the first home owners scheme. Also I am able to report that we did achieve, as a result of past policies, the 151,000 housing starts for 1984-85 that I predicted in the last session. Last week I was able to say that we achieved that figure.

I conclude on the other side of the portfolio, in regard to construction. In such a responsible budgetary atmosphere, it was very pleasing to see that we were able to lift by 18 per cent the amount to be spent during this financial year on civil and defence works. If we count the funds which will go to projects which will be administered under the National Capital Development Commission and the money that will be spent on the New Parliament House, we see that we will be spending $1,150m on Commonwealth construction projects this financial year. It is with no doubt that I am able to say that employment in the housing industry is now running at 485,000. This means that it has gone up by 100,000 since August 1983. Comparing this figure with the abysmal figure of about 380,000 who were employed in housing and construction when we took office in March 1983, the effect that the hike in housing and construction activity has had upon the employment situation is very apparent indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer the honourable gentleman to the bullish comments just made by his colleague, the Minister for Housing and Construction, about the impact of the Budget on interest rates. In the light of those comments and the Treasurer's own comments about the reduced public sector borrowing requirement, does he stand by his and the Prime Minister's promises, made during the election campaign last year and repeated subsequently, that interest rates would fall in 1985? If so, when will they fall, by how much and from what level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition sometimes finds it difficult to understand what the Government says. I have said here on a couple of occasions that the depreciation of the dollar completely changed the outlook for the real economy and the financial markets this year. I make the point again that rates in this country are fixed in the market; they are not fixed by the Government. The Deputy wants to have his cake and eat it as well. He says that monetary policy is too loose, and he made this statement the other day:

ANSWER.PARA: The money supply figures show an alarming collapse of monetary discipline by the Hawke Government. This loose monetary policy further adds to inflationary pressures within the Australian economy.

So he is urging the Government to tighten monetary policy and lift interest rates further. He is really asking the Government to have a credit squeeze so that the economy totally seizes up as a result of high interest rates. When everybody has had enough pain he might then have satisfied some of those basically raw ideological and mindless philosophical instincts held by those on the other side of the House. The fact is that we have run the appropriate monetary policy. Conditions have been kept firm. The indicator of balance in the market is interest rates but market perceptions, conditions and the real economy changed following the depreciation. I make no prediction whatsoever about the outlook, but the dramatic decline in the bond-selling program, from $7,600m last year to $5,000m this year, will be a bull point on markets, as will the outcome in respect of wages and inflation. All those important elements, including the Budget deficit, will be taken in the mix by those people in the financial markets who tender for bonds and essentially fix rates of interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform the House of the prospects for continuing reductions in unemployment, especially among young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the honourable member that the prospects for reducing unemployment across the work force as a whole, and particularly for young people, are better now than they have been for a long time. This Government has already achieved a lot in reducing the level of unemployment. As honourable members will be aware, since we have been in office we have created 410,000 additional jobs, which is one of the highest rates of job growth in the Western industrial world. That growth has encompassed a reduction in unemployment of 130,000, or 2 percentage points, since September of 1983. Unemployment is now below 600,000 and, at 8.2 per cent, it is at its lowest level for almost three years.

ANSWER.PARA: The prospects are very encouraging. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has forecast for Australia continuing strong growth and a rate of unemployment down to between 7 1/2 and 8 per cent in 1986. Of course, the Budget forecasts support that. The Budget forecasts strong employment growth in the course of 1985-86, with employment increasing by 2 3/4 per cent. That will mean 180,000 additional jobs, and will give us over 560,000 additional jobs by the end of this financial year since April of 1983. We will certainly have achieved well over our target of creating 500,000 jobs three years after April of 1983. The Budget prediction is that, depending on what happens to the work force participation rate, the unemployment level could be down to 7 1/2 per cent by the end of this financial year.

Young people, to whom the honourable member particularly asked me to address my remarks, have already shared in the job growth which has occurred in this country. There was a long term decline in the employment of young people but we have reversed that trend. In the last two years the employment of teenagers has increased by 32,000, or 5 1/2 per cent. The unemployment rate amongst teenagers looking for full time jobs, although still 22.8 per cent, is 5 percentage points less than it was at its peak in July 1983. I am pleased to inform the House that in the last year there has been a considerable increase in the apprenticeship opportunities for young people. Preliminary statistics show that over 48,700 new apprentices were taken on last financial year, which is an increase of 21 per cent over the previous year and 43 per cent over the low of 1982-83. Young people will continue to share in job growth which will occur because of the overall growth in the economy and they will also benefit from the initiatives announced in the Budget, particularly in relation to traineeships. We will spend $15.7m on traineeships this year and much more in future years. We will have 10,000 traineeships this year with 75,000 traineeships by 1989. My Department estimates that the traineeship initiative alone, without taking into account the increases in employment otherwise occurring, will reduce the unemployment rate for 16 and 17-year-olds by about 50 per cent when it comes fully on stream by 1988-89. The prospects for youth employment are better now than they have been for a long time. The combination of strong economic growth and particular vocational programs for young people is giving them the greatest prospects for employment that they have had for many years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the statement of the Prime Minister on 17 February, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Look the position is very simple and straightforward. We've got in this country a position where our marginal tax rates are too high and they are biting in too early, they are disincentives and people rightly feel that they've got too high a burden of direct personal tax. So for obvious reasons of personal hardships, incentives, economic efficiency we've got to bring those rates down and bring them down substantially . . .

Will the Treasurer confirm that another 500,000 Australians will move from the 30 per cent tax bracket into the 46 per cent marginal rate as a result of this Budget? Will he also confirm, notwithstanding the Prime Minister's statement, that approximately 250,000 taxpayers will move into the 60 per cent marginal rate as a result of his Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition should understand that this Budget carries a lot of weight of the 1984-85 tax cut. The 1984-85 tax cut totalled $2.1 billion in a full year and $1.3 billion in 1984-85. So $800m of the tax cut is being borne by this Budget. The sheer size of that tax cut is important in terms of the effect upon marginal rates last year. The more general point that we in this country should ponder is who got us into the mess of high marginal rates. Who made a swill of the tax system? It was the coalition parties. Who satisfied every pressure by handing out concessions which are now being abused for tax minimisation purposes? It was the coalition Government. That is why it made tax optional. It allowed people to cheat right through the 1970s, only to describe the McCabe-Lafranchi report as a political stunt. It was dragged screaming by Costigan to the barrier and was finally driven to tidy up the criminal schemes which it allowed to prosper during its term. This Government has done something about rates of taxation by giving a tax cut that the nation can afford. The last tax cut, given in desperation by the coalition in the 1982-83 Budget, of over $2.2 billion was one that it knew it could not afford to give in a debilitated, recessed economy and it blew out the Budget deficit the following year to $9.6 billion in prospect. In other words, the low heels opposite were worried about their hides. We remember what happened when Malcolm Fraser was trying to have a 1982 election. There was a big debate about whether he would or would not. He put in a $2.5 billion tax cut but he knew well that he could not afford it. The former Treasurer also knew well that they could not afford it. What they said was: `We will just stick that on the public debt'.

ANSWER.PARA: When this Government came to office what did we find? On the first day the Prime Minister and I met the Secretary to the Treasury we found a $9.6 billion deficit. That was our fiscal inheritance from the previous Government's last tax cut. That is what honourable members opposite are about. They are cheats, cheats, cheats and they have all always been cheats, cheats, cheats! The only genuine tax reform that this country will get will be from this Government. This Government will make the tax system fairer for all decent Australians and we will reduce marginal tax rates. So we do not need any geeing along by the Leader of the Opposition who was playing dominoes with Barry Simon in room U67 while this debate was going on and who resigned in a fit of pique, in a fit of principle. Having left wages in chaos and having ruined the country with a wage explosion he retired to the upper floors of the-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to section 37 of the Australian Constitution and ask whether you have received a letter from the honourable member for Blaxland resigning either his seat or from the office of Treasurer because he failed at the tax summit.
—Order! I have on previous occasions warned honourable members about raising frivolous points of order. If the honour- able member for Mitchell offends again I will take action. I call the Treasurer.

—The honourable member for Mitchell does that regularly. This is one of the people of business. I think he used to own a car radio installation firm. He got up from under the dashboard, put on a pin-striped suit like an overcoat and walked into the establishment. He used to get around this place in a pin-striped suit. What great people of business! I could not trust him with a jam jar full of 5c bits.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer will resume his seat until the House comes to order. I remind honourable members that I show considerable tolerance during Question Time because I believe that honourable members should have the opportunity to ask questions. If I take action, that opportunity is greatly diminished. I ask honourable members to observe reasonable standards in their conduct. I call the Treasurer.

—I will round up the answer by saying that this Government is the only government that has taken taxation seriously in this country. This Government is the only government that has tried to make the tax system fairer and to clean the cheats out of the system. It has tried to take away the minimisation devices to make the tax system fairer. The coalition parties continue to frustrate our legislation in the Senate and they continue to protect tax avoiders and evaders. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition talks about a jack-boot approach to fringe benefits as though this walking around the tax system is in the slightest way defensible. It is just a ludicrous position for him to adopt. The same sleazy attitude that members of the Opposition have always had to taxation is just part and parcel of the kind of question which the Leader of the Opposition asked.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs. Is it a fact that, under the current youth allowance regime inherited from the Opposition, the Commonwealth Government provides greater financial assistance to 16 and 17-year-olds who elect to receive unemployment benefit than to those who decide to complete their secondary education? Does the youth training package announced in last night's Budget provide for the secondary student allowance to be doubled by 1988? Can the Minister assure the House that the Government's increased assistance to young Australians will go to those who are most in need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the short answer to that question is yes.
—Are you going to do the bottom of the harbour testing on Kim's subs?
—At what age did you leave school, Wilson?
—I left school at 17. I was as smart as you.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting. The Minister will answer the question.

—Under our arrangements maybe even the honourable member for O'Connor could have had a better education. It has been recognised over the recent past and, most particularly, with the report of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development examiners into youth policy in Australia that there exists for some young people-I am not suggesting for all-an incentive to leave school early because of the higher level of assistance that can be provided under the unemployment benefit than is available for those who decide to remain in the education system. This is a most difficult choice particularly for those who are from less privileged families. We know that young people from less privileged families tend to leave school earliest and that the earlier they leave school the worse are their opportunities of obtaining and retaining a job. So the Government has set in place a plan which, by the beginning of 1988, will ensure that there will be no financial incentive for young people to leave earlier than the end of secondary school. Indeed, there will be no financial incentive for them not to participate further in the tertiary level of education.

ANSWER.PARA: Financial support is not the only reason and may not even be the major reason why people decide to continue in education but it is certainly an important factor for a large group of young people who have not been participating in the education system and, as a result, have inferior opportunities for employment in the future. It will be noted that the major increase for 1986 will be in the secondary allowance because we think we have to start at that level to try to ensure that more young people are remaining in the secondary school system and then going on to the tertiary education system. We will see the already impressive improvements in education participation improve even further. I think that not only will that be an advantage to those young people who remain in the education system but also it will be of crucial importance to Australia as a whole in terms of increasing its capacity to produce and compete with the rest of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In view of the anomaly between the rhetoric of his Budget Speech and the arithmetic on the question of wage discounting, the continued prevarication which is the general attitude of the Government towards future wage claims in that respect and a very firm statement by the Prime Minister in Perth on 12 April last at his decision-makers' luncheon that depreciation will provide an opportunity to achieve substantially higher incomes and employment in the longer term only if the competitive advantage is maintained, how can the Treasurer justify promising a catch-up for any loss due to wage discounting?

—We are not promising catch-ups. We are talking about the maintenance of living standards over time. People on the other side of the chamber do not seem to understand that this is possible in a growth economy. We made it quite clear that there is no problem between the fact and the rhetoric that the Prime Minister used on that occasion. It is true that Australia's external position will be improved if our competitiveness is maintained. Our competitiveness can be maintained only if our inflation rate and our cost structure are comparable with those of the people with whom we trade. In this case it means that depreciation can bestow enormous benefits upon Australia if the initial price effects of that depreciation are quarantined and not passed on into wages and ongoing inflation. That was the point of the Government's policy announcement last night and we will be following that through in the appropriate forums.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CARE OF THE INFIRM AND HANDICAPPED

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Government concerned to encourage the care of the infirm and handicapped outside institutions? Can the Minister tell the House whether proposals in the Budget will assist in developing this type of care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government believes that the care of many severely handicapped or aged and infirm is best done in the home. We believe that we need to move away from the philosophy that previous governments employed, which encouraged institutionalisation of the aged and handicapped, and to create the circumstances where people, if possible, can live within their own homes. Of course, that is a very easy goal for a government to announce and to suggest it is pursuing, but this Government recognises that if it is to achieve this aim it needs to take very concrete steps.

ANSWER.PARA: Two steps have been taken in this year's Budget that will assist people in this situation. Firstly, in my own portfolio we have created a new carer's pension. A carer's pension will be paid to people caring for a spouse or a close relative who requires constant care and attention. It will be an important benefit for people caring for an aged parent or a handicapped child in the home. It replaces the existing spouse carer's pension paid only to husbands caring for their wives. Secondly, the Budget also provides arrangements for people being paid the handicapped child's allowance. This will allow people to continue to be paid the allowance for up to 28 days while the child is temporarily absent from the home in respite care. During the last year a number of honourable members on both sides of the House drew my attention to the very severe problems people face in caring for handicapped children and the desperate need of these people to have their child looked after for a period within institutions. This measure, which fundamentally allows for the child to be cared for within the home but does provide for payment during respite care within an institution for a short period, will be of tremendous benefit to many families supporting handicapped children within the home. I believe that those two measures alone-not to speak of the home and community care programs and other programs for which my colleague the Minister for Community Services is responsible-demonstrate that the Government is concerned to develop concrete measures that will support the caring of people within their homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to the rapid increase in medical benefit payments under Medicare resulting from increases in over-servicing and overutilisation under bulk billing. How does the Minister explain the increase in the rate of growth of patient utilisation of medical services from 3.9 per cent three months ago in the May Forward Estimates to 5.4 per cent in last night's Budget?
