—I point out that the elements of the increase are set out in the Budget. Just under half the increase in medical benefits derives from increases in the level of scheduled fee payments to doctors. Secondly, just under 2 per cent derives from demographic change; that is, the increasing aging of the population, plus an increase in the population. Utilisation, including demographic change, as the honourable member points out, increases by approximately 5 per cent. The chief reason for a bigger increase in utilisation this year has been explained to the House on previous occasions, that is, that as a result of the settlement with the medical profession there is an expectation built into those figures that a greater number of people will opt for private treatment in public hospitals. Again, as a result of the change of classification in public hospitals there will be an automatic increase in the number of private patients in the public hospitals system. Those patients will be paid for out of the medical benefits, and that is the explanation of the change from the period in which the Forward Estimates were announced, when that agreement with the medical profession and its effects had not been worked out. As I say, I think we have given an accurate account of the increase.

—Has the Minister for Communications seen the reports in the Australian of 19 August and 21 August which detail allegations that MI5 controls who gets a job at the British Broadcasting Corporation? Can the Minister assure the House that neither the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation nor any of its allied security organisations are involved in such activities in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation?

—Recent reports in the media have indicated that some BBC staff-in particular, current affairs journalists and some program makers-have been vetted by Britain's internal intelligence service, MI5. In September 1984 a similar question concerning ASIO investigation of ABC staff was asked of the ABC's Managing Director, Mr Whitehead. He replied that only two ABC staff members had been referred to ASIO for security clearances. These clearances were a prerequisite for a training course on protective security conducted by the Attorney-General's Department. Staffing matters under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act come within the prerogative of the Managing Director, who may designate any staffing positions within the ABC as requiring a security assessment prior to an appointment. The ABC has advised me that no other security clearances of ABC staff by ASIO have been requested by ABC management.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask: Earlier this year, did the Prime Minister, along with his colleague the Minister for Primary Industry, receive assurances from the European Economic Community in respect of highly subsidised beef trade to the western Pacific? Is it a fact that that letter of assurance failed to cover all potential markets for Australia in the important western Pacific basin? Will the Prime Minister raise this matter during the visit of Commissioner Andriesson next month? Will he advise the House why comprehensive assurances were not sought originally to cover all our relevant markets in the western Pacific?

—The House will recall that on the occasion to which the honourable member refers I was accompanied not only by the Minister for Primary Industry but also by representatives of the friends of the National Party; that is, the National Farmers Federation. The National Farmers Federation, which seems to have the very firm view that it knows much more about the interests of the rural community than the honourable member comes within a bull's roar of knowing, expressed not only privately to me but publicly its satisfaction and appreciation of the job that I and the Minister for Primary Industry were able to do in Brussels on behalf of the meat industry. Once again I accept that the National Farmers Federation can speak more accurately for the meat industry and the rest of the rural industry than the honourable member will ever be able to. I accept its congratulations on the job we did. Having said that, when the representative of the European Commission comes out here next month the Minister and, if necessary, I will address the overall question to which the honourable member alludes.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications. Is it a fact that delivery of mail by Australia Post in Sydney has improved greatly in recent months?

—As honourable members on both sides of the House are aware, concerns have been expressed for some time regarding the delivery of mail, particularly in New South Wales. Based on world standards of mail delivery, very satisfactory levels have been reached in all Australian States except New South Wales. However, it is true, as indicated by the honourable member for Lowe, that, as a result of initiatives which have been put in place in Australia Post in New South Wales, there is an improvement in the New South Wales mail service. The problem which caused one dispute some months ago was identified and has been solved. As a result it is anticipated that improvement will continue. There is still a good way to go, because this problem has been around for many years. It is not something that honourable members opposite were able to do anything about. However, fortunately at this stage it looks as though what the honourable member for Lowe has indicated is correct; that is, that there is currently a good deal of improvement. It is hoped that it will continue.
—I address my question to the Minister for Primary Industry.
—The Minister for Primary Industry is not here. Is a Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry present?

—I will readdress my question to the Prime Minister. In view of the widespread apprehension that is flowing through the timber industry in Australia at the moment, will the Prime Minister indicate when his Government will make a decision regarding the renewal of export woodchip licences?
—No, I cannot.

—I ask the Treasurer: Will he inform the House of the reaction to the 1985-86 Budget by various groups in the community? Do those reactions confirm the views of the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia on the electoral consequences of a disciplined and responsible economic policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are waiting for Mr Valder to appear on the private Westpac No. 1 report again to give us his private view on the Budget. Some commendatory words were said of the Budget in the media and by certain groups today. The Age said:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Keating spoke last night in terms that were both confident and cautionary, striking absolutely the right note.
What about that? The Australian Financial Review said:
This Budget is a serious and largely non-ideological effort to put a responsible philosophy into effect.
The Sydney Morning Herald said:
Last night's Budget more than complies with the spirit of that `trilogy' promise.
Bob White, speaking on the `Carwash' report, said:
Yes, I think we have to be happy that the Government has fulfilled its trilogy of promises and I think . . . it is a commendable achievement without any increase in taxation.
A spokesman for the Australian Chamber of Commerce said:

The Federal Government has correctly identified a strong and vibrant private sector as critical to sustain economic growth. The spending restraint and reductions in the deficit are a positive contribution.
A spokesman for the Confederation of Australian Industry said:
The 1985-86 Federal Budget is a generally responsible attempt to sustain economic growth through an increasing reliance on a viable private sector.
CAI commends the Government for the substantial cut in the total Budget deficit and reducing the record high gross public sector borrowing requirements.
A spokesman for the Master Builders Federation of Australia said:
The package will have a positive effect on the private sector at the same time as it meets desirable social welfare objectives.
The Reverend Alan Nicholls of the Australian Council of Social Service said:
I think the welfare and community sector also welcomes this Budget and welcomes in particular the improvements targeted on the poorest people on every measure of the poverty line in Australia.
That is, I think, a reasonable round-up of the assessment this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware that, in a speech given at Oxford on 7 June 1985, the shadow socialist Treasurer, Mr Hattersley, stated that `the model of centrally controlled public utilities does not meet our needs' and that `the Party was never intended to be committed to old style nationalisation-the public monopoly run as a monolithic bureaucracy from London'? In view of this stark repudiation of government-owned enterprise by the Treasurer's socialist colleague, will he now revise his thinking and repudiate the remarks he made in answer to a Dorothy Dix question on 23 May 1985 in which he said that the type of action being referred to by Mr Hattersley would be lunatic and vandalism?
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I direct your attention to standing order 142. This is not a matter related to the Minister's portfolio.
—The matter is an economic matter. I call the Treasurer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me first take the opportunity to say that I am pleased that the Opposition has no more questions on the Budget. Secondly, let me confirm my remarks made in the House about public enterprise to which the honourable gentleman referred. I also make the point that, if what is intended by the honourable gentleman's question is to lend further weight to the charade that the only way one deals with recurrent outlays of the Commonwealth is to sell assets, I refer him only to Mr Valder's comments about fiddling at the edges in trying to deal with recurrent outlays. The problem of outlays growth, of cutting expenditure, is one to be dealt with over a long period. This Government had five months to put this Budget into place. It had five months of effort to cut recurrent outlays, but not by selling off assets.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know what the point of the honourable gentleman's question is. If he is asserting, for instance, that the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia has not played an important and almost unique role in this country in accepting savings from small savers and turning them into housing, creating one of the biggest housing institutions in the world, I do not know what he is referring to. If he is talking about the Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia, I say that the Commonwealth did not sink one dollar into that bank until this Government put $150m of capital into it after, for years, taking hundreds of million of dollars in profit into the consolidated accounts of the Commonwealth. So if the honourable member's argument is that that institution does not pay, he is wrong. If he is prepared on that basis to get into Qantas Airways Ltd and have private carriers fly only the trunk routes, leaving all of the other important areas of South East Asia and our near neighbourhood to some other ill-defined service, I think that would be a very foolish policy. Given the fact that for so long Qantas has provided a major public service in this country effectively and efficiently and ranks proudly beside any airline in the world in terms of service and price, I do not know what the honourable member means.

If the honourable member is talking about Trans Australia Airlines, which provides a valuable service in this country as a domestic airline, I do not see his point either. The point the honourable member is probably making about my counterpart in Britain is that the British Labour Party has rejected for a long time the notion of a centrally planned economy and the notion of having major areas of enterprise in the public sector. My Party, similarly, rejects that. However, that is not to say that we reject public enterprise per se. We are proud of the public enterprises we have. We have tried to make them better and more efficient. We have substantially restructured them and made them stronger.

If the whole point of this nonsense is to maintain that in some way the jokers opposite have some policy to deal with the recurrent costs of the Commonwealth, pulling down public sector outlays, and if those opposite think they are going to kid anybody out there that they have an answer to the Commonwealth's growth rates of outlays by selling off assets, they are quite mistaken. It is simply a matter of choice whether one keeps an asset or sells it and takes the funds into one's accounts. It does not affect the question of recurrent outlays. One has to take the political scalpel out, do the hard slog and work through the outlays, as this Government has done. That is the difference between the Government of honourable members opposite and this Government. Honourable members opposite, as members of the so-called party of managers, may think that they have the allegiance of business in this country; they do not. Business thinks that they are mugs and hill-billies; and it is right.

Honourable members opposite might still have the allegiance of a few middle managers still dragging their mortgages behind them but they do not have that of the owners, the entrepreneurs and the captains of business. They do not have the support of the small business people, who want a growth economy. Their loyalties are to the party which delivers economic growth, and that is the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has sought my indulgence to answer a question which the honourable member for Bradfield asked him yesterday, and to which he promised an answer. I give the Minister that indulgence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, during Question Time, the honourable member for Bradfield sought clarification of the use of penalty provisions provided under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act for non-compliance with specific camping regulations. The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act does detail arrangements whereby campers are required to camp in designated areas or take out general camping permits. Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service administrators and rangers in Kakadu and in other national parks around Australia have found that penalty provisions are best utilised as a preventive measure to stop loutish and general bad behaviour. The adoption of strict day-to-day checks on campers' permits would add enormously to the work load of rangers and would deflect their attention from wildlife duties.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Oh, come on!

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that, before honour-able members opposite have their epileptic fits, they wait to hear the rest of my answer, because they will be a little embarrassed. While the pickets at Mudginberri have not sought permission to camp, park rangers have been more than satisfied with their behaviour.
—Have they?

—I say to the honourable member that he should hang on and contain his excitement. There have not been complaints from other tourists or campers in the park. I also point out to the House that the workers at the abattoir site have not sought permission to camp within the confines of the park; however, as they also have not caused any concern to rangers and or to other visitors in the area, the use of penalty provisions has not been envisaged either for the pickets or for the workers at the abattoir. This Government believes that the best resolution of industrial disputation is through due recourse to the established conciliation and arbitration processes and not through seeking recourse to legislative measures that have been set in place to overcome problems associated with park administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During Question Time, in answer to a question from the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) quite falsely made the claim that those in the Opposition who support an aggressive policy of privatisation see it as a method of-

—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has received the indulgence of the Chair on the basis that he has been personally misrepresented. It is not the practice of the House to allow honourable members the privilege of that sort of explanation if it has been a matter of a group allegation. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition either must go immediately to where he has been personally misrepresented or resume his seat.

—I seek your guidance, Mr Speaker. Are you saying that a claim by the Treasurer about a group of people on this side of the House who support a policy of privatisation, in circumstances where I have been publicly identified with that attitude and that policy, does not in any way refer to me?

—That is not the question. The question is that the allegation was made against a group. It has been the practice in the House not to deal with such allegations against groups. There is no personal misrepresentation in the matter. What you are seeking to do is to open a general discussion. I think that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would realise that if he does that he will make absolutely impossible the situation for personal explanations. There are other avenues of debate.
—I am indebted to you and, out of deference to you, I will not pursue the matter.

—Mr Speaker, I also seek your guidance. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in answer to my question, on a number of occasions waved his finger in my general direction, looked at me and said `you'. In those circumstances, Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented and would be grateful if you will allow me to make a personal explanation.

—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will resume his seat. He will learn, when he has been here a little longer, that there is a hurly-burly of politics and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has shown the judgment that comes with the experience of that hurly-burly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 21 May 1985 the Director of Public Prosecutions advised the Secretary to my Department that a letter written by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and addressed to the Family Court of Australia, Sydney, amounted to contempt of that court. The letter in question was written on behalf of a constituent who was objecting to orders that had been made in respect of matrimonial property. This matrimonial dispute had been before a single judge of the Family Court and was later varied on appeal to the Full Court of the Family Court. Further proceedings were listed on 29 March last in the Family Court, Sydney. These proceedings related to the enforcement of the orders that had been made.

SPEECH.PARA: The right honourable member's letter referred to a sworn affidavit made by the constituent and shown to him. In his letter the right honourable member stated that after discussions with the constituent he believed the contents of the affidavit raised fundamental questions affecting the validity of the judgment handed down and he further requested that in the circumstances the contents of the affidavit `should be brought into consideration by the Court before the judgment is processed further'. I am advised that this letter was received in the Sydney Registry of the Family Court of Australia, having been delivered by hand at 9.15 a.m. on 29 March 1985.

I am advised that on 29 March the Acting Registrar of the Family Court wrote to the right honourable member advising that his letter had been received and that the case concerning his constituent had been disposed of that morning but that his letter had not been shown to the trial judge but had been brought to the attention of the Chief Judge. The Acting Registrar advised the right honourable member that to write to a member of the judiciary was highly improper and sought an explanation. On 4 April the right honourable member replied to the Acting Registrar's letter of 29 March pointing out that his request was that the constituent's affidavit should be brought into consideration by the court and that his letter merely gave reasons for his request. He emphasised that these reasons were not presented to influence the discretion of the court. I am advised that subsequent to the receipt of the right honourable member's letter of 4 April the Principal Registrar referred the right honourable member's letter to the Attorney-General's Department with the notation that the Chief Judge had suggested that the matter be referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

It is necessary to balance the duties of members of parliament against the law of contempt. I am certain that the right honourable member is not the first member of parliament to have representations made to him by a constituent in respect of family law matters. I am also of the view that many constituents request honourable members to assist them in legal matters by making written representations on their behalf when the constituent is obliged to appear in court, particularly when that constituent is not legally represented. It is acknowledged that the right honourable member's letter was not before the court and in no way could it be interpreted that the letter could influence the judge. However, the difficulty for members of parliament is that the law of contempt applies where it can be established that there is an intention to influence a judge's decision. Representations made by members of parliament, by their very nature, are likely to be interpreted as intending to influence the person to whom they are made.

This case has highlighted the need for me to raise the dangers in writing to members of the judiciary regarding proceedings before them. While it may be perfectly in order for a member to speak in Parliament on behalf of a constituent and, subject to Standing Orders, to disagree with judicial decisions, the same protection does not apply in respect of letters the member may write to a court requesting that a constitutent's written submission be considered; that is the difficulty in this case. I do not wish to single out the right honourable member in particular as many members of parliament run the risk of finding themselves in the same position. This case merely highlights the need for me to mention the difficulties that can arise.

Honourable members are constantly asked to make representations on their constituents' behalf. They are obliged to assist their constituents as best they can and understandably want to pursue their representations with some vigour. However, they must stop short of putting themselves in a position where their behaviour can be seen as conduct intending to obstruct or pervert the course of justice or where it may be established by conduct that there was an intention to influence a judicial decision. I emphasise that such communications may be seen in this light even if the member of parliament making representations is acting in the utmost good faith and doing what the member thinks is the best by his constituent. It should be emphasised also that actions for contempt can be taken by the court itself and are not necessarily a matter for me.

There are proper avenues for bringing matters to the attention of the court. These are by the constituents and their respective legal advisers bringing evidence before the court. It cannot be done by the back door method of private communications with the judge either by the parties in the case or by other persons acting on their behalf whether they be legal advisers or members of parliament. I understand that on many occasions lay persons endeavour to communicate with a judge of the court. In such cases, the court has usually proceeded by the method of the Registrar writing to the person to point out the impropriety of that action. However, the courts expect a higher standard of conduct from members of Parliament. The courts expect that members of Parliament will be aware of the law and will advise their constituents that the proper way of submitting evidence to the court is by presenting oral or affidavit evidence through their legal advisers or in person.

In this case I am not satisfied that the right honourable member has committed contempt of court. It is clear from my Department's files that the constituent in question has vigorously defended the matrimonial proceedings; has taken them to a court of appeal and has been reluctant to accept the decision made. The hearing of 29 March was by way of enforcement proceedings. I am of the opinion that the constituent's personal attitude and demand that his local member and, through that medium, my Department, assist in his dilemma caused the right honourable member to make repeated representations requesting there be intervention in this case. There was no legal right to intervene and accordingly these requests were declined, but obviously the constituent was not prepared to accept that advice.

I am now advised that the constituent's affidavit referred to in the right honourable member's letter, which is the cause of this complaint, was sworn on 11 December 1984 and filed in court in person by the constituent when he appeared for himself on 14 December 1984. In other words, when the right honourable member wrote his letter on 28 March 1985, I am advised that the affidavit referred to in the letter had already been considered by the court some months before.

With hindsight, it would have been better if the letter had not been written. It appears that the letter was delivered to the court in an effort to mollify the agitation of a constituent who was adamant that his affidavit had not been properly considered. There was no possibility that the right honourable member's letter could have any influence on the proceedings because in legal terms the substantive issues between the parties had been decided on appeal well before that time and the constituent's representations, including his affidavit, had been dealt with by the court in the previous December. Accordingly, I am of the view that no action should be taken against the right honourable member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-First, I make no apologies for representing the electors of New England. There are, however, a couple of fairly fundamental questions that have been raised in the course of this statement and I am grateful to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for the opportunity to canvass them. The first is that I think it needs to be comprehended that there are extraordinary difficulties for many people in two areas of the family law jurisdiction at the moment. One is in the question of the custody of children and the second is in the distribution of matrimonial property. I shall address the matter of the general status of the Family Court in a moment. Equally, the circumstances of this particular constituent need to be understood. When the Attorney-General was speaking a moment ago he referred to the fact that no doubt others in this place have also made representations in respect of the exercise of judgment within this jurisdiction. I refer only to one other and that received some publicity not a little while ago. In that instance it was the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) who made representation by letter to a particular judge of the Family Court. That judge read the letter; it was not a casual representation. Indeed, I gather that in this instance the letter was hand delivered to that particular judge. Quite properly, the Minister, representing his constituent, had pointed to the concern of that constituent-`the dilemma of saving the woman's home and her sanity'. That quote is from an article by Paul Sheehan in the Sydney Morning Herald on 9 November 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty in my case was that this particular constituent was, like many, not a man of substantial means. However, he was a man of sufficient means to have the right to legal aid denied him. He had, in fact, appeared on his own behalf on appeal. He was therefore in the situation where an affidavit, which he believed very strongly set down his position and which, in his view, had not been adequately considered by the Court, was going to be ignored in the enforcement proceedings which were to be undertaken on 29 March. In other words, this constituent, having had representation in the initial case, having not been entitled to legal aid, having no legal representation in the second instance because of his income and having been to appeal, was seeking to have an affidavit which he had prepared and which had been lodged by the Court reconsidered at the enforcement proceedings on 29 March last.

It is not altogether without merit to mention that, as far as this constituent's circumstances were concerned, it was his allegation that, were the enforcement procedures to prevail, not only would he lose the ability to sustain himself and thus be forced on to unemployment benefit, but also he would be unable to meet the maintenance order that was in force on him and his wife and children would henceforth be in circumstances where they would need to be cared for by the state. He sought to bring into the Court's consideration certain matters relating to that which he believed had been given inadequate consideration on an earlier occasion.

In the circumstances there was no other recourse for this constituent other than to come to me as his member of parliament. Are members of this place going to refuse to represent their constituents who are not entitled to legal aid and who have no ability to get any other advice on a matter that they see affecting their whole financial future? As a person of honour, this individual felt that the consequence of the order was going to force both him and his family into dependence on the state. Was I, as a member, to say: `I am not going to represent you'? Indeed, in my view had I done so I would not have been meeting the proper responsibilities of a person elected to this Parliament. Honourable members must remember that matrimonial causes is a Federal jurisdiction; it is not a question of an individual being able to go to a State member. This is a matter of Federal jurisdiction; in this case where was no legal aid available; the individual had no legal advisers to whom he could turn and nobody from whom to seek advice except his Federal member of parliament or perhaps a senator. In those circumstances, I make no apologies for having written, not to seek a particular consideration of that man's point of view, but to ask that the affidavit which had been submitted on an earlier occasion be reconsidered.

The Attorney-General says quite properly that there are procedures which a court requires to be followed in the instance of representations to a court. I think it is worth looking at them in relation to the position of a Federal member. I refer to page 4 of the Attorney-General's statement where he says:

There are proper avenues for bringing matters to the attention of the court. These are by the constituents and their respective legal advisers bringing evidence before the court. It cannot be done by the back door, by private communications with the judge, either by the parties in the case or by other persons acting on their behalf, whether they be legal advisers or members of Parliament.

I contend that members of parliament are in an entirely different situation. I do not know the detail of the affairs of that constituent. Certainly I have met him, he has come into my electoral office and I have considered his case. I tried to give him what help I could, but I am not in a position where I can go before a court and attest to the matters which he represents to me. I could only do so within my personal knowledge of the affair. Matters that are represented to us as individual members of parliament have, in my view, the same professional privilege that should and does adhere to any of the submissions made to any other member of a profession in this country. As an individual member of parliament, I am in a position-and I suggest that every other member of parliament is in an identical position-where I cannot go before a court and attest to matters that are put to me by a constituent. I am not a party to the case. Although he is a constituent, he is not in any other way connected to me. Am I now in a position where I am told that I have to go before the court to act for this man in the only way that he has of final recourse-that is, through his Federal member of parliament? I put to the Attorney-General that that cannot be correct. As members of parliament we must have an ability at least to write a letter to say that certain matters should be considered by the court.

Once again I draw attention to the instance of the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. In that instance, Mr Uren was told that he had made an unwarranted intrusion into the judge's handling of the matter to which he took `great exception'. Mr Uren was told:

His honour can only speculate as to the reason for your writing to him privately, and points out that if you had any legitimate reason to intermeddle in the judicial process, there exist procedures by which you could have intervened---

It is interesting that on that occasion there was no suggestion by the Director of Public Prosecutions that there should be contempt of court procedures. But in my case there is. In the instance I have just quoted the Minister wrote privately. I did not write privately. I wrote to the Court. In the Minister's instance the judge who heard the case read the letter. In my case I did not address the letter to a particular judge, I addressed it to the Court. I did not try to intervene directly and I did not intervene by putting a particular circumstance. I asked whether the Court would hear the submission which was prepared by way of proper affidavit and which had already been considered by the Court. Why does the Director of Public Prosecutions see fit to represent that I should be prosecuted by way of contempt of court, when in the Minister's case there is no suggestion of any reference to the Director of Public Prosecutions? I suggest that therein lies another tale.

There are a number of other matters that need to be referred to. There is the general question of the way by which, in terms of a response, the officer, who was only an acting registrar, responded. In his letter to me, dated 29 March-and the Attorney-General referred to it in his statement-he said:
To write to a member of the Judiciary in the manner in which you have done is highly improper.

In my view, that letter constitutes a prima facie breach of the privilege of the Parliament. Had it not been for my sensitivity about the problems of the Family Court, about which I want to say a little in a moment, that letter of itself would have been a breach of parliamentary privilege. I know there is a problem of trying to divide adequately the responsibility between the administration, the judicature and us, as members of the legislature. When I receive a letter, not from the Court but from a person who purports to be the Acting Registrar, which says that my acting properly on behalf of a constituent is highly improper, I frankly take strong objection to it. I see it as very regrettable that in a circumstance where I am making not a private representation but a very public one, and making it not to an individual judge but to the Court, there should be that measure of sensitivity, particularly in the Family Court, to the receipt of that sort of representation from any member of this chamber or indeed from the other place. I think it is worth while referring to the second reading speech on the introduction of the Family Law Act by the then Attorney-General, Senator Murphy. At page 2827 of the Senate Hansard of 13 December 1973 he said:

Honourable senators will recall that in November 1971 I moved a motion, which was carried by this Senate, that there be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry the matter of `the law and administration of divorce, custody and family matters with particular regard to oppressive costs, delays indignities and other injustices'.

In the course of the second reading speech and through the whole of the development of the Family Law Bill in this place and in the other place there was an acceptance that the family law jurisdiction had to encourage informality, that the processes of law were to be contained. The purpose of having a Family Court set up as it is now constituted was to encourage an informal process of hearing evidence, giving evidence and examining witnesses, so that the problems that individuals undoubtedly have in matters that affect their livelihoods and their family relationships can be adequately considered without some of the trappings of the law. In my view that means that not only is the Family Court in the Federal jurisdiction but its processes need to be considered in a different light from the inevitable formality that applies properly in the criminal law jurisdiction or the civil jurisdiction.

The family law jurisdiction is different. I believe it is quite proper that there should be a basis on which there can be a proper and careful consideration of all the matters that surround a case. It would certainly be regrettable if the Attorney pursues the line he has taken in his statement and suggests that members cannot even write, in the circumstance that they are the point of final appeal, to the Court in general. I accept that there should not be special recommendations or representations, but there certainly needs to be an ability for a Federal member to write to the Court, explain the circumstances, and ask that particular evidence be considered. I believe that for them not to be able to do so would create not for us as individuals, for we are not personally involved, but for our constituents an inequity before the law that frankly cannot be sustained.

There are, I believe, a couple of other matters that need to be considered. Firstly, I think it is worth while again considering the remarks made by Sir Harry Gibbs on the occasion of his giving his biennial review of the state of the judicature in Australia. Honourable members will recall that on the occasion of that address he saw fit to comment on some matters pertaining to the Family Court. He said:
. . . this was not necessarily because of any failure on the part of its judges.
`It may have been a mistake to establish a separate court to administer the Family Court Act.
`Quite apart from some jurisdictional problems, the creation of that court has made it difficult to maintain the highest standards in the making of judicial appointments'.

I offer no view on that other than to say that there is without doubt a very real concern that, regrettably, there has been the tragic assassination of Mr Justice Opas and the death of Mrs Watson, the wife of Mr Justice Watson. No one in this chamber and no one in their right mind in our society would in any way accept that that is the proper or valid way by which any protest should be lodged. Indeed, to all who have been affected by those two deaths I extend my own deepest sympathy. I think it needs to be understood that Sir Harry Gibbs was not talking so much about the way in which the Court exercised its judgment as about the problems he sees in the administration of the law in the way the Family Court is now constituted. I do not intend to go through the details of his argument, but I think it is worth while noting that he, the senior judicial officer in Australia, saw fit to make those comments. We who have the legislative responsibility, who constituted the Family Court, need to have that in our minds when we consider the future. Indeed, I was pleased to note the following comment in a the Age of 8 August in relation to the Attorney-General:
Bowen considers overhaul of Family Court.
The Attorney-General himself said:
Big changes to the operation of the Family Court are being contemplated . . .
. . . broadening the court's jurisdiction, streamlining its deliberations and allowing its judges to sit on other matters.

I commend him to that procedure and practice and trust that legislation to that effect will be introduced into this Parliament without undue delay. I think this does need to be said about the Family Court, and John Slee said it as well as I could in the Sydney Morning Herald on 13 August:
. . . a court that is not just specialised, but isolated; not just proud of its work, but defensive and resentful of all criticism, however justified.

While one can understand the difficulties under which the members of the Family Court function one has to accept that there will be extraordinary difficulties if they cannot accept proper and valid criticism and cannot accept intervention in a dispassionate way on matters that are relevant to the exercise of their responsibilities. In no way, of course, should any one of us seek to intervene in the processes that are within their responsibility. But it is proper, as the final point of appeal, I would contend for any member of parliament to act as I did in this instance. Indeed, I refer to comment of David Solomon's in the Australian Financial Review of 8 August last, when he commented, following Sir Harry Gibb's remarks:

The Family Law Act was not designed to be legalistic, and the Family Law Section, which represents lawyers who practise before the Family Court, has confidence in the judges and court staff in the discharge of their difficult duties . . .
The point is that if it is not designed to be legalistic then surely there should be some flexibility in those remarks that are received.

There are but two other brief matters that I would mention. The first is that I find it interesting that the Director of Public Prosecutions did not see fit to comment on the remarks made by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. It is even more notable that those remarks that were made by the Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, about Mr Justice Phillip Evatt were totally ignored. How come we have a Minister who makes statements which directly go to the core of statements made by a member of the judiciary, albeit functioning as a royal commissioner-that is, the remarks of Mr Justice Phillip Evatt-and it is said, in the course of an interim report, that they can be allowed to go in the way they were; yet in this instance it is suggested by the Director of Public Prosecutions that in some way I should be prosecuted for contempt? Surely, once again there needs to be at least some equality before the law in the interpretation of members of this place.

The final matter that concerns me is that, as we all know, in the last few weeks there has been some argument about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The interesting part of that argument is that much of it originates from comments that are made by some of those who see fit to reject any criticism of themselves. While I accept that it is proper for members of the judiciary to play a role in the community, and I understand their desire and wish to do so, I trust that they will always have in mind that at some future occasion some of their number may need to sit in judgment on the matters on which in public they have previously given opinions. I find it of interest that the Chief Judge of the Family Court was among those signatories to the letter that criticised very publicly the ABC's new management, and criticised it at both upper and middle levels. I believe it is relevant that there needs to be an opportunity for members of the judicature to have views and to express them privately if they so desire, but I think it inappropriate for them, having done so, then to try to cast the stone and criticise those of us in this place who try to the very best of our ability to represent our constituencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not know why the right honourable gentleman wants me to apologise. I have already said that I did not find any contempt in this matter. The right honourable gentleman raised a number of matters which I was not going to raise. He raised the question of another member of parliament being in very much the same predicament as himself. I have a report from the Director of Public Prosecutions which says that he asked for the papers concerning the other honourable member. The Director said that the papers were made available at his request because he considered that neither case should be looked at in isolation and that, quite apart from the fact that a good deal of time had gone past without any action being taken in respect of the other matter, the other member did withdraw, did apologise in a fulsome manner when written to by the court and the court did not request that the matter be pursued further.
—Why not?

—Because of the apology. The point in this case-and I am not trying in any way to drag it out-is that the Family Court of Australia was anxious that I should note that the problem in this case seems to be twofold for the right honourable member. Firstly, the right honourable member, it says, should understand the processes of the law, as all honourable members are expected to understand the processes of the law. Secondly, it says that, when confronted with the views of the Acting Registrar, the right honourable member did not appear to comprehend the difficulties and the seriousness. One can read into that that there was an objection by the Court that the right honourable member did not see fit to apologise. I am not going to debate it here. Let me just come to the point. That makes a distinction which I hope the right honourable member understands. What I am anxious to tell all honourable members is that they are not allowed, under the laws on contempt, to write to judges. This is not the first time that this has happened. It has nothing to do with the Family Court. I am very mindful that when the right honourable member was a Minister he made an explanation in defence of one of his own members-I think it was the then honourable member for Macquarie-when the Chief Justice of New South Wales said that that honourable member was guilty of contempt because a letter had been written to the Chief Justice asking that leniency be extended in a matter. I am very mindful of the fact that the right honourable gentleman made an explanation in defence of that situation. Let me make it very clear: Ignorance is no excuse under the law. The point all honourable members have to look at is that any letters that any of them write can be considered contempt. I only want to mention that to them.
—Do you go on television and defend judges?

—It is a pity that we cannot get some sense into this because we are not trying to make a political issue out of it. Let me make it very clear. The idea of giving an explanation was not so much because it relates to the right honourable member but because it relates to every member of parliament. It is a grave contempt of a court to communicate with or to seek in any way to influence a judge upon the subject matter which he has to determine. That is the law. The court itself can take action for contempt. I am here only to alert all honourable members to the fact that they are in that position. I am anxious to explain publicly that I do not agree with the Director of Public Prosecutions in this case. I think that is fair for everybody. I appreciate what the right honourable gentleman has said about this particular court, but I emphasise that it does not matter which court honourable members write to; they are in difficulties. If a constituent has problems about making representations, they cannot be made by members of parliament or anybody else writing letters. That is the difficulty honourable members might find themselves in. They are not allowed to get away with it in those terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court has had a lot of publicity. It is a very difficult jurisdiction and I am sure that there is room for improvement along the lines that I would like to see brought about. Its judges do a splendid job. They are limited to that jurisdiction. We can imagine the difficulties they have in trying to decide disputes related to custody and matrimonial property. It is not an easy jurisdiction. To that extent I support them to the utmost. It is not easy for them to have to undergo criticism that they are not able to do their job. The right honourable gentleman did not make that criticism, but the real issue is that we cannot have a suggestion that it is an inferior court. Its judges are doing a splendid job under very difficult circumstances. The appointments were not necessarily made by my side of the House; many of them were made by the right honourable gentleman's Government when it was in power. This has nothing to do with the politics of appointment. I know that that issue was not raised, but I want to see a court of the utmost capacity. I want to see the members of that Court recognised as being at the top of their profession. That is the important part. In the Family Court there may be an opportunity for issues about which the parties agree to be dealt with speedily, but where the parties disagree they must be dealt with by a judge of the highest standing because a judicial decision has to be made.

I think there are difficulties in an exclusive jurisdiction. It is difficult to have judges limited to that jurisdiction and not able to do other work. I am anxious to explore with the co-operation of all honourable members, because this is a non-party matter, the question of freeing up the Court to give the highest calibre to its judiciary so that they are able to undertake all sorts of other judicial work. I think that would help no end. I thank honourable members opposite for indicating that they do not see any difficulties there.

I want to make the general point that in law, which is what this is all about, all honourable members run the risk of committing contempt if they dare communicate with a court. That is the difficulty. That is the reason for this suggestion. I do not think it is at all fair to try to make an example of any one member. As I say, many members would have written letters and got away with it on the basis of an apology. For reasons related to the right honourable member's tenacity in the issue or perhaps his own personality, he does not think he should apologise. That is a matter for his judgement. In my view, he has committed no contempt anyway. Having made that explanation, I hope that this is the last time I have to deal with the matter of contempt. I know that the right honourable member mentioned another matter. He should not think that that has been overlooked by the judge concerned.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: DOBIE; HICKS; HUNT; LANGMORE; MACKELLAR; RUDDOCK; SHARP; TICKNER
PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Medical Insurance
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Taxation: Private Medical Insurance
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on health fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie,Mr Hicks,Mr Hunt,Mr Langmore,Mr MacKellar,Mr Ruddock,Mr Sharp and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will set aside a national park for these horses and ensure that killing of feral animals be undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners as in duty bound ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Charlesworth,Mrs Child,Mr Chynoweth and Mr Hurford.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned totally deplore the proposed cut-back of funding for pre-school education, as it will not only affect children in their most formative years but also their families.
We urge you to reverse proposals for cuts in children's services.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer,Mr Steele Hall,Mr Hurford,Mr Jacobi and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that `the existing Australian national flag be changed only with the approval of the nation as expressed in a referendum'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Chynoweth and Mr Mildren.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolizes the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that there is a need to end the current discriminatory application of sales on confectionery and the other anomalies existing in sales tax law. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this tax should be replaced by a broad-based consumption tax with a uniform ad valorem rate, without any exemptions whatsoever.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Chynoweth and Mr Hurford.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of The South Australian Country Women's Association Incorporated and the undersigned shall showeth:
The necessity to restore the concessional price of fuel in rural areas-without which there will be increased freight and production costs.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will restore concessional price of fuel in rural areas for the benefit of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer,Mr Jacobi and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond,Mr Rocher and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely''
Capital Gains tax
Hidden Death tax described as ``Capital Gains tax after death''
Gift tax
Increased Company tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
We ask that the tax proposals be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron and Mr Conquest.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the recent cuts announced in the Mini-Budget to Preschools and Day Care Services are a reversal of A.L.P. policy to make child care services available to all at an affordable cost. Further, that the fee rises arising from the cuts will cause great hardship to the majority of families using these services. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's services in Australia, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Ms McHugh.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Governments failure to act to correct the anomolies in the Assets Test on pensions bring to its notice and due to have effect from the 21st March, 1985 the Labor Government's legislation should be replaced before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners, and calls upon the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's bill in the Senate for the abolition of the Assets Test.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill in the Senate to repeal the Labor Governments iniquitous and unfair Assets Test. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not ``windfall gains'', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the bussiness or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell these assets to sustain them in retirement;

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of State Arts Councils
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging regional residents (country and outer metropolitan) with regard to the provision of access to art forms, in particular to tours of professional performing arts. Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organizations to maintain access to performing and other art activities in country and outer metropolitan areas, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lloyd and Mr Peter Fisher.

PETITION.TITLE: Financial Assistance to Canegrowers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

As residents of the city of Mackay and the shires of Pioneer, Mirani, Sarina and Broadsound and surrounding districts, your petitioners do humbly pray that the Australian Government, in recognition of the present plight of the cane growing industry in our region and other parts of Australia, and in recognition of the importance of the industry to the economic and social well-being of our community, provide urgent financial assistance to canegrowers to ensure the survival and future viability of our local economy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia's Defence Relationship with the United States
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the house-
That we should co-operate with America to prevent a nuclear War.
That we should have a stronger Alliance with America pursuing a common goal of sensible and controlled nuclear arms development.
That we should have a referendum to establish the desire of the Australian people to have a more definite and secure commitment in our defence relationship with America.
That the referendum should read-
That Australia maintain and strengthen its treaties with the United States of America even though that may result in separate and different agreements between the U.S., New Zealand and Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request that the above referendum be taken to the Australian people to vote on.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth-

That the current ``epidemic'' of adverse reactions to medical drugs (both prescriptions and over-the-counter) constitutes a severe health problem. The monitoring of such reactions is inadequate. There is a lack of awareness of the role of such drugs in causing disease. Consumers are confused by the large number of unnecessary brand names for the same drug. There is insufficient onus on drug companies to compensate the victims of adverse drug reactions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray-
1. That there should be-
(a) Mandatory reporting of suspected drug reactions to the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee (A.D.R.A.C.).
(b) Recording of pre-death medication on death certificates.
(c) Collection and publication of the resulting statistics.
2. That the labelling of drugs should include-
(a) Generic (or chemical) names in place of brand names.
(b) Warnings of recorded adverse reactions.
3. That Australia should seek uniform international surveillance of medical drugs.
4. That Pharmaceutical companies be made automatically liable for injury or death caused directly or indirectly by their products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have koala declared an endangered species and given the proper protection of the Commonwealth.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Legal Aid to Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. That they are not satisfied with the legal aid system in Australia.
2. We believe that legal aid should provide a solicitor for any type of court appearance even for a parking infringment for a pensioner who is below the poverty line.
3. The undersigned agree that we are not second class citizens and we need to be represented by a solicitor.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that legal aid must represent any pensioner for any type of court appearance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military Bases in Australia and Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully show:

As a part of the world wide campaign by women in the final year of the United Nations' Decade for Women for `Equality, Development and Peace' (1976-1985) and in view of the grave possibility of nuclear catastrophe, the Union of Australian Women calls on the Australian Government to:
intensify its efforts for nuclear disarmament.
remove U.S. bases from Australian soil.
keep the Pacific and Indian Oceans nuclear free.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Aerospace Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

Whereas space technology involves many of the very highest engineering and scientific disciplines that Australian possesses, which may be applied at an international level to reap significant economic and technological return to the nation, and;
Since an appropriate space program for Australia must involve presently uncoordinated industry, government and research agencies, united together with Federal Government funding;

Your petitioners therefore pray that you will support the establishment of an Australian Aerospace Agency to manage aerospace programs under a Federal Budget, promote technology transfer, and market our expertise overseas, while ensuring the continued operation of existing space-related facilities within the nation.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
5. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult and any increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) Those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the education system would be most severely affected by the re-introduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Yours petitioners therefore pray that:
1. Post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any category of students.
2. Emphasis should be on increasing access to education by, among other things, increasing student financial assistance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth their concern at Family Allowance funding and your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to reject any proposal to reduce the level of Family Allowance fund.

2. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to maintain the present system of progressive increases in the rate of payment of Family Allowance up to the fifth child.

3. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to index the present funding level of Family Allowance to Consumer Price Index movements to maintain its real value at current rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That we the undersigned are greatly concerned by, and totally opposed to proposed taxation changes and the introduction of new taxes, value added tax, consumption tax or retail turnover tax, capital gains tax, death duties, gift tax or inheritance tax. We wish you to repudiate any or all of these taxes in part or full.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Commonwealth Government of Australia will protect our society from these taxes,
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

1. We affirm our belief that, in Jesus Christ, human sexuality is placed in the context of mutual loving relationships and therefore Christians reject any form of pornography which depicts violence against adults and/or children and the economic, physical and spiritual exploitation which is basic to hard-core pornography.
2. We urge the Parliament to prohibit the importation or production of this kind of pornography.

3. We request the Parliament to continue a public inquiry during 1985 to report on the operation of Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 in relation to video tapes and video discs which have been refused classification or classified ``X'' by the Film Censorship Board.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the brumby declared a protected species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House follow the example of President Nixon in the U.S.A. by declaring our wild horse protected from industry and indiscriminate slaughter.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show their desire to stop the spread of Paterson's Curse.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House (the Government) act to implement the biological control of Paterson's Curse.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

We hail as a victory for the not-so-silent majority the decision of the Federal Government to now conduct an inquiry into the effects of hard-core pornography and violence upon people and especially children.
We view with grave concern and deplore the decision of the Hawke Government to allow the sale of this objectionable material to continue and become more widespread during the period of this inquiry.
We request the Federal Government to immediately re-enact the previous laws which banned the entry into Australia and the sale of hard-core pornography and violence in video and publication form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Placement of Water Cups along Highways
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representative in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That in arid areas motorists die of thirst and heat on roads and highways.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics mentions that: In 1980 12 died of thirst, 11 died of heat. In 1981 12 died of thirst, 11 died of heat. In 1982 6 died of thirst, 20 died of heat.

These deaths happen after their vehicle breaks down. They have not enough water to last for weeks on the roads waiting for help. When they realise they run short of water, that's the end, they panic they think of their children and start looking desperately for water around. Unfortunately there is none. When they are overtaken by the de-hydration process it is too late to come back. They die where they are, in terrible pains.

The present Petition purports to prevent the motorists dying of thirst by the placement of watercups at regular intervals along the roads and highways so that they can find within a reasonable walking distance the supply of water they need to save their life.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. We are completely dissatisfied with the pricing policy of petrol in this country.
2. We are aware that it has an adverse affect on the living standards of the average wage earner of this country.
