Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that the price of petrol be reduced by 3c a litre in line with a commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the frequent and substantial increase in the price of petrol and diesel fuel.
2. That we are aware that these price increases have an adverse affect on the living standards of the average Australian wage earner.
3. That increases in fuel prices add to farm costs and further reduce the average income per farmer which has already fallen to one-third of national earnings.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government will immediately reduce the price of petrol by three (3) cents per litre in line with the commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign and take all possible action to prevent further increases occurring.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Specialised Nursing Staff at Heidelberg and Other Repatriation General Hospitals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. A petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That facilities and conditions for the treatment of ex-service personnel at the Repatriation General Hospital, Heidelberg, Victoria are being seriously eroded by the closure of wards specifically for veterans and by the appallingly anomalous salary inequities for nursing staff.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament ensure that funding is immediately made available to reopen wards and to correct anomalies in salaries for the dedicated and specialised nursing staff at Heidelberg, and other Repatriation General Hospitals, so that aging veterans who made immeasurable sacrifices for this country can be assured of a continuity of care and treatment.
And your petitioners as in diety will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Local Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1. That the functions of local government involve assessing local demand for services and either providing, or facilitating the provision of, those services;
2. That a transfer of responsibility for the provision of services from one level of government to another must be accompanied by a corresponding transfer of funds;
3. That local government in Victoria is becoming increasingly involved in the planning and provision of human services in particular;

4. That the level of services currently provided by or through local government cannot be maintained, and certainly cannot be increased, if the funds made available to local government through the personal income tax-sharing arrangement are not maintained at the present level;
5. That we are totally opposed to any reduction in the percentage of personal income tax allocated to local government.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the funding of local government without the consent of representatives of local government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned, the Lord of Knights, Officers, Knights and Members of the Order of the White Cross International, a Humanitarian Knighthood for the Defence and Protection of Life, and the Grand Master and Knights of the Order of the Rainbows and residents of the Commonwealth of Australia by this our humble petition respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned petitioners are deeply concerned about the intent and preparations of the present Government to introduce compulsory Identification-Cards for all Residents of Australia, which may constitute far-reaching consequences for the ordinary individual and that these consequences substantiate our utmost concern.

(1) The introduction of said Identity Cards had occupied the minds of previous Governments for all sorts of reasons, but were dismissed due to stern resistance of the Australian Public as being an intrusion into the privacy of the individual at large. We hold that the World has realised and indeed envies the great personal freedom Australians can proudly call their own. Their right to live and let live, respecting the privacy of others, minding their own business. Shall this vital privilege of the individual be put to the chopping-block by a reform-happy Socialist Government, which may see a need to come in step with Orwellian-spirited State Powers elsewhere in the World?

An Identification-Card may look very innocent indeed, containing no personal information other than name, address and number, possibly a photo of the person concerned, yet the number is the key to the Computer behind the Card, the information stored in the course of time. If such is to be the future, the individual may only suspect that ``Big Brother'' knows about one's political affiliations, financial status, religious beliefs, frequency of changing addresses or employment, abortions, divorces and what more! In short: One's past and present is engraved in this proposed simple and innocent looking Identity Card. We believe that such instrument of identity-control must prove disadvantages on all levels for the ordinary citizen, including pre-judgment in employment situations, particularly in the Civil Service sector or simply during a routine-check by Law Enforcement Officers at the road-side. One may then pray, the right Party is in Power in order to receive a fair treatment.

(2) We further believe that By-Laws, most likely to follow the introduction of I-D Cards may also create a lot of inconveniences for many people in the form of timewaste and fines to pay. We humbly ask the Honourable Members of the House to consider the day to day practicality of the ordinary resident, many of whom may in the rush-hour to work forget the said I-D card and thus this would constitute in principal already an offence, subject to prosecution and punishment. Surely in the wake of introducing said Identity Cards great restrictions and cautious limitations may be promised by Ministers concerned, pushing aside fears of bleak consequences, yet this door-opener to citizen-control with the aid of Computers is likely a step by step procedure. Is the Public not used to ``broken promises'', to ideals being compromised for opportunities?

(3) We, the undersigned petitioners doubt very much that the introduction of the Identity Card would reduce the crime-rate in Australia, or would lead to a higher success-rate in bringing criminals to Justice, nor that the problem of illegal immigrants would be diminished. Considering the dropping success-rate in solving crime-cases in European Countries, where I-D Cards exist for decades the relatively high success-rate of the Australian Police should indicate that competence and efficiency of Law Enforcement Officers are better measures to police Law and Order in a country than I-D Cards. Surely, there will be always promoters of the ``Ideal State of Uniformity'' with a ``Big Brother'' watching us all, like the former Chief of the German Federal Police, Dr Herold, calling for ``the transparent Citizen'' in his Publication ``The Sun-State''. We, the undersigned petitioners rather side with the concept of ``Unity by Diversity'' and we do believe such concept is still very dear to the hearts of true Australians.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The Honourable Members of the House of Representatives reject the introduction of a compulsory Identification Card.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled this humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

The Richest 2,000 people own as much as the poorest 2 1/4 million. It is a travesty in these circumstances that 2 million people are living in poverty in this country (Bob Hawke 11.7.81, Sydney Morning Herald).
The present provision of Social Benefits is absolutely inadequate . . . locking recipients into poverty (including 800,000 children of those on social welfare pensions or benefits).
To enable all Australians to share in the wealth of their country we call on the Australian Government in the forthcoming Taxation Reform to . . .
1. Raise the tax threshold to $10,000.
2. Double the permissible income ($30 to $60) plus indexation.
3. All pensions and benefits to be raised to 30% of the male average weekly earnings and indexed to C.P.I.
4. Full standard pension to be paid on an individual basis to eliminate the discrimination against married couples currently losing $30 per week.

Furthermore, we strongly oppose the introduction of a broad-based indirect tax. Thereby shifting the tax burden onto those dependent on social welfare and low income earners. Further increasing their poverty while allowing continuation of high income earners and tax avoiders to pay little or no tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humbe petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned at the proposed withdrawal of Federal Funding from pre-school education. This is 20% of the pre-school budget. Thus it will be difficult to maintain existing programs and impossible to provide pre-school education for those children not receiving it now. We urge the Commonwealth Government of Australia to maintain this funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post Agency Joondanna, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: This Petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That it is proposed Australia Post's Post Office Agency on the corner of Green and London Streets, Joondanna, Western Australia will be closed down on 30 June, 1985.
Your petitioners therefore pray that this Agency be kept operating for the benefit of the many people who avail themselves of its services and who appreciate the convenience of its location.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Baltic States: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That on 28th February, 1985, the Senate passed a resolution that read:

(i) that Australia, as a member of the United Nations should fulfil its obligation to promote and encourage respect of human rights and fundamental freedom, and should support the European Parliament's Resolution in respect of the Baltic States.

(ii) that in order to do so the Australian Government should, on its own initiative, and by seeking the support of like-minded governments, bring the question of human rights and self-determination for the Baltic States before all appropriate forums of the United Nation's, and especially before the United Nations Human Rights Commission, and,
(iii) that the Department of Foreign Affairs should be directed to take all necessary steps in order to implement this Resolution.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members and the House of Representatives will concur with that resolution.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Conditions of Service and Benefits for Veterans and Military Personnel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, we the undersigned call upon all Members to pay due respect to all returned service personnel. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all changes to benefits for veterans, and conditions of service for military personnel, as announced in the May Economic Statement, be withdrawn as to allow sufficient time for sensible community debate before any veteran or service person can be unfairly disadvantaged.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Federal Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That we the undersigned wish the present Australian Flag to be retained for all time as the Flag of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will retain the National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the introduction of a consumption tax will increase the tax burden of those who can least afford it-middle and low income earners, pensioners and beneficiaries.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should oppose any increase in, or expansion of, indirect tax, especially the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fairfax in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people and concerned citizens of Deniliquin and District respectfully showeth the recently announced cuts in Pre-school funding may cause closures to many Pre-Schools.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will ensure that Commonwealth funding be restored for all our children's sakes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Development Commission Office, Swan Hill, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully sheweth:
1. That there is considerable concern in the Aboriginal Community that the decision of the Aboriginal Development Commission to close its Area Office in Swan Hill will:
(a) Adversely affect the Aboriginal Community in the Mallee &Goulburn Valley Area of Victoria:
(b) Deny immediate access of members of the Aboriginal Community to an Officer of the A.D.C.:
(c) Lead to a reduction in services for the Aboriginal Community in the Mallee &Goulburn Valley Area of Victoria:
(d) Create further unemployment in the Aboriginal Community:
(e) Deny the development of self determination from the Aboriginal Community in The Mallee &Goulburn Valley Area of Victoria.
2. Calls upon the Government to intervene to prevent the closure of the said Area Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The Petition shows: That certain citizens of the State of Victoria are concerned by the Australian Government's failure to adequately fund the Australian Broadcasting Commission.
The ABC, both in radio broadcasting and television, has in spite of a history of severe government cut-backs over the past years, given Australia wide broadcasting of excellence and balance.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the present government take positive steps in the next budget to halt the destruction of ABC programming, without forcing the Commission to introduce commercial advertising, as we believe this will certainly destroy the Australian Broadcasting Commission's quality and independence.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The uncertainties surrounding wages policy and economic growth revealed by last night's Budget.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Budget was brought down last night, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has showered himself with self-congratulations about his third Budget. Certainly we in the Opposition welcome the fact that there has been a significant reduction in the size of the Budget deficit. We also welcome the fact that, unlike the first two Keating Budgets, in which he spent money like a drunken sailor, there has been an increase of only about 1.5 per cent in real terms in Commmonwealth outlays. Certainly that kind of approach is better than the totally irresponsible, wilfully spendthrift approach that was adopted in the first two Budgets. But before the Treasurer settles back into too much self-congratulation about this Budget, there are a few things that ought to be kept in perspective.
—Like interest rates.

—I shall come to interest rates shortly. But we ought to understand the perspective in which this Budget was framed. Last night the Treasurer himself told us that we would have an inflation rate at the end of this financial year of at least 8 per cent, which is double that of our major trading partners. If he does not get up on discounting-and his record of getting up with the unions lately is not too good-we shall have an inflation rate of between 9 per cent and 11 per cent. So if Simon and Bill get their own way, we shall have an inflation rate that takes us into double digits.

SPEECH.PARA: Even though this year the Treasurer did not spend as recklessly as he did in his first two Budgets, the average real increase in government spending under the Hawke Government is 4.9 per cent in real terms. That is more than double the average of the seven Fraser Budgets; and this man comes in and purports to give Opposition members lectures about fiscal responsibility. He is still, without question, the highest taxing, biggest spending Treasurer that we have seen since Federation. But not content with that, under the third Keating Budget 750,000 pay as you earn taxpayers will be going into higher tax brackets this year, with 500,000 of them moving into the 46c rate. He is backing and filling, and twisting and turning. At Question Time, when he was asked about this, he indicated that come September, the bleak September statement on taxation, there will not be any relief for those three-quarters of a million Australian taxpayers who will be going into higher personal tax brackets because he got rolled at the taxation summit.

I know that the Treasurer wanted to change the tax system, he wanted to alter the tax mix; but he got mugged at the Canberra International Motor Inn during the taxation summit-as he may well get mugged at the John Curtin Hotel in Melbourne, where all those IR Club deals are made. When there is a bit of sticky going in the discounting case, I suppose the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will come running along and, reminiscent of his old days at the Australian Council of Trade Unions, he will say, ``Look fellows, we will go over and work it all out', and poor old Paul will be left out in the cold again, in the way in which he was left out in the cold at the taxation summit and he was rolled by the unions.

But not content with leaving those 750,000 Australian taxpayers out in the cold, the Treasurer also brought down a Budget that disclosed a very interesting statistic. It disclosed that under the present Treasurer, per capita overseas debt in Australia has risen from-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not that again.

—Yes, that again; and the Treasurer will hear a lot more about it. He does not like his overseas debt. Last night he said: `You do not want to worry about overseas debt; forget about it. The real reason that it has gone up is that we have had a devaluation, and you know what happens when you have had a devaluation: We have to pay more for our overseas debt'. What a surprise it is. Until we have a revaluation, we shall be stuck with that problem, and the policies that the Treasurer is pursuing will not give him a revaluation of our currency. To return to the theme, however, in June 1983 overseas debt was $1,571 per head. By June 1985 it was $3,326 per head. It has gone from 14.6 per cent of gross domestic product to 25.1 per cent. The Treasurer cannot come back and say: `It is all private sector'. A lot of it is private sector.
—Most of it is.

—I thought that the Treasurer would say that most of it is. But it so happens that the ratio of increase in the liability on the public account is exactly the same as the ratio of increase on the private account. What makes the situation worse, of course, is that Australia's external debt servicing obligations, expressed as the ratio of interest payments and contractually due capital repayments to exports of goods and services, stood at 8.3 per cent of GDP in 1979; it had risen to 33.6 per cent by 1984-85. We did not hear any of that in the 25 minutes reserved for the television last night when the Treasurer tried to represent that he and his Prime Minister were the greatest things since sliced bread so far as the Australian economy is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: But not content with that perspective for the Budget, the Treasurer did not tell us last night that interest rates under him are the highest in real terms that Australia has seen since the Great Depression. Yet he had the indecency, the temerity, in concert with his Prime Minister, before the last election campaign, to promise the Australian people that we would have lower interest rates in 1985. He got up at Question Time today, buttoned up his coat and said: `Look, the market sets interest rates; I have nothing to do with it. It is all out in the market'. I happen to agree with him. The market does set interest rates. He did not worry about that economic finessing in the run up to the election; he did not worry about it in September of last year when he was heavying the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia to let the money supply run out so that interest rates were kept artificially low before the election. That is why there has been such a ridiculous blowout in the money supply from the Budget projections. I know that some of that blowout is due to deregulation, but not all of it is. One has only to read the Governor's Copland Memorial Lecture delivered a few months ago in which he put it very squarely on to the Treasurer and made it perfectly clear that this Government has run until fairly recently quite a loose monetary policy.

The Treasurer also did not tell us that although he brought down the public sector borrowing requirement-he brought it down to 5.6 per cent of the gross domestic product from the dizzy levels he gave us in his first two Budgets-it was still in relative terms 50 per cent above the public sector deficit in the United States. Yet he and his Prime Minister, on their sundry journeys overseas, had lectured the Reagan Administration about its high Budget deficits. In relative terms the Keating deficit this year, taken in concert with the deficits of the States, is 50 per cent greater than the United States deficit. Most of the States and cities in the United States run Budget surpluses. He did not tell us that, either. He did not put that in the 25 minutes that the television gave him last night.

He also did not tell us that one of the reasons he has been able to bring about a big reduction in the deficit is that he has had a rather good profit from the Reserve Bank this year. I do not begrudge him profits from the Reserve Bank-I was happy to have a profit from the Reserve Bank on one or two occasions myself-but there are some remarkable one-off features about this particular profit, as he well knows. It would be a pretty stupid Treasurer who thought that year after year he could repeat this sort of dividend that he got from the Reserve Bank this year. The other thing that he did not tell us is that one of the reasons why there has been a good improvement in the deficit outlook is that he has projected a fall in unemployment benefit payments. It remains to be seen whether or not that fall is achieved.

So whilst the Opposition welcomes the fact that this year the Treasurer has not spent quite so drunkenly as he did on the first two occasions, let us not get carried away about the economic parameters of the third Keating Budget. Let us remember that if those optimistic growth forecasts, which are really the centrepiece of the Budget, either do not stand up or turn out to be far more qualified than the Treasurer thinks, the whole Budget will fall. That is crucially dependent upon what happens on the wage discounting front.

That brings us back to the Treasurer's clout within the trade union movement. I ask honourable members to remember that this is the man who stormed the country, who laid it on the line, who told us that he was not a shrinking violet. He said: `I am not in this business to be messed around by fools. If I cannot get this tax package up I will go. I have more useful things to do with my time.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I never said that.

—He said that he would go if he did not get the tax package up. He pounded in here and said: `It is what you do in this game that matters, not what you say, what you promise, what you threaten or what you beg. It is what you do.' He promised the world on taxation and he delivered us a rout. We all know who was routed; we all know that it was the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland. He had a deal stitched up. He told everybody, out of the corner of his mouth, that Bill and Simon had told him that it was okay and that he could get it through. What happened when the going got a bit rough? The good old Prime Minister ran down to the International Motor Inn and he stitched it up. That was done with such complete disregard for the Treasurer that, the morning after, the Treasurer was still saying on the steps of Parliament House that he was no shrinking violet, that he was after option C and that he would get it. But that did not happen. Yet he comes in here and expects us, and the Australian people, to believe that, having failed to deliver the unions at the Taxation Summit, he can deliver the unions on wage discounting.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who imagines that the unions will go quietly on wage discounting should have heard Simon Crean last night. They should have watched the two of them debate each other. The Treasurer was frightened to say boo to Simon Crean. The magical word `discounting' does not even appear on page 13 of the Budget Speech. He talks about bringing it to the attention of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, he talks about having a discussion about catch-up and he talks about this or that. Then, last night, he said to me: `Look, I told a Press conference that I was going to discount and I told the National Press Club'. Why did he not put it in the Budget Speech? Is he frightened? Has he got it wrong again? He mucked up the discounting section in the mini-Budget and he has mucked it up again on this occasion.

He ought to know, as many other people know, that the unions have a very good mastro when it comes to attitudes to wage discounting. The unions learned very early in the piece that when politicians talk about wage discounting agreeing with them is a mug's game. The unions have had no better authority on this than one of their former presidents, that is, the present Prime Minister of Australia. This is what he had to say about all this damned fool discounting:

We'll say to the Government, `We know inflation is at 16 per cent and we believe it's quite likely it may reach 20 per cent in the next two quarters. But we will not indulge in a trade-off in wages for some conjectural reduction in inflation.

That was the philosophy of Bob Hawke when he was President of the ACTU, and that is the philosophy that Cliff Dolan, Simon Crean and Bill Kelty still support. That is why the Australian public is entitled to take with an enormous grain of salt the pretentions of this man who failed to deliver the unions on taxation, despite all of the hype and all of the discussion, despite all of his strutting around Australia. Do we really believe that he can deliver the unions on wage discounting? Do we really believe that he believes he can deliver the unions on wage discounting? He says that he will have a talk about it. He says that the Government believes in the maintenance of real wages but that there will not be any catch-up. However, he refers to a catch-up in his Budget Speech. I think that at our most charitable we are entitled to suspend judgment on whether or not this man who failed to deliver the unions on taxation can deliver wage discounting.

One has only to look at Budget Statement No. 2 to find out how crucial wage discounting is to the whole Budget edifice. If the Government does not get wage discounting, it is done so far as that 5 per cent growth figure, and its continuation, is concerned. That is the centrepiece of the whole Budget strategy. In immortal Treasuryese, Budget Paper No. 2 says:

Provided its cost and price consequences are handled adequately, the depreciation could still be having a favourable impact on activity beyond 1985-86. On the other hand, if they are not, the macroeconomic outlook would become progressively less favourable as 1986 unfolds.

In other words, the Treasury is saying that the recovery will fall into a heap if we do not get wage discounting. Can we really rely on the Treasurer to get wage discounting? He told us he would deliver tax reform; he told us that he was the hottest number on tax reform in this country. He is now pretending to be the hottest number on wage discounting. We are entitled to assume, from his track record, that he will not get up on wage discounting and that casts a fundamental and serious doubt on the whole Budget strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During September of 1984, at page 1000 of Hansard, this same honourable gentleman, the honourable member for Bennelong and Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), was repeating a theme which he had put forward for a month-that whoever was putting together the next Budget would have huge difficulties in handling it and that we would have a $12 billion Budget deficit on our hands. He said that the unassailable fact was that next year we would have in this country a major budgetary problem. Referring to deficits in earlier years, he said that they would be reduced to pygmy proportions by the deficit problem we would face next year. On 11 September he predicted that the Budget deficit this year would be $12 billion unless we had a mini-Budget in March to increase taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the sort of bunkum he went on with last year. Last year I said it was rubbish. Every year he drags himself into this chamber and says: `I know you have brought the Budget down. It might be okay, but wait until you get to next year and then you will see the problem'. That happened in 1983-84, it happened in 1984-85, and it is now happening in 1985-86. The fact is that we will do next year what we have done this year. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was on this theme for a month and he even had some commentators interested in this theme. I see that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is smiling. He has been trapped again with his own stupid rhetoric.

The fact is that the Government did not have that problem. This Government sat down with an ambitious but, nevertheless, manageableexpenditure-cutting exercise in a routine way and produced the right deficit outcome this year. So we can weigh up all this huffing and puffing against the Deputy Leader's fulminations last year on this issue.

The other thing he said was that we spent recklessly in 1983-84 and 1984-85. What he does not understand-I have told him over and over again-is that the best deficit is not necessarily the lowest deficit. The lowest deficit was not the best deficit in 1983-84 or 1984-85. The deficits for those years were right, and because they were right we got growth in the economy. Yet the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, after we have clocked up these phenomenal growth rates, says: `You had the growth numbers wrong. You had the outlay numbers wrong'. We did not have them wrong, We had them dead right, and we have them right again.

TALK.START.PARA: —All you have done is finance growth with debt.
—You boxhead, you would not know. You are flat out counting past 10.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I ask for that remark to be withdrawn.
—I will withdraw it if you shut up for a while.
—I will shut up in the normal way I have to. You are an idiot. You are just a hopeless nong. You would not know.
—Shut up! Sit down and shut up, you pig.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the fact of the matter is-

—Order! Before the Treasurer proceeds, there was a request for a remark to be withdrawn. The Chair did not hear the remark, mainly because of the noise that the honourable member for O'Connor was making.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw. The fact is that the Government did not spend recklessly in 1983-84 or 1984-85. Those deficits were right. The spending levels were right. The outcome in the economy establishes that. That is the case this year. It is not a matter of giving me any marks this year to detract from our performance over the last two years. Our performance was right then as it is right now. I just demolish this nonsense that the only deficit is the lowest deficit. This is the sort of misery mentality the former Treasurer inflicted on this country-trying to get the lowest deficit and fighting inflation first. It all failed. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition should not give us any lectures about fiscal policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made a point last night about the overseas debt and he has tried to make it again. He talked about the rate of decline in the public sector borrowing requirement in the United States of America and in Australia. It is true that our public sector borrowing requirement is higher than that in the United States, but what is also true is the spectacular rate of decline for Australia. Australia is down 2.4 per cent in its public sector borrowing requirement within two years and the United States is up 0.4 per cent. Canada is down 0.9 per cent and we are down 2.4 per cent. It is the speed of the change that is important. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition should ask himself this question: Who let the States out of Loan Council control, the big electricity instrumentalities and the large State authorities' borrowing programs? Who let the rabbit out of the bag? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and Mr Fraser let it out of the bag. With a global limit we have got it back in and we have tried to get some discipline in borrowings, which we have been able to effect in the last two years. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is to blame for the blow-out in the public sector borrowing requirement when he had his mad railway program, his mad coal loader program, and every other mad thing he had when Malcolm Fraser decided that he would play Santa Claus to the States.

The other thing the Deputy Leader of the Opposition did was to leave to us the sharpest deterioration in our fiscal history in 1983-84. He now has the indecency to say to us: `You have all these indebtedness problems'. Who left us the indebtedness problems? We have spent the last three years trying to bring them down to a pace consistent with economic growth. On page 65 of Budget Statement No. 2, private debt is shown at 25.4 per cent of gross domestic product, up from 5.8 per cent in 1980. The reason for that is that we had an investment boom in this country in respect of energy projects but those same energy projects did not produce their returns in the world market because the energy prices collapsed in 1982-83. Over time they will make their money. Over time the indebtedness relating to them will come down. Even so, they are not in a position where their viability is threatened. We are not talking about some sovereign debt problem of projects of the South American variety built for foreign exchange reasons. These are sensible, properly commercially-structured projects for which there have been borrowings. The public, Commonwealth debt is 6.2 per cent of GDP. This has risen through the 1980s but it is much lower than in the 1930s, the 1940s or the 1950s, and it is offset by official reserves of 6.5 per cent. The figures are 6.2 per cent for the Commonwealth and 12.6 per cent for the total public and publicly guaranteed debt. But that 12.6 per cent has `legrande bouffe' the States went in for as a result of the former Treasurer's action from 1980 to 1983. So the Deputy Leader of the Opposition should not talk to me about external debt. God strike me!

The other thing is that the stock of United States dollar, deutchmark, yen and pounds sterling debt is revalued upwards by our depreciation, so the Australian dollar denomination of the debt rises in the first instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it does.

—If the honourable member listens for a while he might learn something. That is because of the depreciation. The same depreciation which has upvalued the debt in Australian dollar terms will change the balance of imports and exports and drag the current account down. As it changes it will also revalue the debt downwards. While I take a fairly serious and cautious attitude to the question of Australia's external indebtedness, one has to trace its history to understand where it came from and to understand that the former Government let the genie out of the bottle. Honourable members opposite should not go on about that.

SPEECH.PARA: That dispenses with the third matter raised. The next one is the question of the money supply. The former Treasurer did not hit the money supply target once in six years. This Government did so in its first year of office by selling $12 billion-

TALK.START.PARA: —And then you gave it away. You lowered the pass mark.

—I ask the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to hear me out. I heard him out. We did so by selling $12 billion worth of bonds. As if we would sell $12 billion worth of bonds one year and give up on it the next year! The former Treasurer was not able to bring in financial deregulation because the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System had already been eaten by moths on the shelf. That financial deregulation changed the relationship between activity and the monetary aggregates. That is why now, with the money supply-M3-running around 17 1/2 per cent, if we were seeking-
—You could not even deliver Christmas presents to Warren Anderson.
—Why do you not shut up, you clown?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, this man has a criminal intellect and I wonder why he is even in the Parliament, much less-
—Order! The Treasurer is making a personal reflection. He knows that that is contrary to Standing Orders.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, this clown continues to interject in perpetuity.
—Mr Deputy Speaker-
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The Chair is capable of handling the situation. I ask the Treasurer to refrain from making personal reflections.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I was doing so in response to one from him. I just make this point: If this Government were to chase the money supply down a hole to bring that 17 1/2 per cent back within the target range, we would simply destroy this economy. It would do nothing more than satisfy some lunatic fringe interest in the Liberal Party of Australia. It has nothing to do with monetary conditions because monetary conditions are firm. It has simply to do with the change in aggregates. This is happening in the United States and in Britain. The Governor of the American federal reserve system, Paul Volcker, has changed various indices over the last couple of years. He has widened them. He has a pretence at targeting. That is all it is; it is only a pretence. He has gone from one aggregate to another. He has broadened the aggregates from two percentage points to five percentage points. It is a pretence. We will not go into some pretence here to try to find an aggregate about which we cannot possibly make a judgment. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition well knows that that is just a phoney, lousy debating point he has now raised. He now talks about the Reserve Bank profit. What he does not understand about the Reserve Bank profit is that there is $800m in the Budget from the Reserve Bank. That is offset by outlays of $400m on the other side of the Budget which the Commonwealth pays the Reserve Bank on the bonds it holds when it buys those bonds to provide cash for the cash base of the economy. That is $400m against $800m, a net $400m. The Royal Australian Mint this year has a $200m decline in its contribution to revenue. From the Reserve Bank-Mint sector of the non-taxation receipts there is a net contribution of $200m to the Budget. As well as that, the Reserve Bank has sold Commonwealth assets in the form of currency, for which it has reaped Australian dollars and, like any government selling any asset-the mob opposite believes in privatisation-it is entitled to take that into its books. If one makes a choice to sell an asset one is entitled to take it into one's books. That is $200m. Opposition members should not say that in some way the deficit has been reduced because of Reserve Bank profit. That is bunkum. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows that as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to wages. God, I would have thought the honourable member for Bennelong would be the last person to raise his head about wages. When he was Treasurer he presided over the greatest wage explosion in this country's history, put our economy into negative growth for the first time in 30 years and gave us a recession nearly as deep as the Great Depression of the 1930s. He claims he has some credibility on wages. He cavils at the wages and incomes accord and the problems posed by depreciation. The only solution he would have is chaos: Let them all go out there and get their part; let the unions and the high points of the economy take their increases, paying a minimum guaranteed wage to the people at the bottom end. That is his policy. In other words, have a maximum for the work force and a maximum plus for those who are exceedingly strong in the work force. That is his policy. He is not happy with 5 1/2 per cent award wages; he would rather have 14 per cent.

Mr Speaker, in the last 27 months of this Government the increase in award wages has been 12 per cent. In the last 27 months of the Fraser Government, when the honourable member for Bennelong was Treasurer, it was 28 per cent. Is that what he wants? He will never learn anything. He has been giving commentary on an economy entering its third year of growth, but he is still pulling out the old chestnuts that took him to defeat, as though he has learned nothing. He is like an economic Bourbon-he has learned nothing and forgotten nothing. He is trying to tell us that he has the right solution to wages.

This Government, the accord and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have faced these problems before and we will face them again, but they will be faced with the constructive relationship of the accord. Without it we would still have hundreds of thousands of people left in unemployment, particularly young people. The fact that 410,000 people are now in jobs is no thanks to the Liberal Party or the National Party; it is thanks to the policy mix on this side of the House and the conducive relationship with the trade unions. It ill becomes the honourable member to say anything about that.

Finally, the honourable member for Bennelong made much of the tax debate. He said that I said: `What you do is what matters'. That is right. I will repeat that: `You are judged by what you do'. What we have done is to implement almost entirely the recommendations in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System-that moth-eaten thing the honourable member for Bennelong left behind, forgotten on the shelf. As well as that, we are seeking to bring about substantial tax reform in this country, something he might have wanted to do but never tried to do because the Treasury had no conceptual plan for a consumption tax and could not have had it in his time. I reject the matter of public importance absolutely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-
—Hoorah!

—The cheer squad is here, but a bit depleted. Mr Deputy Speaker, once again this Government has thrown away the chance to restore Australia to its former pre-eminent position as one of the world's richest countries. When it first came to power it had the opportunity to take advantage of the world economic recovery, the breaking of our drought and the effective wages pause. Instead of capitalising on the situation it proceeded to become the biggest taxing, biggest spending government in Australia's peacetime history. It increased spending in real terms by over 6 per cent in each of the first two years and this year spending is up again in real terms by about 1 1/2 per cent. Analysis emphasises the uncertainty that surrounds this dubious document. Thirty per cent of all taxpayers-as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) leaves the chamber he should remember this-will move into a higher tax bracket this year. It would be a bold man who would forecast that the incidence of higher taxes on so many taxpayers will not affect the incentive of those workers. As we know, higher taxes do not encourage hard work and productivity. Overall income tax in this Budget is increased by 11.6 per cent. No less a person than Eric Risstrom forecast that this figure is more likely to be 15 to 17 per cent. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I doubt the income tax revenue statistics.

With incentives reduced and the level of tax collections doubtful, it is not surprising that there are uncertainties about this Budget.Furthermore, pay as you earn taxation has increased by 13.3 per cent, compared with a stated inflation rate of 8 per cent. Once again, the Government has shown the PAYE taxpayer no mercy. Once again, the tax burden falls on the wage and salary earner and on small business. The Treasurer has made no effort to reverse the trend which, 30 years ago, had only one per cent of taxpayers paying a marginal tax rate of 46c in the dollar and now has about 40 per cent of taxpayers paying a marginal rate at about the same level. How can the Government meet its growth rate target if the average taxpayer has to work from 1 January to 10.30 a.m. on 12 June each calendar year just to pay government bills? This Government, with its corporate state outlook, its acceptance that big government, big business and big unions should impose their collective will on the community, has yet again demonstrated its disregard for small business. Nothing in this document suggests that this vital and creative sector of our society will in any way be encouraged to take the necessary risks to create prosperity for us all.

Receipts have increased by 13.2 per cent. The Treasurer, who has now deserted us, has indulged in self-praise on the fact that there is to be a minor reduction in the deficit. It is not hard to make a minor reduction if receipts are up 13.2 per cent and the inflation rate 8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he your expert?

—The honourable member should learn to count, too. But the crucial aspect is that there is still a deficit, and a very significant one at that. The deficit of about $5 billion will still add to our large structural deficit. We will still have to pay interest, not only on the existing deficit but also on this year's increase.

SPEECH.PARA: Budget Paper No. 8 on page 9 shows the value of total government securities on issue is now $56 billion, an increase of a startling 43 per cent over the last two years. Furthermore, from a table hidden away on page 308 of Budget Paper No. 1, we now learn that public debt interest will be nearly $7 billion this year, an increase of 19 per cent on last year's figure. These figures, selected from a Budget the Treasurer calls responsible, are appalling. The conclusion is inescapable. I am sorry the Treasurer is not in the chamber so he can look in the public gallery and see the people from whom we are stealing. We are stealing from our children. This Government is the main accomplice in that theft. This further deficit, added to the already existing large deficit, requires that to pay the interest bill we must expropriate our children's future taxation. No member's household-including the household of the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay)-no business and no government should continue to run at a deficit, but there seems to be no effort by the Treasurer to bring spending under control and balance the Budget. No wonder there are uncertainties surrounding last night's Budget. It would be uncharitable to say that the Government has made no effort to cut spending.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not be uncharitable.

—It would be uncharitable of me not to acknowledge the presence in the chamber of the honourable member for Grayndler. Let me give an example of the Government's efforts to cut spending. Export development grants have been cut from $192m to $121m. It is unbelievable that the Government continues to spend money on its own pet schemes, yet cuts funds in an area that is vital to Australia's future. Australia is going broke. Last year our balance of payments deficit was about $10 billion; yet we are reducing support for our exporters. Treasury documents show that at the end of June Australia's external debt was $68.5 billion. Last month our payments deficit was an incredible $1.362 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: We all heard what the Treasurer said. He said that he inherited the external debt. Rubbish! It has doubled in the last two years. It is now running at the rate of $15 billion a year. Furthermore, each taxpayer in the private sector is now owed $15,000 by the Government. By June next year the external debt will be $78 billion, around 35 per cent of the gross domestic product. By the bicentenary, it will be $100 billion and then we will really have something to celebrate. Honourable members opposite can go around their maypoles saying: `We made a ton'. Tremendous! The cost of servicing our overseas debt-about $12 billion-is now greater than was the total debt just over five years ago. These servicing payments are going up at a faster rate than our exports. We now know what the Government thinks about exports. I am glad to see that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is in the House. He could help, simply with one stroke of the pen, by getting Mudginberri back to work.

Our international competitiveness will not be restored until first we control our inflation rate, which is currently running at nearly 10 per cent and which is admitted by the Treasurer to be 8 per cent, and, secondly, we deregulate our labour market to make it more responsive to world conditions. This Budget makes no effort to facilitate the resolution of these two most important matters. Australia will not rejoin its rightful place as one of the world's richest countries until we cut taxes so that initiative can be restored, small business revived and more prosperity created. This requires curtailing government expenditure. Here the Treasurer has been found wanting yet again.

This Budget is a curious, dubious document. The growth rate of 5 per cent is dubious. The inflation rate of 8 per cent is dubious. The tax collection figures are dubious. In so many aspects there must clearly be cause for uncertainty. This uncertainty will be heightened by the knowledge that this document is not all we are to get. The tax package is yet to come. If this Budget is all the world's best Treasurer can give us, we should replace him with someone who can count.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling the honourable member for Streeton, the Chair extends indulgence to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to make a brief comment because of its relevance.

—I apologise in advance to the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) for leaving the debate. I have to catch a plane to fulfil a commitment in Melbourne. I would not wish to be discourteous to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) will not be around to hear my rebuttal of some of the few things he has said. I am rather amused by the fact that the wording of his matter of public importance was far different from the content of his speech. He certainly did not stick to it. He certainly did not make any reference to a wages policy or economic growth. I am not surprised, because the Opposition has shown that it lacks any comprehensive, detailed wages policy. Certainly its record when it was in government is one of negative growth rather than positive. There is an explanation of why the honourable member lacked fire and verve in what he had to say. I believe that the honourable gentleman actually secretly supports the Budget. He actually finds very little in it to disparage or complain about. However, he was obliged to go through the act of blustering and puffing up, of giving some sort of pretence to his numbers on the back bench, which he hopes to amass into a majority over his current Leader, that he has something to say, that he is made of stern stuff, the mettle of leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: Further proof that there is nothing those opposite can say, that they do have a vacuum of opinion on this matter, was the paucity of questions on the Budget at Question Time. After one or two preliminary rounds of feinting boxing moves they ran out of steam. There were no questions from the Opposition on the Budget. We moved on to extraneous matters which certainly had nothing to do with the matter of public importance before us now. We then heard what must be one of the most cliche-ridden, set scripts provided to a member of this Parliament. I suspect that when the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) heard that he was to be the supporting speaker for the Opposition during this debate he rang the Institute of Public Affairs and the Australian Small Business Association and said: `Quick, get me something. I do not understand anything about the Budget. I need a set script with some cliches in it'. Both organisations, which obviously wrote the script, are so out of step with the rest of business feeling, the business praise for the Budget handed down by the Treasurer yesterday, that the script was completely peripheral to the Budget and the debate today.

I found it very difficult to swallow when the honourable member cried crocodile tears for wage and salary earners. The honourable member is noted as one of the up and coming band of union bashers and wage and salary bashers from the other side. He is itching to get on to that front bench and take over the role with the waddy to try to crush the unions into submission. The honourable member said that the Government was stealing from the babies in the street. I found that extremely hard to take when not one small advance in tax reform ever came from his side of the House during its period of government. We have attempted, we have talked about, we have debated tax reform. We will hear the final package of tax reform very soon.

Let me get back to the Budget, brought down last night. Its strategy received praise right across the spectrum. Right across business, the unions and the economy we hear praise that this Budget strategy is the correct one. It is designed to bring about sustainable private sector economic recovery. There is nothing vague about it. There is nothing uncertain about it. We now have the third year of sustained economic growth which is pinned on a consistent Budget strategy. Because of this Budget, we expect a non-farm growth of 5 per cent over the coming year, which is 4 1/2 per cent in total growth of GDP.

The honourable member for Deakin referred vaguely to wealth, saying that somehow we should return to some pinnacle of being a wealthy nation. Yet no mechanism for achieving economic growth-the generator of wealth in this country-was mentioned by those opposite. During the three years of office of this Labor Government since April 1983 we have achieved greater growth than was achieved during the whole eight years of the Fraser Government. However, just as important as the magnitude of growth is the pattern of that growth. Once again, this Budget continues to provide the certainty of growth in years ahead. Last year, despite pumping up the economy through government expenditure, only one-third of the economic growth occurred in the public sector. Two-thirds, or nearly 70 per cent, occurred in the private sector. Expectations for the coming year are that the contribution of growth to the economy by the public sector will be halved again. That is, less than one-sixth of the growth will be in the public sector. This Parliament must recognise that when growth is sustained in the private sector, when the level of unemployment is going down and jobs are being created, there is certainty in the air.

The honourable member for Deakin compared Australia with other countries. I can say only this: While this Government will not be satisfied until we have almost no inflation and extremely low interest rates, it is a fact that the rest of our major competitors and trading partners in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development are actually experiencing declining growth, whereas it is the reverse in this country; we are expanding. Provided that there is co-operation and the talks between the Government and the leaders of the Australian Council of Trade Unions are successful, we can expect that about one quarter of our predicted growth will be due to the effect of the depreciation of the Australian dollar. The Treasurer was adamant that the responsible task before us is that of ensuring that the one-off inflationary effects of depreciation do not become built into the underlying rate of inflation. I ask honourable members to contrast that acceptance of responsibility, that declaration of intention, with the inability of the Opposition when in government to develop a policy to come to grips with the fact that the value of the Australian dollar was out of step with the world economy. The previous Government had no alternative policy, other than relying on an over-inflated dollar, because it could not cope with the changes that deregulation and even a free float in the economy would demand of it. The reason it had no policy lay in its utter contempt for the cornerstone of success of this Labor Government-the prices and incomes accord.

The accord has been the mechanism which has allowed this Government to talk in co-operative fashion with the peak council of the wage and salary earners and to deal with inflation. This has meant that we have had a growth in jobs and a drop in the level of inflation. I ask honourable members opposite to contrast that improvement with the deplorable record of the previous Government and the situation just three or more years ago. That Government had a lack of policy; it had no wages policy whatsoever and, as the Treasurer said earlier in this debate, in 27 months this country experienced a wages blowout of 28 per cent. The previous Government had an abysmal record. It was unable to develop a wages policy and to control the wages blowout. Worse still, added to that Government's sorry record of economic mismanagement we had 10 per cent unemployment, 13 per cent inflation, negative growth rates, record levels of industrial disputes, and also record Budget deficits.

The honourable member for Deakin said that he was concerned and that we should do something about the proposed level of the Budget deficit. He said that $4.9 billion was too high. In percentage terms of gross domestic product, the current proposed Budget deficit announced last night is less than half of the record Budget deficit that the now Opposition left us when, fortunately, it was defeated in March of 1983. Let us have no doubt about that and let us be quite clear that the Australian people do not want to return to that sorry state, that dismal performance.

The talks to be held in the next few weeks between the Government and the ACTU are crucial. It is quite correct for the Treasurer to say that the Government will ask the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to take into account the effect of the deflation of the Australian dollar. There are many costs in production. Wages are only one of those costs. They are not the total contributor to inflation caused by the devaluation. Working people should not have to carry the total burden of inflationary effects, but they should be expected to bear a fair and proper burden. So the Government proposes to modify its support for full indexation, after talking over with the trade union movement a comprehensive package that will honour and preserve the accord which, according to the OECD, has been a remarkable and successful instrument of wages policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the Committee's report on proposals for variations of the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs-Eighty-fifth series-together with extracts of minutes of proceedings and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Foreign States Immunities Bill 1985 is to set out in clear and accessible form the law relating to the jurisdiction of Australian courts over foreign states, their agencies and instrumentalities. This matter is currently determined according to the common law. The legislation will implement the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission in report No. 24 on foreign state immunity; which was tabled in the Parliament on 10 October 1984. The report was prepared after thorough examination of similar legislation in other countries and extensive consultation with relevant organisations and individuals. The matter was referred to the Commission by the previous Government. It is non-contentious and we expect bi-partisan support. The Bill is concerned only with immunity from suit and related matters such as the proper scope of enforcement measures and service of process. It does not confer immunity from substantive laws nor does it concern liability to criminal proceedings. The Bill is strictly prospective in effect.

Since the early nineteenth century it has been recognised that foreign states are at least in some ways in a special position when action against them is brought before the courts of other states. The basic justification for immunity is the notion of sovereign equality of states. Until the early 1970s, it was generally thought that at common law foreign states and their agencies were entitled to absolute immunity from jurisdiction. The civil law countries, by contrast, have long distinguished governmental and private transactions of foreign states, according immunity only to the former. In a series of recent decisions United Kingdom courts applied a restrictive immunity approach and declined to accord immunity in respect of commercial transactions. The United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada, Singapore and other common law countries have legislated to apply this restrictive immunity approach. There have been no recent Australian cases on the matter. Although it is likely that Australian courts would adopt the restrictive approach taken in the United Kingdom prior to enactment of legislation, there are many areas of uncertainty. Because other common law countries have now legislated on the matter there will be little case law to develop and clarify these areas of uncertainty.

The main argument for the restrictive theory of foreign state immunity is that commercial or trading activities conducted by or on behalf of foreign governments should not attract the special jurisdictional immunity enjoyed by foreign states. Australia's increasing involvement in international trading and financial activities, including the involvement of foreign state agencies in investment and banking or other trading or financial activities in Australia, make the subject of increasing importance to Australia. The proposed legislation follows the United Kingdom State Immunity Act 1978 in laying down a general rule of immunity for foreign states which is made subject to the following exceptions:

Commercial transactions will not be immune. This includes all contracts for the supply of goods or services or for loans or guarantees. This will bring Australian law into line with the law of other major financial centres such as New York, London and Singapore. It is an essential step if Australia is to develop as an international banking centre conducting sovereign risk lending.

Torts resulting in death, physical injury or damage to tangible property will not be immune if committed in Australia by the foreign state or by its servants acting in the course of their employment. As an example of such a case, a person injured in a road accident involving diplomatic personnel acting in the course of their employment will be able to sue the state for damages. The diplomat personally will continue to be protected by diplomatic or consular immunity in accordance with internationally agreed rules. The foreign state will retain its immunity where only economic loss is suffered-that is for torts such as defamation, misrepresentation, deceit, and negligent mistatement unless the tort occurs in the course of a commercial transaction.

Employment contracts entered into by foreign governments will not be immune from suits unless the contract is made with a person who is a foreign national and not a permanent resident or national of Australia.

Disputes concerning immovable property-for example, land-will not be immune. This lack of immunity will apply accordingly to claims that the foreign state is using its property here in such a way as to constitute a nuisance.

Other matters for which immunity to some extent will be removed include disputes involving industrial and intellectual property, membership by the foreign state in a locally formed partnership, company or body corporate, and the conduct of arbitrations.

Apart from these circumstances prescribed by the legislation, a foreign state also is able to submit voluntarily to the jurisdiction. This may be done, amongst other ways, by a written agreement in advance or by submission in the face of the court.

`Foreign states' are defined to include political subdivisions or component units, such as provinces or states, and hence the Bill extends immunities to them. This could assist the Australian States to claim similar treatment in foreign states on the grounds of reciprocity. The proposed legislation will deal also with the immunities of `separate entities' such as state trading corporations or investment commissions that are agencies or instrumentalities of the foreign state but have a separate legal existence. `Separate entities' are given, in most respects, the same immunity as the state. In practice, this means that entities with exclusively commercial functions-the majority of those involved in dealings with Australia-will lack immunity. Consistent with the approach taken to immunity from jurisdiction, the property of foreign states is made immune from execution to satisfy judgments obtained against it, subject to specified exceptions. Commercial property is not immune from execution. This is defined as property being used by the foreign state substantially for commercial purposes and can never be military or diplomatic property. Consistently with the lack of immunity of immovable property, such property loses its immunity from execution consequent upon successful suit against that property. A foreign state also may waive its immunity from execution with respect to any property.

The third area of major reform which the Bill implements is an area about which currently there is considerable uncertainty; that is, the appropriate way to serve court documents on a foreign state. The new legislation will also enable service of writs on foreign states to be carried out by the Department of Foreign Affairs using diplomatic channels. It also makes service of an initiating process effective where it is in accordance with an agreement or treaty.

Certain procedural requirements additional to those imposed by the general law will apply where foreign states are parties to a suit. For example, there is an extension of the time for entering an appearance before judgment in default of appearance can be entered against foreign states.

The legislation does not affect any immunity or privilege conferred by the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act 1967, the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972, and the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963. Nor does it affect immunities conferred on foreign states by or under other Commonwealth legislation. Where the immunities and privileges under the Bill exceed those allowed to Australia by the laws of a foreign state, regulations may be made modifying the operation of the legislation in relation to that state. Regulations also may be made to modify the operation of the legislation where a treaty is concluded between Australia and a foreign state in which different provisions have been agreed. An additional matter covered is the immunity of a head of state acting in a private capacity. The position at common law is unclear. The legislation provides that a foreign head of state acting in a private capacity has the same immunities as a head of a diplomatic mission similarly acting. These immunities extend to the spouse of the head of state. This is the approach of the United Kingdom legislation and has the advantage of bringing a rarely litigated issue under a well-developed body of law which has been specifically developed to satisfy the needs of both the sending state and the receiving state.

The financial impact of this legislation is likely to be minimal. Any additional administrative workload resulting from my Department's role as recipient of process to be served on foreign states, or from the role imposed on the Department of Foreign Affairs to secure service through diplomatic channels, is not expected to impose any significant financial costs.

Finally, I take this opportunity again to congratulate the Law Reform Commission on its excellent work on this reference. It is an outstanding example of legal scholarship and of the continuing relevance and importance of the Law Reform Commission. The report will prove, I am sure, of lasting importance and of use not just in relation to this legislation, but also to other countries and international bodies like the International Law Commission which are continuing to work in this area. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr N. A. Brown) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The provisions of the Bill before the House have two effects. The major amendment is to extend the ambit of the Census and Statistics Act to enable the external territories to be included in the 1986 and future censuses of population and housing conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Earlier censuses of the external territories were conducted under local ordinances. The amendment implements, in part, the Government's policy that the inhabitants of the territories will be treated in the same way as other Australians. The provision relates to such territories as are prescribed. This avoids the necessity to conduct the Australian census in external territories where there would be significant operational difficulties and cost for relatively little benefit. The amendment does not extend Part III of the Census and Statistics Act to the external territories. This is because the needs of the territories for statistics other than those derived from the census are likely to be significantly different from those required by other parts of Australia. The extension of the Australian Bureau of Statistics statistical activities, other than the censuses of population and housing, is therefore unlikely to be necessary or cost effective. The additional cost to the ABS of extending the census to the external territories is estimated as $58,000.

The Bill also provides for an amendment to Section 14 of the Act. This will overcome a technical difficulty of the existing wording. It does not change the intention of the existing provision, which is to ensure that people are not liable to any penalty for omitting, or refusing, to state the religious denomination or sect to which they belong or adhere. An explanatory memorandum is available to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr N. A. Brown) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to authorise payments in 1985-86 arising out of decisions taken at the Loan Council meeting of 30 May 1985 which fall outside the provisions of the Financial Agreement Act 1928. Specificially, this Bill seeks to authorise:
the payment of general purpose capital grants to the States in 1985-86;
the prepayment of capital grants during the first six months of 1986-87, pending passage of similar legislation in that year;

the continued payment in 1985-86, 1986-87 and 1987-88 of loans on concessional terms and conditions of amounts nominated by the States and the Northern Territory from their approved borrowing programs as being for the purpose of public housing; and
to provide scope for the payment of concessional housing loans in the first six months of 1986-87, 1987-88 and 1988-89.

The amount to be advanced to each State under this last provision is limited to an amount equal to one-half of the amount it was permitted to nominate in the previous year. Loan Council decided to hold the total State Government's borrowing programs to $1,564.5m in 1985-86, the same money level as in 1984-85. This will assist the Commonwealth in further reducing the public sector borrowing requirement in 1985-86.

Since 1975-76 one-third of the State governments' borrowing programs have been provided by the Commonwealth as interest-free capital grants. For 1985-86 only, the capital grant provision is to be increased by 7 per cent, or 36.5m to $558m, or approximately 35.7 per cent of the total program, and the loan component reduced by an equivalent amount.

The effect of these grants is to relieve the States of debt charges-that is, interest payments and sinking fund contributions-which they would otherwise have to pay, and the grants accordingly have a substantial beneficial effect on the overall financial positions of the States.
