The grants were introduced to help States finance works, such as schools and other capital works, from which debt charges are not normally recovered. There are, however, no conditions attaching to the manner in which the grants are applied by the States.

The arrangements whereby the States and the Northern Territory are able to nominate part of their approved borrowing programs for public housing were introduced in 1982-83. As a condition of the payment of these funds, the Bill contains provision that a State or the Northern Territory must be able to meet its matching requirements for the purposes of the Housing Assistance Act 1984. Subject to that, nominated funds will be provided to the States and the Northern Territory as the loan terms and conditions set out in the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, and hence will bear interest at the highly favourable rate of 4 1/2 per cent per annum and will be repayable over 53 years.

In deciding to continue the arrangements the Government has recognised the considerable contribution made by the arrangements to the financing of public housing in the States and the encouragement it has given the States to increase their housing expenditures. However, the concession represents a large and growing ongoing cost to the Commonwealth in terms of the reduced interest payments received from the States and, as a result, the Government has found it necessary to introduce some limits on the application of the concession. The Bill therefore imposes limits on the proportion of Loan Council borrowings which States and the Territory can nominate of 30 per cent of the loan component of their programs. This exceeds the proportion of the loan component which has so far been nominated by any of the States, except for South Australia and Western Australia, which in 1984-85 each nominated the whole of their loans. As a transitional arrangement, the Bill provides that those two States will again be able to nominate the whole of their loans in 1985-86, 60 per cent in 1986-87 and 30 per cent thereafter. This Bill forms an important part of the Commonwealth's overall financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory and I therefore commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr McVeigh) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to amend Section 6 of the principal Act to set the upper ceiling for the new levels of the charge to be fixed by regulations. As honourable members will recall, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) announced on 22 March the broad parameters of the new overseas student policy.

Decisions on the direction of the policy followed consideration of the reports of two independent committees. These were the Committee of Review of Private Overseas Student Policy, chaired by Professor John Goldring, and the Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program, chaired by Sir Gordon Jackson. Both committees identified the hitherto hidden subsidy in the overseas student program-that is, the gap between the cost to the Commonwealth of providing places for overseas students in educational institutions, and the contribution made by those students through the overseas students charge. In 1984-85 this subsidy was valued at $98.6m for students from developing countries-about 96 per cent of all overseas students. The student's contribution through the overseas students charge represented about 25 per cent of the average cost of a place in higher education.

The increase in the overseas students charge proposed in this Bill raises that contribution to approximately 35 per cent of the average cost. As from 1 January 1986, the new levels of student charge will be, subject to regulations, $4,340 for courses in medicine, veterinary science and dentistry; and $3,500 for all other courses. The overseas students charge raised $30.3m in 1984-85 and is expected to raise $45.5m in 1985-86, but $3.065m of this amount relates to 1984-85 charge payments not recorded until 1985-86. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr McVeigh) adjourned.
(Quorum formed)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to authorise the Treasurer (Mr Keating), on behalf of the Commonwealth, to guarantee borrowings raised by Qantas Airways Ltd to finance the purchase of a Boeing 747-300 extended upper deck aircraft. Acquisition of this aircraft by Qantas will bring to four the number of B747-300 aircraft in Qantas's fleet and will bring Qantas's total fleet in March 1986, when the aircraft is delivered, to 28. Qantas's decision to purchase an additional B747-300 aircraft was a result of market growth, and the company's need to participate fully in that growth. The fourth aircraft will join the company's existing three 747-300 aircraft on the Sydney to London route, and will enable Qantas to operate a daily B747-300 service on the Kangaroo route to maximise the marketing impact of the new aircraft type. A number of the company's competitors already operate, or are planning to introduce, this type of aircraft on the Kangaroo route, and the fourth aircraft will also allow Qantas the option of introducing upgraded services on other routes.

The extended upper deck aircraft has proved very popular with passengers, particularly with business travellers. Like the company's existing extended upper deck aircraft, the new aircraft will also be powered by the latest generation of fuel efficient Rolls-Royce engines. In addition, satisfactory offsets arrangements have been concluded by the Government with both the air frame and engine manufacturers, and these arrangements will provide benefits by way of manufacturing activity and technology transfer to Australia's aircraft manufacturing industry.

The provision of a guarantee for Qantas's payment of, and payment of interst on, amounts borrowed for this new aircraft and related spare parts and equipment will be limited by the Bill to $US115m or its equivalent in other currencies. The provision of the guarantee does not involve the Government in any cash outlay, but does create a contingent liability for the Commonwealth.

The terms and conditions of Qantas's proposed borrowings for the new aircraft are to be subject to the Treasurer's approval. The Bill also provides for proper security to be given to the Commonwealth over such property as the Treasurer deems satisfactory, and Qantas is to undertake to maintain adequate insurance of the items under the loan guarantee, and to protect the security of the Commonwealth against the sale or mortgage of the aircraft. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr McVeigh) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Economic Statement to the House on 14 May announced that the export market development grants scheme was to be revised, effective from 20 May 1985. This Bill gives effect to the changes announced in my media release dated 14 May. The EMDG scheme was first introduced in 1974 and has been amended on several occasions since. It is based on the same principles as the export market development allowance scheme which operated from 1961 to 1974. The EMDG scheme aims to encourage Australian exporters to seek out and develop overseas markets for goods, services, industrial property rights and know-how which are substantially of Australian origin. It provides financial incentives in the form of taxable cash grants for eligible expenditure incurred on overseas market research and development such as advertising, overseas representation, the cost of participating in overseas fairs and exhibitions, overseas travel associated with trade promotion, and the cost of bringing agents or buyers to Australia.

For some time, however, the Government has been concerned about the operation of the scheme. Apart from its rapidly escalating cost and concern over its abuse, increasing doubts arose over the scheme's effectiveness. The Government is concerned to ensure that public funds provided for export incentives are used in a cost-effective manner and result in an improvement in sustained export performance. It is mindful that the EMDG scheme is an incentives scheme to encourage Australian exporters to seek out and develop overseas markets and not a subsidy for industry. Against this background, last year the Government asked the National Export Marketing Strategy Panel, chaired by Mr Bill Ferris, Group Managing Director of Barlow Marine Ltd, and comprising representatives from the export sector, to examine the EMDG scheme, in the context of providing general advice on the most effective marketing strategies through which the Government can assist in increasing Australia's exports, particularly of manufacturers and services. I take this opportunity to congratulate Mr Ferris and his panel for their very thorough report.

At the same time, my Department of Trade undertook an evaluation of the scheme based on a random sample of EMDG claimants. Subsequently this year my Department undertook a second evaluation of the scheme based on a separate random sample which confirmed the results of the initial evaluation. It can be seen then that the Government's examination of the scheme has been most extensive and underpinned by solid analysis. It involved consideration of the Ferris report, which, incidentally, was the subject of extensive consultations with exporters and export organisations, including through public seminars in all States, as well as two evaluations of the scheme by my Department.

The outcome of this examination was quite unequivocal. The Ferris Panel concluded that the existing EMDG scheme was badly designed and that there was a need for significant reforms if the scheme is to provide a positive inducement to genuine exporters in a cost-effective and measurable way. The Panel made 15 recommendations designed to make the scheme more accountable and `results oriented', to remove the backlog of unprocessed claims and to tighten up and streamline certain administrative procedures.

Similarly, the Department's evaluation disclosed major deficiencies in the scheme. Almost 50 per cent of claimants were shown to be dropping out of the scheme after three years, having generated little or no export earnings. The scheme enabled recipients to obtain grants of up to $200,000 per year for the first three years without necessarily generating any export earnings at all. Thereafter, claimants had to have export earnings of only $25,000-$10,000 in the case of industrial property rights and know-how-to be eligible for further grants. In other words, it was possible for them to receive grants of up to eight times the level of their export earnings under the existing export performance test.

Another important finding was that less than 5 per cent, or some 300 claimants, generally the large exporters, were receiving almost one-third of total EMDG payments. Many of these were subsidiaries of large international corporations with access to their own `in house' marketing networks and therefore with a questionable need for assistance from scarce public funds. Not surprisingly, therefore, usage of the scheme and its cost was escalating dramatically. In the four years ended 1984-85 fiscal year the number of claimants under the scheme rose by some 40 per cent and the total cost by around 120 per cent. In turn, the mounting cost of the scheme has led to its being underfunded in recent years by successive governments, resulting in a large backlog of unprocessed EMDG claims. The Ferris report recommended that urgent action be taken in this area. The Government shared this concern and towards the end of 1984-85 provided funds of $54m by way of an Advance to the Minister for Finance to reduce the backlog of outstanding claims. These funds were additional to the $125m provided for the EMDG scheme in the 1984-85 Commonwealth Budget. With the provision of these additional funds. The carry-over of unprocessed EMDG claims as at 30 June 1985 was reduced to a more normal level.

In reviewing the scheme, naturally enough the question was raised: Why have any export incentives at all? After all, a report of the Industries Assistance Commission in 1982 had recommended that the EMDG scheme be terminated with effect from 30 June 1985. This threshold question was thoroughly examined by the Ferris Panel, which concluded, inter alia, that an export incentives scheme is needed to motivate Australian companies into export action and, in particular, to counter the legacy of the post-war import replacement strategy for industrial development. The Ferris Panel examined a number of alternative export incentives schemes, falling into three categories: Tax-based schemes; advance approval, project-type schemes; and a general access, reimbursement scheme. It came out in favour of the third option-a general access, but reformed, EMDG scheme.

The Government accepted the broad thrust of the recommendations contained in the Ferris report, in deciding that a general access EMDG scheme be continued. It was clear that a general access scheme was supported overwhelmingly by major export organisations and industry groups. In reaching this decision the Government was mindful of the IAC's views but influenced even more by Australia's relatively poor trade performance and the urgent need-as outlined in my statement on Australia's trade to the House on 13 May 1985-to improve our performance as a trading nation. The Bill provides for the amended scheme to continue until 30 June 1990.

While the Government accepted the main thrust of the relevant Ferris report recommendations, it was not able to endorse some specific elements for a variety of reasons. Apart from the important question of cost considerations, the Government was mindful that the recent large depreciation of the Australian dollar and a reduction in the rate of inflation had improved the international competitive position of Australian exporters. It was also anxious to address the shortcomings of the scheme which emerged from my Department's evaluation of it.

Let me now outline the major changes that are being introduced in this Bill. The provisions are being strengthened to ensure that only firms which export can continue to receive EMD grants beyond two years. The maximum grant entitlement will remain at $200,000 per year. New claimants will be eligible to receive grants of up to $200,000 in their first two grant years without being required to achieve any export sales. The decision by the Government to depart from the Ferris report recommendations in order to provide this two-year `no exports' period of grace for new exporters resulted from the consultations held on the Ferris report. The Government accepted that new exporters often require a lead time between market development and export sales.

Thereafter, however, the maximum grant which can be received will be the lesser of $200,000 or a percentage of export earnings declining progressively over a five-year period, as proposed by the Ferris report. That is, the maximum grant entitlement will be determined by export performance. Firms which have been receiving the benefit of grants for some years will be subject to the percentage of export earnings applicable under the amended Ferris report formula to their next grant year.

As under the existing scheme, `approved bodies' will be exempt from the export earnings test since these are organisations which promote the exports of members of an industry but do not export in their own right. Grants will not be payable to claimants with export earnings in excess of $20m. The Government believes that, at a time when there is a need to reduce Government expenditure, such large exporters are less in need of the support of a Government export incentives scheme and that scarce Government funds are better directed towards assisting committed small to medium size exporters.

Because of its unique nature, tourism did not sit easily with some aspects of the EMDG scheme. Obviously there were difficulties in applying an export performance test to the tourism industry. Accordingly, the tourism industry is to be excluded from the scheme. However, given the importance the Government attaches to tourism as one of Australia's fastest growing industries, and as a foreign exchange earner, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) recently announced the introduction of a new tourism overseas promotion scheme to be administered by his Department to meet the tourism industry's particular needs. This scheme will continue the provision of Government assistance to the tourism industry. It will have the advantages of producing a more co-ordinated and efficient promotional effort and will enable specialist advice to be given to prospective tourism promoters.

Statutory authorities, except those primarily funded through industry charges, those subject to income tax or those which provide eligible educational services, will be excluded from the scheme. This is to eliminate the element of `double dipping' in the past where authorities which are already funded by the Government have also been claiming government grants under the EMDG scheme. This will be effected by regulation. Grants will be paid only on the amount of eligible expenditure in excess of $5,000 incurred in a grant year. The Government believes this represents a reasonable amount of expenditure which claimants should be prepared to bear in order to demonstrate their bona fides as well as some financial capacity to mount sustained export activities. It considers that this threshold of eligible expenditure represents an important safeguard against the possiblity of public funds going to claimants not genuinely interested in, or indeed engaged in, serious efforts to develop export markets. The threshold also obviously contributes substantially to the necessary reduction in the cost of the EMDG scheme. Significantly, analysis by my Department showed that the dropout rate of claimants with eligible expenditure of $5,000 or less was up to 50 per cent greater than for claimants as a whole. The $50 per day promotional visit allowance will be discontinued and, where first class air travel in undertaken, reimbursement under the scheme will be restricted 65 per cent of the fare. These measures again reflect the Government's resolve to limit abuse of the scheme and to reduce its cost to the Budget.

In recognition of the potential for considerable export earnings, education and hospital and medical services are to be added to the list of services eligible for grants under the scheme. As the cost of defending patents can be extremely high, insurance premiums paid in protecting Australian patents, registered designs or trademarks overseas and copyrights open to infringement outside Australia will also be eligible.

Several technical and administrative amendments will be made to the scheme to improve its operation and to limit abuse. In particular, section 38 is to be substantially strengthened following close examination by the Export Development Grants Board and my Department, to curtail abuse and manipulation of the scheme. A decision of the Adminstrative Appeals Tribunal in 1984 highlighted problems with the interpretation of the section as it now stands. In the amended section, the Board will be clearly given the power to adjust grant entitlements where claimants, to obtain a larger grant, have taken action to re-arrange their affairs in a way that is not in accordance with the spirit of the legislation. The Export Development Grants Board will be empowered to collect statistical information necessary to evaluate the effectiveness of the scheme, as recommended by the Ferris Report.

Provision is also made for the Government to act quickly to deny the granting of export incentives in cases where it is decided to take economic measures against a particular country, in the context of, for example, international action arising from a United Nations Security Council resolution. This provision will be used to give effect to the Government's decision announced by my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) on 19 August to terminate the EMDG facility in respect of majority owned South African firms. The termination of the EMDG facility for these firms is to take effect from 19 August. Grant entitlements up to that date would, or course, be honoured. Bona fide contractual arrangements entered into before the exclusion date but acquitted after this date would also be honoured. Other elements of the existing scheme are not being changed.

Given identification of major shortcomings with the existing scheme, urgent remedial action was obviously required. The Government therefore took the view that the 1984-85 grant year-for which grants are determined on the basis of the old scheme-should be terminated on 19 May 1985 to enable the amended scheme to come into effect on 20 May. Early implementation was also necessary if the Government was to make some cost savings in the 1985-86 financial year. This is because the cost of the EMDG scheme to the Budget in any fiscal year relates to expenditure by exporters in the preceding fiscal year. To have provided a greater period of notice for changes to the scheme by, say, not making them effective until the 1985-86 grant year, would mean that resultant Budget savings would not be made until the 1986-87 fiscal year. Notice of the date of implementation was given by the Treasurer in his economic statement on 14 May.

Other factors considered relevant in introducing the changes as from 20 May 1985 were the long period over which exporters were aware that the Government was reviewing the scheme and the scope for expenditure to increase markedly during any lengthy period of notice of changes to the scheme. The Government has, however, accepted that, in some cases, the early termination of the 1984-85 grant year could pose particular problems for those claimants who were relying on a full 12 months grant year to satisfy the old export performance test, and the Bill makes appropriate provision for exports between 20 May and 30 June 1985 to be taken into account in such cases. The Government sees the amended scheme as maintaining a worthwhile level of assistance to committed smaller to medium sized firms in a more cost-effective and measurable way, and at the same time contributing to its efforts to restrain spending and reduce the Budget deficit. The Government estimates that, in its first full year of operation, the amended scheme will result in cost savings of approximately $80m. This is notwithstanding the eligibility of new types of services and costs under the scheme which is estimated to cost approximately $1.6m per year.

I would emphasise that in developing the proposals to amend the EMDG scheme the Government, after extensive analysis, has very carefully selected the main elements such as the $20m cut-off point on export earnings, the $5,000 minimum eligible expenditure test and the export earnings test. This has been done in order to produce a balanced package, which will best address the identified shortcomings in the scheme and effectively allocate the Government's assistance to the export sector, via the scheme, consistent with its intention to reduce spending and control the deficit.

Honourable members will be aware of the Government's decision to establish an Australian Trade Commission from 1 January 1986. The Commission will have a senior part time Board drawn from the private sector and a Managing Director, a position open to anyone from the community. It will provide exporters with the full range of advice and assistance but in a more consolidated and co-ordinated fashion. As such the Commission will encourage a more efficient and targetted approach to Australia's export effort.

A separate Bill to establish the Commission will be presented later in this session. The Commission will assume the responsibilities, functions and powers of the Export Development Grants Board and administer the EMDG scheme as amended by Parliament. However, given the need for urgent amendment of the EMDG scheme so that processing of EMDG claims for the 1984-85 grant year can proceed, the Government is proposing that the EMDG Act should first be amended to give effect to these changes. The Bill now before the House seeks to do this.

In conclusion, I would emphasis the importance the Government attaches to prompt passage of the legislation which, as I have indicated, forms part of the package of cost savings announced by the Treasurer in his May economic statement. I commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr McVeigh) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day when a government of any political persuasion must move to deregister a trade union. Deregistration is and should be a last resort, one made only in exceptional circumstances, because the deregistration of a trade union can have a very great effect in the labour market. The Builders Labourers Federation, however, has ceased to have the proper and decent hallmarks of trade unionism about it and has become a body whose actions are dictated by people who will resort and have resorted to tactics not befitting the name of unionism in any way. The BLF is guilty of violence, damage to property, interruption of concrete pours and intimidation of fellow workers as well as employers to achieve different objectives. The BLF tactics have extended to action against parties not directly involved in the industry, and against other unions. Indeed, members of the Builders Labourers Federation have occupied buildings of insurance companies, private organisations and, on at least one occasion, the premises of another trade union. They have engaged in violent demonstrations and have threatened and physically assaulted fellow trade unionists.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to go over ground already covered in this debate by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), but suffice it for me to say that the Builders Labourers Federation is now, without exception, a body in the history of trade unionism of this country which is being spurned and shunned by the rest of the trade union movement. It has been expelled now for the second time from the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council. The BLF has well and truly finished its last chance dance.

Earlier today we heard the usual rhetoric from the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack)-always short on detail, long on rhetoric. We also heard the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) criticising the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). Let me say at the outset that it is not the Government that is on trial here for any level of competency in regard to the deregistration and handling of the BLF. The Building Industry Bill is precise, accurately targeted and will be rapid in its resolution. What is on trial here is the drift and indecision-the Leader of the Opposition so readily uses that term-and the administrative incompetence of those opposite in industrial relations, particularly the then Minister for Industrial Relations in 1981, the current Leader of the Opposition. At the outset I remind him that the Australian Labor Party has been in government for little over two years. I also remind him that the recent history of the BLF, beginning in 1974 with its various violent activities, its recourse to industrial practices not seen in regard to other unions, and right up to the period of 1981, when he first moved for the deregistration of the BLF, covered seven years, during which time almost exclusively there was a Liberal-National Party coalition government, If we have been lax or untimely in our role in relation to the BLF, what does he say about his own Party in government and himself? Let us explore it.

While I am on the subject, I remind the Leader of the Opposition that in 1976 the BLF reregistered. What did he have to say about it then? I can find nothing on the record about that. In particular, I want all those builders out there in the electorate, in my electorate of Barton and everywhere else, who are traditional Liberal voters, and I want all the unionists in the afflicted areas in relation to the BLF across the country, and anyone else who requires decency, firmness and a bit of guts in industrial relations, to compare the stark contrast of Andrew's ambivalence and the Hawke Government's resolve on this question.

On 17 February 1981, the then Minister, the honourable member for Kooyong, took the matter to the Federal Cabinet seeking, pursuant to section 143 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the cancellation of the registration of the BLF. It is interesting that a statement of claim contained over 800 particulars when it came before the trial pleadings, pleadings that were an arduous and tedious process. When the applicants were required to provide further and better particulars, they were required to assemble detailed information about hundreds of incidents on sites all over Australia. That is the kick-off that we had under Andrew Peacock, and let us explore that a little further.

When the deregistration proceedings finally commenced in Melbourne on 8 November 1982, those proceedings having been instituted fully 14 months before then and decided upon by the Federal Cabinet, at the then Minister's behest, 21 months before then. So, after nearly two years of deciding to take action against the BLF, Andrew Peacock, the great industrial warrior who had the hide to come here and criticise us today, managed to get the whole thing kicked off-after two years. It is a joke. And he wants to talk about us being slow. He was the slowest of the slow. His legislation had little chance of achieving a lasting settlement. It was ill prepared; it was without popular support; and it was without any agreement whatsoever among the union movement. With all of that in mind, the undue haste that the honourable member for Kooyong, the Leader of the Opposition as he is now, brought to industrial relations in this country and the BLF at that time, in 1981, resulted in one thing, and one thing only: Andrew Peacock managed to unite the whole of the union movement behind the BLF and he managed to make Norm Gallagher a martyr, and thus we have the present situation. It is the shoulders of Andrew Peacock upon which sits the responsibility for the delay in tackling the BLF. Indeed, his legislation involved no adequate consultation with employers who were, as they said at the time, placed in a no win situation. That was their judgment, not ours.

Indeed, we can turn to the Australian Financial Review of 16 September 1981 and an article headed, `Viner bids to erode Peacock's credibility with backbenchers'. I say to my colleagues on this side of the House that at that stage Andrew was involved in yet another internal faction fight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that he should be referring to the Leader of the Opposition as the Leader of `the Opposition'.

—The Leader of the Opposition, the Minister as he then was, was involved in yet another faction fight inside his own Party; but that is by the by. But this is what the article had to say about the unpreparedness of Andrew Peacock's resolve as regards the BLF:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, attacked his predecessor, Mr Peacock, yesterday for being unprepared to proceed with the deregistration of the Builders Labourers' Federation at the time he resigned from Cabinet. Mr Viner told Parliament that when he became minister on April 16 this year the case was in a `state of unpreparedness'.

That is the Leader of the Opposition, mark 1. Then, of course, there is what the industry itself had to say. I refer to the transcript of PM of 17 September, the day after, and explicitly to the remarks of Mr Ken Lovell, the Director of the National Industrial Executive of the building and construction industry. This is what he had to say about the preparedness of the then Government, the then Minister, who had just resigned, and the deregistration proceedings in regard to the BLF:

But the actions that they have taken over the last eight months, often without proper consulation with the industry, mean that really we will have to look at the situation when they decide to seek the application-deregistration.
He went on to say:
But it is a matter of continuing concern that decisions, for example, to defer the deregistration application are taken without consultation with the industry.

It will be noted that he says `over the last eight months', and that was late in September 1981. For a significant period of that eight months, dating back from September 1981, the then Minister, the only person to whom Mr Lovell could have been referring, was the present Leader of the Opposition. Yet he has the unbelievable gall to come in here today and criticise us. The reality is that the honourable member for Kooyong then attempted to shift the blame for his parlous record as the Minister responsible in this matter, and on 23 September he abstained from a motion of no confidence in the Minister who followed him, the then honourable member for Stirling. This circus that they called action continued, with Viner ultimately releasing the name of the Costain building company, causing the Melbourne Age of 18 September to report in its headline: `Gaffe makes builders wary of BLF case'. The article, by two journalists, said:

The building industry might withdraw its support for the Federal Government's deregistration case against the Builders' Labourers Federation because of a gaffe by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner . . .
Mr Lovell is reported in this article to have said:
Employers in future will have to make their decisions after seeing what the Government has actually done, not on the basis of its announced intentions.

So I suggest that before the Leader of the Opposition comes in here and criticises us over the BLF deregistration proceedings he should have a good hard look at the mess in which he left the proceedings when he resigned from the Cabinet and how his own Party carried on from there. Members of the Opposition still have not learnt about the realities. They are still talking without having any concrete proposition for action. The Australian of 24 September 1981 provides the final indictment of just how prepared the then Liberal Government was in the matter of the BLF. Under the headline `Case to proceed tomorrow despite departmental advice', it said:

The Federal Government is to begin attempts tomorrow to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation-even though the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, was told by his department in mid-July that employers' support for the case was near collapse.

The article then referred to a confidential minute to the then Minister, Mr Viner, which revealed that as recently as two months before the Federal Government had been without evidence of BLF activities at the Loy Yang power station. Honourable members will recall that that was one of the most prominent sources of industrial disputation involving the BLF, yet the Government could not get even that right. What an unbelievable indictment. On the same day, on the AM radio program, Gallagher claimed to all the world that he had a complete list of builders who had co-operated with the Government to deregister the BLF. What a farce; what a mess. Yet, as I have said, the Leader of the Opposition has the unbelievable gall to come in here and criticise us.

The wash up of all this is that the supporters of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on the other side of the House must be experiencing deja vu. The honourable member for Kooyong was then unable to keep his ministerial duties up to scratch and attempted to shift the blame. How often have we seen in this Parliament blame shifted to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition? The AustralianFinancial Review of 2 December 1981 provides the best conclusion to the mess that went on through that year, having started with the now Leader of the Opposition. Under the headline proclaiming `High Court told BLF hearings could run for years', the article stated:

The High Court was given an indication yesterday of the extraordinary political, legal and constitutional ramifications of the continuing battle between the Builders Labourers Federation and the Federal and Victorian Governments.
The court was told by the Victorian Solicitor-General, Mr D. Dawson QC, that the Federal Court hearings aimed at having the BLF de-registered could go on for `years rather than months'.

That is the mess those opposite left. Yet they ask why this Government terminated the deregistration proceedings in 1983. I should have thought that the answer was perfectly simple. The Leader of the Opposition had managed to turn the deregistration proceedings into a saga longer than War and Peace. He had managed to unite every trade union behind the BLF and he had managed to make Norm Gallagher a martyr. That was not a bad effort. He managed to kick off that whole process, and was followed in his exhortations by his colleagues. It is little wonder that in May 1983 we attempted to reach an agreement, including the famed moratorium, with the employers. I need to remind those opposite that in the first half of 1984 the employers still recognised the problems with deregistration and were still hedging around it. It is a final indictment of the Liberal Party and the criticisms its members are making in this House today that the employers withdrew from the deregistration proceedings in June 1984. The honourable member for Tangney forgot to mention that. He also forgot to mention the secret meeting between the BLF and the Master Builders Association in September. The MBA was still pursuing the Government's no deregistration course as late as September, and it had the agreement signed. That is the reality of the discontinuation of the deregistration process. It had been botched up to such a degree that it was unworkable.

The Bill before the House has an expeditious, fast-track solution aimed at what is ultimately a problem in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory. It provides the opportunity for other unions to take coverage. So unlike the previous Liberal Party deregistration proceedings, these proceedings will actually hurt the BLF, stop the BLF, rather than repair it and help it to grow. That was the effect of the coalition's deregistration proceedings. It seems to me that the Leader of the Opposition did not read the Bill before he made his contribution today because he went so far as to say that it does not provide any means by which other unions-he mentioned the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia and the Australian Workers Union-can take coverage. That provision is in the Bill, and I suggest that he and his staff read the Bill before they criticise the Government for something that they know very little about and in which they have a poor track record. Most importantly, this Bill makes sure that the proceedings go before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. History will see that there was an impartial judge; not the lynching of a union but rather collective action before the appropriate industrial body by the governments of Australia, Victoria and New South Wales and the community as a whole against a union that now can be regarded only as the Libya of Australian industrial relations.

A number of final points have to be made. We are presently seeing in this country a widespread rhetorical attack from the Liberal Party on the parameters of trade unionism. This is despite real unit labour costs now being back to 1966 levels, it is despite the lowest rate of strikes in 17 years, and it is despite three years of growth in gross domestic product of 4 to 5 per cent. It has to be said in this House this afternoon-I challenge those opposite to hear this and to heed it-that the Labor movement, the Labor Party in government in New South Wales, Victoria and Australia, and the trade union movement, has shown itself to be prepared to cleanse itself of the bad apple in its barrel. This is in stark contrast to those opposite, who continue to hide and apologise for the bad apples in their barrels-the tax avoiders, the corporate crooks, the people we have tried repeatedly to bring to justice and whom their Senate members have protected. Our action in this situation is in stark contrast to that. In the context of the prices and incomes accord, it remains to be said that the Liberals not only still have no framework for a wages policy but also that they can now be seen to have no policy on industrial and political morality. I suggest that they re-examine themselves, and do it very soon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The union movement has to decide whether it is prepared to argue for a system in which there are no effective santions against industrial activity, however outrageous. Would the trade union movement propose supporting a system where anything goes? If that question is answered in the affirmative, there is little doubt that the very existence of the trade union movement could be threatened. `If the lack of penalties encourages the irresponsible use of industrial power, then widespread community support for the type of action seen in Queensland will result'. Those are not my words; they were attributed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in an article in the Australian on 13 August 1985, wherein he pointed out the inevitable consequences of the use of union power without responsibility. This, of course, was supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in debate earlier today. We certainly hope that he gets support from the Australian Council of Trade Unions in this move.

SPEECH.PARA: The Builders Labourers Federation has set its sights on power-absolute power to act in whichever way it has a desire to act, regardless of the legality or morality of its actions. This extremism is demonstrated by the BLF's attitude to industrial relations: `Give us what we want or you will suffer'. The history of this union's blatant disregard of accepted principles bears testimony to its warped attitude. The cause of industrial relations problems is not necessarily that one of the parties involved is a union. Causality is often the existence of a workplace problem. Events do not happen in a vacuum but occur in response to changing circumstances in the overall industrial environment. I should qualify that by saying `usually' or `normally'. That qualification is necessary when discussing or debating industrial relations and the BLF's role in the workplace. If there is no problem the BLF will create one. It is not interested in the welfare of the workers. I repeat: It is not interested in the welfare of the workers. Union power and standover tactics-that is what it is all about. As the Prime Minister himself said today, it is about anarchy in the workplace.

The nature of the employment relationship dictates that the economic context will probably always be of considerable importance. It is more than the division of wages and profits, because the relative bargaining power fluctuates with variations in the state of the economy and often the economic conditions in specified industries. Macroeconomic impacts are most often emphasised, however, in practice and of greater importance to the determination of workplace rules are microeconomic factors.

The BLF has a reputation-I might add, a bad reputation-for perpetrating costly, ill-conceived, unwarranted disruption on building sites. One of its tactics-just one of many-is to time the strike when the employer is facing contractual penalties for late completion or perhaps financial loss because of some commitment to take delivery of or to instal certain equipment. Whether this action is in response to a workplace problem or merely to gain an additional site allowance is irrelevant to the BLF. The attitude of Australian society will be extremely important in shaping the new nature of this country's industrial relations.

The overwhelming support for the Queensland Government's action in handling the power dispute has demonstrated that power without responsibility will not be the prerogative of the BLF union bosses and that Australian society has had enough. Unions are creatures of legal and administrative processes in Australia rather than the outgrowth of protracted worker struggles. The enactment of the Federal Conciliation and Arbitration Act of 1904 saw the re-emergence of unions under the sponsorship of the various arbitral and conciliation bodies subsequently spawned. Employers were forced to recognise unions and unions were readily recognised by the arbitral machinery. Government regulations, through a form of compulsory arbitration, was seen by our founding fathers and unionists as a sensible means of overcoming labour's bargaining inadequacies with management. Alfred Deakin said:

We can now substitute a new regime for the reign of violence by endowing the State with power to impose, within the limits of reason justice and constitutional government, its deliberate will upon the parties to industrial dispute.

Of course, the BLF is not interested in the eradication of a reign of violence. If that happened, what would it do with all its baseball bats? With what would it be able to substitute its baseball diplomacy? I read in the Courier-Mail in June this year that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) said that he did not want his supposed housing-led recovery jeopardised by the nonsense and bastardisation that have been carried out by the BLF. The Minister is nothing if not an optimist if judged by his subsequent appeal to the union to show a little consensus and industrial decency.

Inter-union co-operation in bans has been a feature of Australian unionism which is to be expected of a class-oriented organisation. However, this bond of comradeship and support has been broken by the unilateral action taken by this renegade union which has caused disruption and harm to the nation, the employers and the members of the unions employed at the workplace. The call for fraternal support of other unions is now going unheeded and has been replaced by enmity, which had been transcended previously by strong traditions.

For the BLF there are no rules of the workplace. Rules suggest a code of behaviour predictable within recognised and defined limits. If anyone should claim that the BLF abides by the rules, the boundaries could only be without definition and without limit. Actual industrial action is not represented by Australian Bureau of Statistics figures showing the number of days lost through strikes. The damage caused by BLF action in the middle of a concrete pour by imposing lightning bans is never documented in statistics, but the employer suffers greatly, just as he would from strike action. Guerilla tactics are the BLF's forte. Statistics can be the tool of those trying to demonstrate that all is well in the workplace.

This Building Industry Bill is not an attack on unionism per se, but an attempt to remove legislatively a malignant growth which is affecting all responsible unionists through irresponsible action. Last year the President of the ACTU issued a last chance warning to the BLF. It is laughable that he should issue a further last chance warning this year. When is last really last? The latest episode with this maverick union engenders a sense of deja vu as we see the previously threatened courses of action being trotted out yet again. If credibility means anything like the dictionary definition, this must be the time to sort out the mess once and for all. The cry `It is time' has more relevance in this issue than it has had at any other time. The forces seeking change must be united because this is not a time to be wimpish. Division within government ranks must not be the excuse for retreat. It is not the time to back off. Divine intervention will not eliminate factions. Whilst a firm hand is required, I must emphasise that it needs to be the right hand.

The recent decision by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to pass on the 2.6 per cent national wage rise, which followed the Victorian Government's decision to back the BLF in a trade-off for its lifting bans on government works, is indicative of a weakness which the Australian elector will not tolerate. The Nunawading by-election outcome surely indicates that firmness and consistency are a desired quality of government. It is to be hoped that these same qualities are demonstrated by employer groups and individual employers. The nation asks: How long can public and private funds be squandered as a consequence of the costly delays brought about by stoppages, bans and similar tactics?

The history of the BLF's activities over the last 10 to 15 years, as outlined by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in his second reading speech, portrays a picture of almost unbelievable chicanery and ruthlessness. The Minister hoped that the Bill would be dealt with expeditiously. I believe that I speak for all honourable members on this side of the House when I say that it is hoped that the speed with which the legislation is passed is matched with an even quicker use of the powers contained therein. On the question of powers, we expect that the impartial consideration by the Commission, as outlined in clause 4 of the Bill, will be undertaken without undue delay, as is indicated in sub-clause (6) of the aforementioned clause, and not, as has been reported in the Australian on 24 July 1985, that `the whole process could take up to 12 months'. The question must be asked: What if the Commission is not satisfied that the BLF engaged in action that was in contravention of or inconsistent with the intent of those undertakings and agreements listed in clause 4? The vote from this side of the House is for the Government to act to solve the problems it acknowledges are caused by the BLF's most harm to the boss attitude and actions. We are not voting to give the Commission the chance to overrule the Parliament.

The legislative system of industrial relations is compulsory in two senses. An arbitration decision in the form of an award is binding on the employer and employees covered by it. The more significant aspect is that either the employer or the trade union can legally compel the other to deal with issues of common concern through arbitration by submitting such issues to the appropriate authority. How far does this compulsion extend? As far as the BLF is concerned, it appears that it can flout the orders ad nauseum, having only to back off periodically when the heat is too much and then revert to its former course after a short period. Deregistration, by depriving the union of certain advantages, such as access to tribunals, gift of incorporation, competence to sue members in ordinary courts, and a degree of protection against the emergence of competition due to the practice that registration is not automatically granted, will, under this Bill, be a somewhat restricted option.

I refer to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I refer in particular to section 143 (1), which provides that any organisation namely, one registered pursuant to the Act or person interested, the Minister or the Registrar may apply to the court for an order directing the cancellation of the registration of an organisation. Clause 5 of the Bill before the House restricts the opportunity to act upon the Commission's declaration under clause 4 to the Minister only and denies the other parties referred to in section 143 (1) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act the ability to initiate action in their own right. We have the situation now where there is no requirement of the Minister to apply to the Commission for a declaration. Given that such an application is subsequently made and a declaration is then forthcoming, it is left again to the Minister to direct the registrar to cancel the BLF's registration. I am concerned with the extent of ministerial discretion in the present climate, with the President of the ACTU voicing the opinion that the BLF should be given another chance, as well as seeking the passing on of the 2.6 per cent wage rise. Both points have been mentioned earlier.
I turn to the second reading speech of the Minister for Employment and Industrial relations. He stated:

Its objective is to provide machinery for the cancellation of the registration of the Builders Labourers Federation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or to provide for the effective equivalent of such deregistration in parts of Australia.

Given the Government's past record, I suggest that honourable members on this side of the House will have to crank that machinery continuously and relentlessely to ensure that it is implemented. He continued:
The Federation has around 35 000 members in non-residential construction, with almost 70 per cent of them employed in the industry in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory.

It is a pity that the more principled State branches may have to suffer the consequences which were not of their making but were of the making of the members of their union in the States of New South Wales and Victoria and in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister continues:
Further, it-
that is the Federation-
has broken numerous undertakings as to its conduct given to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Industrial Registrar and the Federal Court of Australia.
I suggest that this Bill is only the opening skirmish with the major conflict to follow. It will be interesting to see on what side of the line the Government's factions enter the battle.

This Bill seeks to deregister a union. Other industrial actions have been taken by unions which should be brought to the notice of this House. I refer to how the Australian community as a whole suffered heavy losses as a result of the last Commonwealth Public Service strike, led by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. Its claim for an 8 per cent salary rise for public servants was outside the prices and incomes accord. The method then used by the strikers was to cut off the flow of millions of dollars to the Federal Government, which cost the Australian taxpayers some $18m in interest alone during the period of those industrial actions.

Earlier in the year vital coal shipments to Japan were held up and more than 20 vessels were kept at anchor in New South Wales harbours as a result of a railway strike, not a coal strike, over a manning issue. The union's claim was repudiated by all relevant arbitral authorities and was condemned even by the Labor Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran. Mines were closed and mining jobs were lost. I believe that the time has come for this House to take note of the great concerns of the people of Australia who have been faced with continuing disruptions to their lives and in the workplace. They have said that they have had enough. I believe that the Bill which has been introduced in the Parliament by the Government to take action against the Builders Labourers Federation is a first step to bring to the notice of those unions that wish to go into disputation on points which are really irrelevant to the manner in which their workers are employed that this Government, supported by the Opposition parties, will implement the powers which are given to it under this Bill, even though a lot of the power is being given to the Minister himself. I believe that the Government should act, and act with haste, because the people of Australia want to see the Government taking a responsible attitude in regard to the actions of militant union leaders who have caused such disruption in the Australian workplace.

I remind this House that surveys taken show that the union members can see that what they are being asked to do by their union bosses is such that their livelihood is being threatened by these actions. There have been numerous indications of this in the Queensland power dispute. We have had situations where union has been pitted against union because one union has been called out on strike and disrupts the working practices of other unions. In my own electorate of Hinkler, there was a situation in Gladstone where the power house unions were called out. I remind honourable members that there is an alumina plant in Gladstone. If those smelters are kept without power for up to four hours the smelters could be out of operation totally for up to four years. The members of a union who work at the power house and the members of the union who work in the smelter live side by side in an urban environment, their children go to school together and their wives attend social activities together. There would have been a very detrimental situation in that city if the power union workers had held out for more than four hours and placed the lives and aspirations of those smelter workers in such a perilous situation.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Blanchard) Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Building Industry Bill, as many previous speakers have said, is quite significant legislation. I would like to begin by directing some remarks to members of the Opposition-the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest), who has just resumed his seat, and others. One of the dilemmas that Opposition members face because of their attitude to industrial relations is that they tend to see all unions and all unionists as being troublemakers and likely to disrupt the economy. This was demonstrated when they last, lamentably, held government. They were unable at that time to show that one of the ways to handle industrial relations is to get the support of the broad base of the union movememt for one's actions. Then, having achieved that support, one is able to identify those unions which are acting in a way that is not in the best interests of the community. The difficulty that our predecessors faced was that they treated all sections of the entire union movement as if they were troublemakers. They treated the members of the Australian community as if they were troublemakers. That is no substantial way to establish an industrial relations policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem that honourable members opposite face is that behind their attitude towards industrial relations is still the mentality of a jackboot. Until they are able to resolve that in their own minds and until they are able to depart from that as an option in terms of industrial relations, they will have that difficulty. I do not know how we on this side can possibly teach honourable members opposite that intolerant behaviour begets intolerant behaviour. Honourable members opposite still seem to think that the likes of Mr Bjelke-Petersen represent the high point of Australian industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Joh.

—Honourable members opposite might bleat about Sir Joh. We do not. We refer to him as Mr Bjelke-Petersen and we will continue to do so. As far as the attitude to industrial relations of honourable members opposite is concerned, they just do not have it right yet. I thought they would have learned from having been sent to the cold areas of opposition. However, they still do not have it right. They still seem to see all unionists out there as troublemakers and all unions as likely to cause trouble. We are a little more mature in our understanding of Australian society. Australian society is not like that. It is very mixed. There are troublemakers. We are dealing in this legislation with a union that is regarded as being substantially a troublesome union. However, we also suggest to the Opposition that the rest of the Australian union movement has the capacity to act within the accord and to deal with its membership and activities in a way that we would regard as being responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members opposite do not regard that claim as being substantial, they should look at the figures on working time lost when they occupied the Government benches and since we have occupied the Government benches. They will find that the change is quite remarkable. That change is substantial evidence that the approach of honourable members opposite to industrial relations does not work. It is the approach of the arsonist. If they see a fire, they throw petrol on it. Commonsense communities do not do that. Honourable members opposite can make their own decisions as to whether they are commonsensical. The Australian electorate has done that twice. I say to the Opposition: Adopt a more mature approach to industrial relations.

I also suggest that when honourable members become a little agitated about time lost with respect to the BLF they should also consider time lost in all the industrial disputes that occurred when they were in government when unemployment grew so rapidly. Neither of those indices casts any favourable light upon honourable members opposite. In fact, they present them in the light of being incompetent managers. While they are trumpeting John Stone around the country and forecasting clouds of gloom with him, they might remember that he was one of the fellow vandals in respect of the Australian economy. The Australian community has not forgotten. I do not think honourable members opposite should forget either.

This Bill is about reducing industrial relations to a sensible state of affairs. It is about identifying the activities of the Builders Labourers Federation. Its objective, as previous speakers have said, is to provide machinery for the cancellation of the registration of the BLF. We recognise that. We also recognise that that has to be undertaken with the support of the union movement, the community and the employers. One notes that the terms-that is, getting support-are rather significant. I note that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest) said that he was a little doubtful as to whether the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was the right arena in which this decision should be made. We have no worries about that. We have been long time supporters of the role of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commisssion. However, we know that the Opposition's real agenda is to dismantle the Commission. Let it go ahead and try it on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear hear!

—You see, Madam Deputy Speaker; Opposition members are the same old bunch of arsonists. They see a fire and they cannot help themselves. They have to begin to identify a serious situation. The serious situation is that they are not able to produce any normality in industrial relations. We are prepared to accept the role of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission because we accept its role as an umpire in disputes and as a setter of standards in industrial relations. However, we are also prepared to say that when we see an area of trouble in industrial relations we are prepared to deal with it. This legislation does that.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a lot of testimony to the difficulties that the BLF has created in terms of industrial relations. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has spoken about that in his second reading speech. It is necessary for me to identify four areas in talking about the objective of the Bill; that is, why it is necessary to proceed to establish machinery to deregister the BLF and what reasons we might adduce for that. First, there is the breach of the undertakings that the BLF made to the Federal Government, to fellow unions, to employers and to the Federal Court of Australia in May 1983. When we came into Government we had a major amount of damage to repair in industrial relations as well as in the economy. We felt that it was appropriate to say to the union movement generally and to employers: `We would like you to get some agreement about the establishment of an accord for industrial practice'. We did that. The BLF was a party to that agreement. It was a party to those negotiations. It said then that it would engage in good conduct in industrial relations. It breached that agreement.

Secondly, we turn to the breach of the undertakings to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. In national wage cases the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission argues that parties to those proceedings must engage in substantial compliance with the guidelines of the Commission. Substantial compliance requires that unions and employers must show that they have not engaged in unfair and unnecessary industrial action during that period. It is necessary for parties to a national wage case who are seeking increases in wages to be able to say: `Our conduct has been such that we earn this increase in the national wage'. In 1983 the BLF again said that it was prepared to behave itself to earn that increase in the national wage. Again, it breached that undertaking. That was the second major breach of undertakings.

The third major factor was the breach of undertakings to the Federal Government in December 1983 with respect to deregistration. As the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) who preceded me on the Government side said, the previous Government had commenced deregistration proceedings against the BLF. Those proceedings were bound to be long and drawn out. However, at the same time they were also remixed proceedings because the previous honourable member for Stirling who was at one stage the Minister for Industrial Relations had great difficulty in pursuing those actions. I will not pursue that argument further because he is not in a position to respond, not being in the House. However, it is important to observe that there was then a great deal of confusion both with the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who was at one stage the Minister for Industrial Relations, and the then honourable member for Stirling over what was the appropriate procedure. When we came into government we said to the BLF in the discussions of May 1983: `We are prepared to look at the question of deregistration'. We did that in December 1983. We said: `We will not proceed down that path involving the Federal Court because we believe that there is another way to proceed in industrial relations'. The undertakings the BLF gave to us then were breached again. That was the third breach.

The fourth breach was the breach of undertakings to employers in July 1984 when again, in the context of the negotiation of a superannuation package and good conduct arrangements on sites, the BLF, along with other unions who were party to those negotiations, said that it was prepared to engage in good conduct in industrial relations. It did not. It breached that undertaking. In our view as a government, and in my view, that consistent failure to engage in fair dealing and good conduct in industrial relations warrants some extra action. The extra action is that to which I have referred, that is, to establish machinery to provide for the deregistration of the BLF.

I believe that it is important to describe very briefly the significance of the building industry in this country and what a strategic location the BLF occupies within it. Since we have been in government we have recognised that in general both the housing and construction components of the building industry have been substantial employers. We have set about restoring them to economic prosperity. Our performance in terms of the Budget has been significant. We could talk about the first home owners scheme in the private sector of activity. We could talk about the admirable contribution to public housing by the State governments, particularly in Western Australia. One of the reasons the housing sector has been so successful is that the BLF has not been able to get in on the sites and enrol workers. That is why most of the jobs on building sites-that is, cottage construction-have been able to proceed without the disruption that has been characteristic of the construction industry.

Sadly, our budgetary commitments in terms of the construction industry have been let down by the BLF. Let me give honourable members an indication. In the period from May 1984 to May 1985 there has been an increase of 52,000 employed in the construction industry in this country, an increase of 11.9 per cent. That increase shows not only the gross fixed capital expenditure commitment of the private sector but also the capital outlays expended by the Government. We were prepared to invest money to ensure that those industries are restored. In that climate, the BLF has been engaged in some of the worst behaviour that one could imagine. That is just not on for the Government.

Under the prices and incomes accord we are doing something about increasing employment. At the same time we are doing something for the housing sector and we are improving capital arrangements in the economy. If a union in a key place in an industry is not prepared to play its part and say `let us make sure the jobs keep going', we will be left with very few options. The BLF has refused to accept the jurisdiction of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It has refused to accept the normal procedures relating to conduct on building sites. It has refused to accept what would be regarded as civilised behaviour by the union movement, employers, its own members on building sites and, certainly, the community at large. All the evidence is there-I could go through it, but I will not-that the union was prepared to do a number of things, ranging from taxes on fellow unionists, employers and other organisations in society to general random behaviour. We would be wrong as a government if we were to say: `Let us turn a blind eye to that behaviour and let us say that it is not happening'. We are saying that we believe that such actions cannot be condoned and that they need to be dealt with very firmly.

Whilst I am on this topic, I shall make one other observation. I am talking about the situation that faces the Government. The Government believes that by establishing growth in the public sector it will be in a position to restore economic health. It has achieved growth in the last two Budgets and the hope now is that the Budget that was presented last night by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will get private fixed capital expenditure going. I can go through the evidence to justify that hope; it is in the Budget Papers. These aims are just too crucial for us as members of this society to allow the actions of the BLF to affect such developments.

Let me give honourable members two examples. The Budget proposes expenditure on airports around Australia such as Perth Airport in my State of Western Australia, Canberra Airport-dear me, that is necessary-Townsville Airport, and so on. At the moment work on those airports can be delayed by the whims of the BLF. The Government is committed also to the expenditure of $15.5m on a court complex at Parramatta. Honourable members will note again that that is a strategic area of expenditure and the BLF is strategically placed to disrupt that expenditure. That proposed development will result in jobs, prosperity for the contractors who are working on those jobs and prosperity for the surrounding community. We hold the view that it is just not satisfactory to allow such developments to be disrupted in a cavalier way, and the evidence is that that is what the BLF is prepared to do.

I agree fully with a previous speaker from the other side of the House who said that when the heat is on the members of BLF start to behave themselves and when the heat is off they misbehave. I think that the community accepts that argument. The testimony is there. That is why it is necessary for us to proceed in the proposed manner.

One instance which I find particularly disturbing relates to Western Australia. It is important to put this on the record, because many members of the BLF are not aware of this. The rules of that union require that, if one is working as a builder's labourer in the construction industry, one must give written notice when one leaves the industry. It is fair to say that some members of the union who are working as builders' labourers are not people who normally write many letters; in fact some of them are relatively unskilled in writing and producing written documents. Obviously it does happen that, when some members leave the industry, they fail to notify the union. The union has been pursuing those members and collecting unpaid dues which those members were not aware they had to pay. The union not only has been using its own members to collect that money, but also has been using professional debt collectors. I know of no other union in Australia which, when a member leaves the industry and goes off to another occupation, which is quite a natural thing in anyone's working life, pursues that former member with that degree of grudging victimisation as has the BLF. That is inexcusable. Many people have said: `It is behaving like a union; it is looking after its members'. True, there is such evidence, but there is more evidence to show that its behaviour towards fellow unionists in other unions and former members of its own union is absolutely contemptible. We have to say that this legislation is about behaviour that we as members of a civilised society are not prepared to accept. Let us not forget that we are dealing with a union whose conduct is not the same as that of the Australian union movement in general. We should be aware of that fact.

I say to members of the Opposition that, before they come in here and get terribly excited about militant unionism, they should realise that we can show up one union's misconduct only if the rest of the union movement is behaving. We have achieved that. Before any member of the Opposition gets terribly excited about all these terrible unions, I say that we must achieve a calm sea; only then can we see where the ripples are. We have achieved that. The trouble is that before we came into government there was an absolute tidal wave of trouble; there were industrial disputes right across the industrial spectrum. We have the sea calm and we can now see where the ripple is. Those honourable members of the Opposition who wish to become terribly inflamed in this debate should remember that good conduct in most industrial relations has to be pursued before misconduct can be isolated. That is what we have done. Clause 4 of the Bill provides for that. It deals with an application by the Minister to the Commission.

Despite the whims of some members of the National Party of Australia who might want to display king-hit Joh's mentality with regard to industrial relations, the Government is not going around hitting unionists on the head at any whim. It is saying that, if there is evidence of industrial conduct which it does not agree with, it will say to the Commission: `Will you have a look at that conduct?' If, in the view of the Commission, that conduct is regarded as misconduct in the area of industrial relations, the Commission can proceed to make recommendations.

I shall deal with specifics. Clause 4 lists certain criteria. One relates to compliance. In other words, we have to ask whether a union has engaged in activities which we would regard as not complying with industrial relations. That is not arbitrary behaviour. The Australian community is concerned that, if a government engages in arbitrary behaviour at the ministerial level, such as that which the Queensland Government seems to favour in industrial relations, we shall see the shadows of the 1930s in Germany. We on this side of the House are not talking about arbitrary ministerial behaviour: We are talking about behaviour that is constrained by good conduct; and that is what we are insisting upon. We have to ask whether that conduct is likely to hamper the settlement of a dispute. That is one of the criteria in clause 4. The Commission and the Minister are concerned with the good conduct of industrial relations.

For those who are concerned about the rights of the Federation, importantly, clause 6 provides an opportunity for it to make submissions to the Commission to the effect that its conduct was all fair and above board and that the Commission ought not to proceed with deregistration. A crucial and significant question is that of coverage for union members. Clause 8 of the Bill provides that if deregistration were proceeded with, it would be possible for another union to grant coverage to members of the deregistered union. I say to honourable members opposite that, in talking about a union and union power, they have to deal with the capacity of an organisation, whatever that organisation may be, to organise and to cover its employees. It is not just a case of saying: `Let us deregister a certain union and everything will be fine'. It is a question of asking whether it is possible to establish another organisation that will behave itself in a responsible manner and that will provide coverage for those members.

The Government's approach has been thought through. It is a consistent approach to industrial relations and to dealing with industrial disputes. I conclude by saying that the issue at stake here is established misconduct. That is very clear. It has been recognised by the community, by the employers, by the Commission, by the courts and by this Government, but it is established misconduct in relation to good behaviour in the context of the prices and incomes accord. This Bill will set up important procedures because they will enable us to deal with a major area of misconduct in Australian industrial relations. I believe that, if we proceed with this Bill and if it is successfully carried, it will enable us to further our record in industrial relations. Accordingly, I am pleased to commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I must admit that I feel very sorry for the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). I have heard some good speeches from the honourable member, but I have just listened to a 20 minute speech in which the honourable member for Stirling has done his very best to deceive himself. I feel very sorry that he has adopted such an attitude, because I am quite certain that, in more thoughtful or reflective moments, he would adopt a very much different attitude to this issue from that which he has stated publicly here tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Building Industry Bill relates to the proposed deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation. But the real issue before this House and before the Australian people is not the deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation; the key issue is law and order within the trade union movement.
