The honourable member for Stirling said that we on this side of the House lump all of the trade unions into the one melting pot. That is true. We do put all the trade unions into the same pot, to be consistent and to comply with the laws of the land. We apply the same principle to every citizen and every other organisation in Australia. We say that trade union members, collectively or individually, have no immunity from the laws of the land. Government members have said that the union movement has no immunity from the laws of the land. We on this side of the House will never accept that concept.

I am sorry for the honourable member for Stirling. I have a great personal regard for him, but if he assumes that the Australian Labor Party, in government or opposition, in any party of Australia, does not provide immunity from the law for the trade union movement, clearly he does not know his Party's conference resolutions. I strongly suggest that he read some documentation from his own Party. I remind the honourable member, or any other member on the Government side, of resolutions that were passed at the Federal Conference of the Australian Labor Party in July 1979. I am sure Madam Deputy Speaker would be aware that these resolutions have never been rescinded by the Australian Labor Party. They are still the policy of the Government Party and they are still required by the organisation of the Party to be implemented by the Government. One of the resolutions from the July 1979 Conference states;
An ALP Government would recognise `the rights of unions to regulate their own affairs in a democratic way free from Government and judicial interference...'

That final section-`free from Government and judicial interference'-is the key to what the Government is doing now. It is the key to the whole approach of this Government towards the trade union movement. That is a requirement of the Australian Labor Party on this Government and on State governments as well. The key issue is not simply the deregulation of the Builders Labourers Federation; the key issue is whether trade union members, collectively or individually, should be required to comply with the laws of the land. Clearly, in the case of the Builders Labourers Federation there have been breaches, not only of civil law but also criminal law. I quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) when, referring to the Builders Labourers Federation, he said:
Its resort to industrial blackmail, thuggery, violence and intimidation, has added a further ugly dimension to its activites.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Normie's bunch for you.

—I agree, that is Normie's bunch, and also Mr Black's in New South Wales. Those words are from the Minister himself-`blackmail, thuggery, violence and intimidation'. Those are not just breaches of industrial relations practice, they are breaches of criminal law. Yet what action has this Government taken to enforce the law of the land on this union or any other union? Those matters are not a recent revelation to the Minister or to any other member of the Government. The Winnecke report of the Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation, of which the Minister is aware, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The conduct not only exceeds the bounds of industrial propriety but, in many instances, plainly transgresses the Criminal Law...The result has been to place the B.L.F. in a unique position-a position of being above the law.

The Minister has come in here parading himself as being the upholder of good industrial peace and harmony in this country and has said: `We are going to get tough with the unions and deregister this mob of disruptive people in the Builders Labourers Federation'. What he is doing is trying to put a band-aid over an enormous wound in Australia. If the Minister were fair dinkum in his approach, not only to this disruptive union but also to other unions, he would not attempt such a passive measure as deregulation. He would ensure that the Australian Federal Police investigated all breaches of criminal and civil law that are prepetrated in the name of trade unionism. When have we heard of the Minister, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), or anybody else on the Government side, asking the Federal Police to investigate breaches of the law by the trade union movement? Not once. That is the real test of whether they are fair dinkum about bringing some sort of adherence to the law by the trade union movement.

Members of the Government have come in here with a sop for the Australian people. They have said `We are getting tough with the union movement', when all they are doing is trying to build up their popularity polls. Government members know full well that deregistration of a union does not cause it to cease to exist. They know that the Builders Labourers Federation will still exist. What deregistration will do, in fact, is take away any discipline that is presently on that union to comply with some sort of industrial practice. All they will do is remove any constraints now on the union. They will not make the Builders Labourers Federation comply with the law until they are prepared to have the Federal Police investigate the breaches of criminal and civil law. That will be the test of whether they are fair dinkum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Their membership went up last time they were deregistered.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Denison says, BLF membership did go up in 1975-76 when it was deregistered. Exactly the same thing will happen again because deregistration does not cause a union to cease to exist as a legal body. That is exactly what will happen again, and the Minister knows that it will happen again. The union will be deregistered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, but it will still exist as a body and it will still use the same blackmail and criminal thuggery tactics as it is now without any constraint whatsoever. The constraint will come only if the Minister asks the Federal Police to investigate the union's activities and, if necessary, to press charges in the civil courts. That is where the test will be.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister came in here with all his spurious claims about what he will do to the Builders Labourers Federation and all its breaches, and tried to put across the idea that he is getting tough with the union movement. I cannot use the word `hypocrisy' in this place-I know it is unparliamentary-so I will use the word `inconsistency'. The Minister came in here and pointed out all these transgressions of the Builders Labourers Federation and said: `We are going to get tough; we will deregister them'. I agree that the Builders Labourers Federation has been a very disruptive influence on the trade union movement and on industrial harmony in Australia, but what has the Minister done with the meat workers union at Mudginberri? It committed the same breach of criminal law, yet he condoned that action. If the Minister is to be consistent if he chooses to act against one union for its unreasonable, distruptive tactics, why does he not act against another union? In both cases there have been clean breaches of civil and criminal law. Why does not the Minister ask the Federal Police to take action against both the meat workers union at Mudginberri and the Builders Labourers Federation, or any union that breaches civil and criminal law? That would be the test of whether the Minister is fair dinkum.

As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) pointed out this morning, not only will this union continue to exist as an organisation but also the likelihood is, as the honourable member for Denison said, that the union will increase its membership and its activity. There has not been a commitment by the Australian Workers Union or any other union to recruit the membership of the Builders Labourers Federation. The honourable member for Stirling should not look so stunned. He knows darned well that that is right. That is exactly what happened in 1975. The other unions will refuse to take the membership of the Builders Labourers Federation and its membership will increase. The honourable member knows that to be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie!
—The honourable member for Grayndler will withdraw that comment and keep quiet.
—I did not say that the honourable member for Lyons was a liar, I just said that what I heard was a lie.
—Just withdraw, please.
—I thought the ruling was that you are not allowed to call an individual a liar.
—It is unparliamentary to call out.
—If it is offensive to the honourable member for Lyons, I am quite happy to withdraw it.
—Thank you for protecting me, Madam Deputy Speaker. I must say that I have been insulted by experts and I did not even feel that one.

SPEECH.PARA: The real test of this Government, and indeed of industrial practices in Australia, is not whether a union is to be registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, not whether matters will be heard by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and not what agreements one might give or might not give to employers or to any other bodies. What is important is that all groups within society should live by the rules of society and those rules are laid down by our laws, passed through our parliaments. The trade union movement-as exemplified by the Builders Labourers Federation, but not restricted to that Federation-collectively assumes that it is above the law. One cannot in all seriousness have an ordered, progressive society while one has a major section of that society assuming a position of immunity from the provisions of the law.

As the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations identified in his second reading speech, we have a situation in which members of the BLF, in the name of a trade union, have practised thuggery, blackmail, intimidation and breaches of criminal law. However, in the name of the trade union they have assumed an immunity from the law. If any one of those individuals practised those same activities not in the name of the trade union movement, he would be prosecuted for criminal breaches. But because such people claim to be members of a trade union acting on legitimate trade union business, they assume that they are above the law and cannot be prosecuted. The real test in this case is not deregistration, that will not prove anything. If the Government and the Prime Minister are serious in trying to bring some sort of legitimate law and order to the trade union movement, the real test will be whether they are prepared to have the Commonwealth police investigate these breaches of criminal and civil law and to treat the unions in the same way as they would treat any other group or citizen in the community.

The only effort that has been made to date to have unions comply with civil law in this country has been the provisions that were placed in the Trade Practices Act by the previous Fraser Government. These provisions are found in section 45D and E. What has been this Government's response to those requirements of the trade union movement to comply with rules that apply to every other citizen and organisation in the community? The Government wants to wipe them off the statue book. Why? Because it has been instructed to do so by the same resolution at the 1979 July conference in Adelaide as that to which I referred earlier. Another resolution from that same conference is that the unions should be exempted from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. That resolution was passed at the July 1979 conference and has never been rescinded. It still stands. The Government's requirement to comply with that resolution has been shown several times by its attempts to remove sections 45D and E from the statute book. Just as this Government complies with instructions from its masters in the Australian Labor Party organisation to do that, so, too, does it comply with the same instructions to ensure that the union movement is free from government and judicial interference.

I throw out the challenge to members of the Labor Party, to members of the Government, to the Minister and the Prime Minister: If they are fair dinkum about doing something constructive to stop the intimidation, thuggery and criminal activity that has been going on in the union movement-and not just in the BLF-they will ask the Commonwealth police to investigate and prosecute members of trade unions in exactly the same way as they would any other citizen in the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: 6.36)-I guess after hearing the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) one would immediately think that we had just heard from Mad Max 3. Members of the Opposition often fail to remember history when they talk on this Building Industry Bill and tell the Government what it should and should not do. If one asks what governments should and should not do, one could ask what the present Leader of the Opposition (MrPeacock) was doing between 3 November 1980 and 16 April 1981 when he was the Minister for Industrial Relations in the Fraser Government. If members of the Builders Labourers Federation were on the rampage then as they are now-and there is not doubt that they were-one would have thought that Opposition members who are beating their chests now and telling the Government all the things that it should and should not do, would have taken action when they had the chance. Unfortunately, when the rhetoric and the actions are added up one finds that the present Opposition in government was very long on rhetoric and extremely short on action. On the other hand, this Government has decided that it will do something.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members should look at what the Building Industry Bill of 1985 is about because when one hears the honourable member for Lyons and some of the other Opposition speakers it is unclear what the Government is proposing. It is important that we should realise that the Bill will provide for a hearing before a Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission upon an application by the Minister at which the Commission will be required to consider whether the Builders Labourers Federation, or a prescribed person, has engaged in certain specified forms of industrial misconduct. If the Commission then decides that the BLF or any person has done so there are certain prescribed steps that can be taken. After he receives a report from the Commission, the Minister may direct the cancellation of the Federation's registration. He may order the termination or suspension of any of the rights, privileges or capacities of the Federation or its members. He may order that the rules of the Federation relating to the industry will cease to have effect. The Minister may also order that other unions registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act be given, with their consent, coverage of work in the industry in respect of which the Federation is or has been registered. Despite the ravings of the previous speaker, a number of unions recently have said that they would take over coverage of people in those industries. Where the Minister decides not to make such an order, he may enable the Commission to determine whether other registered unions should, with their consent, be given coverage of such work and, if so, make a declaration which will have that result.

That is a method by which some sense can be brought into the industrial anarchy that has been caused by the BLF since 1974. It is not easy for a Labor government to make such a decision. There has to be a great deal of thought put into it as well as a lot of soul searching. After that agonising and soul searching the Government decided, on balance, that it had to look after the good of the majority of unionists rather than the principle of whether the BLF should be allowed to run riot in the building industry in Australia. When the Government was looking at the possibility of introducing this legislation it had to take account of the many thousands of good men and women who are members of the Builders Labourers Federation, who have had nothing to do with many of the industrial actions in which the BLF has been involved. They also must be protected. This Government is about protecting the rights or ordinary men and women to go about their business in an organised, unionised fashion. Unfortunately, over a period the BLF has placed itself outside the bounds of civilised trade unionism. The Government is very concerned that one small group of people in an large union could cause the building and construction industry to come to a standstill. This Government, which is committed to a significant increase in productivity in Australia and to a restructuring of the Australian economy so there can be more work for Australians, has picked the building industry as an area where it wants to see more employment created. It is important to remember that the building and construction industry contributes about 10 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. The non-residential sector of the building industry currently employs 350,000 people. That is a lot of good people and a lot of jobs. The Government has encouraged the industry as a central force in its renewed economic expansion since 1983.

The activity the Government would like to see in the building industry is being hampered in many areas by certain elements of the Builders Labourers Federation. Around Australia the Federation has about 35,000 members in the non-residential construction area, and in the States of New South Wales and Victoria and in the Australian Capital Territory it has about 24,000 members. But as I said earlier, the history of the BLF since the early 1970s is strewn with numerous examples of unbelievable industrial campaign practices, of broken undertakings to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, to its fellow unionists and to employers, and of understandings and co-operation from fellow unionists being ignored and trampled upon.

I think it is important, in considering this legislation, to consider in depth some of the activities of some elements of the Builders Labourers Federation. I would particularly like to say some things about the view that people in the broader labour movement from my own State of New South Wales have about the activities of the BLF. In the last few months there have been some rather significant decisions taken by the labour movement in New South Wales, and I will name four of those as they relate to the BLF. In the last few weeks the administrative committee of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party unanimously condemned the BLF. That was not just one group of people in the Labor Party; people from the Left, the Right and the Centre were opposed to the BLF. The New South Wales Trades and Labour Council, at a recent meeting, nearly unanimously condemned the BLF. Two hundred delegates were present and a mere handful were willing to vote against the proposal. The Newcastle branch of the Labour Council, which is a left wing group, recently expelled the BLF. Even the South Coast branch of the Labour Council, which would probably be the farthest Left of any branch of the Labour Council in New South Wales, has been most critical of the way the BLF has held up economic expansion on the south coast of New South Wales.

My colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) was telling me earlier this evening about the difficulties people have had in that area, where there has been massive unemployment, being held to ransom by a small group of people. Merv Malcolm, the Secretary of the south coast branch of the Labour Council, who could not be called a right winger, has been most vocal in his condemnation of the actions of the Builders Labourers Federation in my State.

It has been interesting to see the change in attitude of trade unionists and Labor Party activists against the members of the Federation in the last 11 years. In 1974, I was a delegate to the New South Wales Labour Council from the Federated Clerks Union of Australia. I was at a meeting one night when a number of members of the BLF who had been drinking in a pub across the road from the Labour Council building broke into the meeting and started systematically to assault other trade unionists who were there at the Thursday night meeting of the State Branch of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That was the beginning of the thuggery that has had people worried ever since. One of the most disgusting things I have ever seen done by one unionist to another occurred when Jack Ryan, who was an official of the Rubber Workers Union of Australia-an old man with only one leg-was knocked over and hit on the head with a chair by a person who purported to be a trade unionist, a member of the Builders Labourers Federation.

In May 1974, after very bitter debate, the New South Wales Labour Council expelled the BLF for the first time. In October 1978 it was readmitted to the Labour Council on giving the undertaking that it would act as a responsible trade union. In March 1981, it was suspended again from the Labour Council of New South Wales after complaints from other unions of the BLF attempting to enrol members of the Australian Workers Union and the Building Workers Industrial Union. In July 1984 it was readmitted to the Labour Council after intervention by the ACTU. In October 1982, it was disaffiliated from the Victorian Trades Hall Council. In March 1984, the New South Wales Labour Council issued a statement calling for `an immediate end to the anarchy which has resurfaced in the building and construction industry at the instigation of the BLF'. The Labour Council called for the expulsion of the BLF from the ACTU to be considered if the BLF did not agree to have disputes solved in accordance with the ACTU's demarcation policy.

In May 1984, the ACTU President said that the BLF had been given its last chance. In July 1984, 1,000 building workers participated in a demonstration at the Sydney Town Hall condemning the behaviour of the Builders Labourers Federation in intimidating other trade unionists. In August 1984 Transport Workers Union drivers were harassed and intimidated at the Sydney police centre site. In September 1984 Builders Labourers Federation members invaded the AWU offices in Melbourne. The police were called and arrests were made. In May 1985 the ACTU Executive condemned the BLF's recent behaviour at the police centre site and the Greater Union site in New South Wales-two of the biggest jobs in that city.

In July of this year the New South Wales Labour Council passed an almost unanimous resolution calling on the Federal Government to deregister the union. In 11 years the BLF was expelled from the Labour Council of New South Wales on a number of occasions. The important thing to recall is that after all of those 11 years, the decision of the Council in May 1974 to expel the Federation was bitterly contested and was only narrowly passed. In July 1985, the New South Wales Labour Council was nearly unanimous in its decision to condemn the Builders Labourers Federation. The Federation had lost the support of ordinary trade unionists. In its activities on building sites it has shown that it is willing to use all sorts of tactics in the pursuit of what it has called legitimate industrial activities. Its practice of stopping concrete pours and of putting other unionists out of work is legend. In some instances it has used jackhammers to break up concrete that has been poured by members of the AWU. It has interrupted the concrete pours on State government and private enterprise buildings. At a time when the Government in Canberra tried to do its best, in co-operation with the Victorian Government, to provide hospitals and colleges of technical and further education in Victoria, the Builders Labourers Federation is preventing work being done on those sites.

In many of its activities on building sites the Federation has often put at risk the health and safety of other unionists. The unfortunate thing is that it is only a small group of people within the BLF who are doing this. It is not the 35,000 members; it is just a small clique who are running the organisation, a small clique who like the power involved and a small clique who have absolutely no interest whatsoever in the industrial aspirations of other trade unionists. I think we also should remember, in dealing with the BLF, the number of agreements it has entered into with governments and the way it has pulled out of them. It makes promises and it breaks them. In fact, one could say that the BLF and Malcolm Fraser have had a lot in common. A promise or an understanding lasts only until it is cancelled shortly after being made or reached. The Federation has given re-registration undertakings to the Industrial Registrar, it has given undertakings to the Government, it has given undertakings to its own trade union colleagues and it has given undertakings to the labour councils and to the ACTU. All those undertakings have been breached at the end of the BLF's achieving its aim.

Notwithstanding all that, the present Government is not proposing in the legislation today to deregister the BLF. The Government is going to ask the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to conduct a hearing and properly investigate the matter. In my view, the BLF has shown itself to be an organisation that has scant regard for the rights of ordinary working men and women. It has brought the union movement into disrepute, and strong action needs to be taken. I think that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his speech in the House earlier today summed up the view of all members on this side and, I should think, members on the other side when he said:

I know of no sense in which the trade union movement can regard the industrial thuggery practised by the BLF with anything but profound disquiet. The BLF consistently now has put itself out of line with the mainstream of what legitimate trade unionism is about.
I think that should sum up the attitude of all of us to this legislation. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two important precedents have been created for the socialists in Australia by their Government's pursuit of this legislation. The Building Industry Bill does much to destroy two great Australian Labor Party myths. The first of those fairy tales is that legislation is to be eschewed by democratically elected governments in countering malpractices of or by irresponsible unions and unionists. The second myth to go by the board today is that which seeks to justify international treaties and conventions becoming a legitimate and binding basis for Australian law. Dealing with the second myth first, we should be particularly mindful of the International Labour Organisation conventions, some of which have been ratified by successive Australian governments.

SPEECH.PARA: It has long been argued by those opposite and their predecessors that international conventions assume something like the standing of holy writ, albeit that, if selectively applied, they put into a form of words only those doctrines of the ALP that it holds at a particular time. ILO conventions seem to be particularly sacrosanct to the ALP although the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the listing of Australian real estate by the World Heritage Commission seem also to loom large in the thinking of both those opposite and minority groups from time to time. Because ILO conventions and deliberations are so important to some opposite, they will know that this Bill is contrary to ILO Convention No. 87 which deals with protection of the right to organise. The United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which Australia has also ratified, of course, in Article 20, clause 1, stipulates:
Everyone has the right to freedom of association.

It seems to many that this Bill will very much offend against the spirit and the letter of international undertakings of the type I have just instanced. That will put us in the same court as those other great examples of countries which have ratified ILO Convention No. 87 and have subsequently flouted its provisions. We are about to be numbered along with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the German Democratic Republic as countries which, despite ratification, will deny the right of certain workers to organise.

Let me say at once that I agree with the Government's stated intentions to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation, even though I doubt its sincerity. However, we cannot as a country have it both ways. We cannot on one hand expect to claim that ratified ILO conventions are inviolate while legislating for the opposite. It has to be one thing or the other. Given the bipartisan support for this Bill, there is only one real choice-that is, that the conventions against which the legislation offends must be disowned. Australia must, if it values its reputation for honest dealings, tell the ILO that it no longer accepts the dictum of Convention No. 87 as something we can abide by, and that its ratification is to be removed. If the Government does not do that, we will be seen to be no better than the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or the German Democratic Republic, countries which unashamedly flout that ILO convention.

Many times in this Parliament and outside the coalition parties have been chastised because they sought to legislate or amend legislation to control the mindless excesses of the trade unions. Almost as many times we have been told that legislation is not the answer to even general, let alone particular, union misbehaviour. Perhaps we will see an end to that sort of specious insincerity in future. At last the Australian Labor Party or some members of it seem to have reached the inescapable conclusion that, unless there is an unfettered right among Australian working men and women to true freedom of association, governments have to regulate their affairs. The union movement would do well to remember that. So it is that we see an end to a couple of the ALP's sacred cows. No longer can it be said that international conventions should dictate how elected governments in Australia will legislate in the interests of its electors. No longer will the claim that governments should not make laws to control recalcitrant unions be sustainable.

This morning we experienced the unusual and, might I say, rare participation of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in general debate. No doubt he felt it necessary to end his self-imposed exile from parliamentary proceedings. Perhaps his masters insisted upon it, perhaps he needed to reassert himself for ALP factional reasons. But what about the Prime Minister's contribution to the debate? He quoted something that Mr Steve Black of the New South Wales Builders Labourers Federation said in 1979 which illustrated the lawlessness of the union. Who was President of the ACTU in 1979? He cited the words of a Mr Dalton in 1979. Who was still the President of the ACTU in 1979? The Prime Minister offered as justification of his support for the Bill words spoken by Mr Norman Gallagher, again in 1979. Who was President of the ACTU then?

The Prime Minister also referred to events over the period 1976 to 1982 in a way which was intended to leave us with the impression that those events warrant the measure before the House. Who was in turn President of the ACTU and spokesman on industrial relations for the parliamentary Labor Party over the years 1976 to 1982? The same goes for the report by Mr Justice Winnecke, which was published in 1982. At all material times the present Prime Minister was either President of the ACTU or parliamentary spokesman for his party on industrial relations. Did he, in either capacity, publicly condemn in a way which could be taken seriously the examples he now cites? He did not. When in a position to show leadership before and soon after he came into this place, he failed to condemn, discipline or otherwise disown the BLF for its wanton irresponsibility and in many cases its illegal behaviour.

The Prime Minister this morning even said that he was considering ways and means of in future making contractors on government contracts adhere to government policies on industrial behaviour. What was the same Prime Minister doing earlier this year following a decision by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which denied the BLF an increase of 2.6 per cent arising out of a national wage case decision? Not long after Mr Justice Alley's correct decision, the 2.6 per cent was-as it still is-being paid to BLF members on the new Parliament House site.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can't be. You are joking!

—I am not joking. This is under this Prime Minister. The Government is already paying and condoning payment of sums to BLF members in contravention of a decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. How can that circumstance be matched with the Prime Minister's rhetoric? It just does not gel. There is a huge credibility gap. The doubts expressed by the coalition about the sincerity of the Government or its firm resolve to take the necessary tough action must be viewed in the light of these inconsistencies in its argument. The Prime Minister also said that the powers this Bill promises will not be used indiscriminately or capriciously. The great doubt that some have that the powers will not be used at all is the doubt which is exercising our minds tonight. With the word `may' attached to the powers to be given to the Minister, and given the Government's history over the past two and a half years, no one can be supremely confident that this Bill is anything but a big stick to wave without actually administering the punishment.

SPEECH.PARA: The first hurdle to be overcome before the deregistration process can even start is the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission itself. The Prime Minister tells us that offending behaviour by the BLF must be proved. The standard of proof required is not all that clear but, whatever it is, getting employers to give evidence not knowing what the Minister may ultimately do-`may' ultimately do-will not be as straightforward as it may seem at first glance. For instance, evidence by a national builder may attract retribution from the BLF in States other that New South Wales and Victoria. Such builders will be extremely reluctant to give evidence of problems in those latter States. Some employers will think more than twice because of the treatment they have received at the hands of the BLF, coupled with the lack of certainty that the Minister will exercise his discretionary powers. Not many will have much confidence in the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) to act with courage given his record since he attained his present office.

On the face of it, this Bill deserves the support the coalition will give to it. On closer examination, however, despite the claims the Minister and his Government make for what could be thought to be a panacea for the industrial mayhem created by the BLF, the proposed legislation is unlikely to match the expectations of the public. Over recent weeks, and after all the rhetoric from the ALP and sources within the ALP in Canberra, New South Wales and Victoria, it seemed that an almost universal sigh could be heard around Australia-at last something was to be done about the unreasoned lawlessness of the BLF. Anyone who thinks so is almost certainly bound to be disappointed.

That prediction may seem to be unduly pessimistic, but the reasons for making it can be gleaned from only a superficial look at some recent relevant history. It may have been forgotten that when this Government came to office, deregistration of the BLF was already in prospect in proceedings before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. With not a little confidence- building persuasion, the Fraser Government, with advice or with active leadership from the now Leader of the Opposition, had encouraged building employers to come out of the woodwork and present detailed and well documented arguments before the Commission.

The process of deregistration was well under way in 1983. Enter the Hawke Government and what happened? The Australian Council of Trade Unions said that that little exercise was not on. Nothing has happened since 1983 when the socialists came to power that has not happened before through the behaviour of the BLF. There are now more examples of the BLF's outrageous anti-social behaviour because of the passage of time, because of the elapsing of another couple of years. The union has not changed and, in fairness to it, it never seriously pretended that it would change.

Other things changed, though. The employers changed. The behaviour of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations had more than something to do with the change of heart by employers. The Minister actively, albeit behind the scences, made sure that the resolve of employers in 1983-84 to pursue deregistration was weakened. It might even be said that when that uncharacteristic determination was weakened sufficiently the Minister made both the BLF and the building industry employers an offer they could not refuse, in the best traditions of the American Mafia. Before the offer was made by the Minister, however, as might be expected in dealings of this kind, the real heavies of the trade union movement had obviously made a similar undeniable offer to the Minister. The ACTU made it clear that deregistration of a union whose secretary was the sole representative of the building unions on the ACTU Executive was simply not on. That is a pretty powerful constraint on a socialist government. In 1983 a Minister and a Prime Minister whose powers depended mightily on the ACTU were not about to upset those in the ACTU who were, mistakenly, as subsequent developments clearly show, thought to be powerful but sympathetic friends of the Labor Government in Canberra and Labor Governments around Australia.

Whether under pressure or instructions from the ACTU is not clear, but the Minister wasted no time in planning an end to the 1983 deregistration. To do so he had first to secure a pay increase denied to the building unions by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. A series of devices and schemes behind the scenes saw both new words and new concepts in industrial relations. One of the strange animals which were created in this atmosphere was the building industry recovery procedures allowance. Unfortunately for the Minister, the Commission saw the building industry recovery procedures allowance for what it was-a device to get around the findings of an anomalies bench of the Commission. The Commission knocked it back. While all this conniving by the Minister to get around his own Government's wage guidelines was going on industrial disruption by the BLF and by other building unions continued unabated. The Government was funding and nominally supporting that deregistration action brought by employers back in 1982-83. It is of little more than incidental interest to note that the Minister finally got around the Commission's decision not to grant the pay increase to BLF members which would have been outside the guidelines. He did that by promoting a building industry superannuation scheme without precedent in Australia. Furthermore, he continues to sponsor the same thing for the whole of Australian industry. It is in these events and others that we find the genesis of what is a belated and what promises to be a half-hearted attempt at disciplining the BLF.

The offer that could not be refused which the Minister made to adversaries in the 1983 deregistration action came in two parts. Part one was in essence that the Government would no longer support the case mounted by building employers. Part two was the clincher: The Hawke Government would pick up the tab for the costs incurred by the parties in mounting and defending the case, which I think was $600,000 to $800,000. Discouraged by the equivocation of the Minister and his Government, the employers could not wait to take the money and run.

Those are the things that are exercising the minds of members of the Opposition. Many of the points I have raised give rise in turn to doubts which we have expressed about the firm resolve and future intentions of the Government and in particular the Minister once this Bill becomes law. I hope that the Minister will take some of our remarks on board. I hope that he will be conditioned by the very real doubts-they are not without good reason-which we have expressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up this debate I firstly thank the Opposition for facilitating the progress of the Building Industry Bill through the House. This debate has come on the day after the Bill was introduced and I thank the Opposition for its co-operation in allowing that to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to two or three things said and a number of questions raised during the debate. One matter that the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) referred to as being of some importance concerned the allegation that the Government had given major priority to deactivating the deregistration proceedings which were in place when it came to office and that this was somehow evidence of heinous activity on its part. It is true that we did give priority to that, because we did not regard those proceedings as being likely to lead to any satisfactory resolution of the industrial relations nightmare which existed in the building industry. We believed that that was so because it was our opinion that the conditions for effective deregistration were not in place, nor were they likely to be in place. Those conditions certainly involve a substantial degree of trade union preparedness to take over the work of builders' labourers. I believed that there was absolutely no chance of that being achieved in the course of proceedings before the Federal Court of Australia at that time. There was total trade union opposition to those deregistration proceedings and it was highly unlikely that that attitude would have changed.

It was also the fact that the time involved in reaching any deregistration would have been extraordinary. The proceedings had already continued for well over a year and there was every expectation on the part of the parties involved that the proceedings would roll on for some indeterminate number of years. It seemed to us that this was a rather absurd process, that in those circumstances it was best to terminate the proceedings and attempt to achieve a resolution which involved an industry agreement, as I outlined in some detail in my second reading speech, and that if that approach did not result in a satisfactory outcome the Government should seek to take effective action of another kind. That was the course that we proceeded on, and the end result is that we have reached the point where we have had to take that effective action.

It was also said by the Opposition spokesman that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and I personally guaranteed Builders Labourers Federation adherence to the building industry agreement-a guarantee which he said was worthless. It is not true to say that we guaranteed Builders Labourers Federation adherence to the building industry agreement; we were not in a position to do that. The Government did guarantee building industry employers that if the Builders Labourers Federation did not abide by that agreement the Government would take effective action to ensure that the industrial relations situation in the industry was corrected and that we would take effective action against the Federation. The legislation now before the House gives effect to that promise.

The third point that I mention as a result of the debate concerns the serious matter raised by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). He suggested that the Bill breaches International Labour Organisation Convention No. 87 as well as the International Covenant on Human Rights. I disagree with his assertions in that regard. I do not believe that this legislation does breach International Labour Organisation Convention No. 87 and I would be concerned if that were the case. The situation is that Convention No. 87, which deals with freedom of association, has regard to the right of people to join associations. Action by governments to terminate the existence of associations such as trade unions probably would be regarded by the International Labour Organisation as a breach.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Willis-Mr Speaker, I require the question to be put forthwith without debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as I was saying, the ILO would probably regard action by government to terminate a union's existence as a breech of convention No. 87. What we are doing with this legislation is not terminating the existance of a trade union. What we would do if the option of total deregistration were taken would be to put that union outside the Federal system of conciliation and arbitration. It would still not be against the law to be a member of an association which was unregistered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act but known as the Builders Labourers Federation. So I disagree with the honourable member's assertion that it is a breach of the ILO convention. There are also other reasons which support that point which I will not go into.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer to a few questions which were raised by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Tangney, in relation to the legislation. The honourable member said that the words `prescribed person' in the legislation were limited to officers of the BLF. He pointed out that this was a very narrow definition and would limit the effectiveness of the Bill. In fact the definition of `prescribed person' is in similar terms to the deeming provision of section 188 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which was inserted by the Fraser Government. I draw to the shadow Minister's attention the fact that under clause 4(3) the Federation is also responsible for the actions of its members. So it seems to us that the responsibility of the Federation under the legislation cannot be said to be in the narrow terms suggested by the shadow Minister. Indeed, if he looks at the Bill he will see that it refers not only to officers but also to employees, agents and even a member of the Federation. So it has a very wide coverage. Indeed, in our view it would have a wider coverage than that contained in section 143 of the Act to which he referred.

The honourable member also raised the point that he could not see how it could be proved that the Federation was responsible for the actions of members under clause 4(3). It seems to us that his assertion of a very narrow coverage is not true. Sub-clause (3) not only makes the BLF liable for the actions of its members where it is proved that it instigated or encouraged the relevant action, but also it makes the Federation responsible for those actions if it does not prove to the contrary; that is, the Federation has to prove that it was not responsible for the actions of the members. So I do not think there is any need for the honourable member to be concerned on that score.

The honourable member asked whether clause 4(5) has a provision which is designed to facilitate the presentation to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of evidence that is already available or that has already been presented to it and other tribunals. It is not a provision which excludes the production of other evidence. It is merely designed to facilitate the proceedings.

The honourable member also asked why the word `may' is used instead of `shall' in relation to the powers of the Minister. That occurs in clauses 5, 8 and 9. The simple answer to that is that `may' is used so that the Government will have alternatives at its disposal. There is no lack of resolve by the Government to take whatever action is appropriate under the legislation.

The honourable member also said that there should be national deregistration of the BLF and no alternatives. I think that assertion shows a failure to understand the wide ranging and rather subtle nature of the Bill which gives the Government flexibility of approach which we think is highly important. Indeed, I notice that in the contributions made from the other side, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest) seemed to indicate some understanding of the need for flexibility in approach. That is the case. I made the point, I think quite clearly in my second reading speech, that there is a great diversity of action by the BLF around Australia, that in some areas and some States the actions of the organisation have been rather outrageous in the way that we have spelled out. In other States and, in particular, in the State of Queensland, it could be said that that action has been nowhere near as outrageous. With that diversity we believe that it is important to have a flexible approach. I indicated in my second reading speech that it would be the Government's intention to use the flexible provisions of taking selective action and that we would be looking to confining action in the initial stages and perhaps only at any stage to Victoria, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory.

Another question raised by the honourable member for Tangney was how long proceedings would take before the Federation was deregistered. I have already said that there may be action other than straight out deregistration. It is very difficult to lay down any timeframe in relation to this matter, mainly because what will happen is not entirely within the control of the Government; that is, there are proceedings before an independent tribunal and parties are able to put their cases to that tribunal in the way that is appropriate. There is also the possibility of the parties involved resorting to rights under the law. It may well be the case that there is more than action simply before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Those matters make it impossible for the Government to give any time estimate, but I point out that the Government will proceed with all appropriate expedition under clause 4 (6). The Commission is required to proceed with expedition. It is our intention, as soon as this legislation goes through the House, to get this matter before the Commission and to have the matter of a declaration achieved as soon as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Interest Rates-Schools Funding-Industry Survey Grant-Taxation-Assets Test: Veterans

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Willis) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my painful duty tonight, on behalf of the Opposition, to raise the question of the deliberate misleading of the home owners and the public of Australia by the man who occupies the position of Treasurer of the Commonwealth, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), on the question of interest rates. I have notified the Treasurer's office that, painful though it is, the Opposition would be shirking its public responsibilities if it did not bring to the attention of this Parliament the fact that the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia, over an extended period, consistently and deliberately misled home owners and, in particular, prospective home purchasers in Australia on the question of interest rates. The conclusion is inescapable. Last year, with malice aforethought, the Treasurer set about conveying the impression that there would be a drop in home interest rates in 1985. On the evidence it is inescapable that wilful misrepresentation took place in a succession of public statements made by the Treasurer on this very important issue and, in particular, in the period leading up to the Federal election.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind the House of the Treasurer's appearance on the national television program Sunday on 4 November 1984, when he categorically stated his views in relation to interest rates. Let me quote just two of the comments he made. These comments were heard by thousands and thousands of decent Australians, particularly young Australians who were contemplating purchasing their first homes. He said:
We have a further interest rate step fall ahead of us . . .
He said also:
I am sure that there are further declines in housing interest rates ahead of us.

He was aided and abetted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the then Minister for Housing and Construction, all of whom conspired to repeat that home interest rates would drop in 1985. Now we have a situation in which whenever anybody tries to ask the Treasurer a question, either inside or outside this Parliament, about interest rates he goes scurrying down his hole like a ferret and will not answer the question. Today the Treasurer was asked categorically as to when home interest rates would drop in 1985. He did not say that they would drop. He did not say that they would not drop. He did not say that the fall had been postponed until 1986. He just said that the matter was out of his hands.

If the people of Australia had known that without any conviction in what he was saying and without any evidence to support his contentions, his claims, the Prime Minister's claims and the claims of the then Minister for Housing and Construction that home interest rates would drop in 1985 were false, a tissue of falsehoods, a pack of lies, I suggest that many Australians would have voted completely differently in December of last year. The plain fact is-painful though it is for the Opposition to expose it-that the Hawke socialist Government, through the agencies of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the then Minister for Housing and Construction promised the people of Australia that interest rates would fall in 1985. As we all know, they have gone up.

As recently as January of this year the Treasurer continued to say that home interest rates would drop. Yet at the very time he made that statement prime interest rates went up. Housing interest rates have gone up and will continue to go up. They will not peak for another six months. The plain fact is that the Treasurer of this country is now publicly exposed as a deceiver and misrepresenter whose credibility on interest rates is now totally and absolutely destroyed. Shame on him. The home owners of Australia will well remember the Keating-Hawke-Hurford promises of 1984 and the way in which they were totally dishonoured in 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling the honourable member for Lowe, I remind honourable members about the standing order with regard to imputations of improper motives. While this clearly resides in imputing improper motives as far as the House is concerned, the standing order is worded so as to cause some concern regarding whether similar allegations are made about misleading other groups. I ask honourable members to give that some consideration when making their speeches.

—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. I did advert to this question. Can I simply say that I note your ruling and accept it? I am quite prepared to repeat outside the chamber every word of what I have said tonight. I challenge Keating, Hawke and Hurford to sue me.

—Order! The honourable member for Denison will resume his seat. I gave a warning to honourable members because I have a feeling that the sense of the standing order is as I mentioned it to honourable members. I did not interrupt the honourable member, but I think I should remind honourable members. I call the honourable member for Lowe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter tonight which relates to my electorate of Lowe in Sydney. It involves the establishment of new non-government schools. In 1984 there were three systemic schools which were part of the Catholic education system, but this year one of them went into the private sector voluntarily. These schools, two for girls and one for boys, end at year 10. The children, the parents, the teachers and the principals, in response to the Government's participation and equity program, and with all the emphasis on staying at school and perhaps family expectations, applied for the schools to offer year 11 in 1986 and then year 12 in 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, quite sensibly, has introduced tests on the granting of recurrent funding to non-government schools because it is essential that, if a new school opens in a town, suburb or an old established area, such as the electorate of Lowe, there is no damage to a neighbouring school, be it a government, catholic or private school. If a new school opens and a large number of pupils transfer to that school it is quite easy to see how courses which had been advertised would not be available at the original school. There has to be a minimum number of pupils in order to offer a number of courses. There could be real harm to an existing school by the opening of a new school nearby, or on the same bus route. There could also be a waste of funds because classrooms and facilities would be unused.

In answer to a question on notice that I asked, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) informed the House that there will be a decision in September on new school recurrent funding for 1986. The problem arose today when we were told by a delegation of administrators from St Mary's College, Rosebank, at Five Dock, one of the schools involved, that the decision might be delayed, not due to any problems in Canberra but due to problems in various States where priorities for new school funding had to be worked out. There is a fear, particularly with the people at Rosebank, that the decision might not come down until October, which would create great chaos and mayhem for the parents of children who are trying to send their children on to year 11 in 1986. The school in question, St Mary's College, Rosebank, has an enrolment of nearly 70 per cent of pupils from families in which English is a second language. They are essentially middle or low income earners because the school has been graded in group 11. When one thinks that all the parish and systemic catholic schools in Sydney were put in groups 10, which is one group higher, this school was put in group 11. The schools in New South Wales in group 11 and group 12 are often Aboriginal schools or schools run by ethnic groups. They have a lack of facilities and are in great need of maximum government funding.

The problem is that if children cannot get into a school to study for year 11 many of them will go on the dole. Many of the parents and teachers have told me that and the principal told me that today. The brightest children will have no problem. They can get into other non-government schools. Some children will go to State schools, to Catholic schools and some to Catholic private schools. Children in the medium range of intelligence will have trouble getting into a school because the percentage of Catholics in the inner western suburbs of Sydney, with migration since the war, has doubled. It is 45 per cent in some of the subdivisions in Lowe. There is a real demand for places in Catholic secondary schools. The proposal in 1986 is for an amalgamation of the Christian Brothers High School at Burwood, and St Mary's College, Rosebank, for year 11.

I raise this matter tonight because these schools are needy. They have no facilities such as halls or swimming pools. This Christian Brothers High School does not even have a decent playground. I hope that the Minister can ensure that the decision, as promised, is made in September because any further delay will produce great difficulty for the parents who are not well versed in dealing with educational systems and may have trouble with written English, forms, et cetera. If their children cannot go to the proposed new school next year my fear is many will have trouble getting into any other non-government school because all the schools in the Catholic system and the private Catholic schools in Lowe and nearby suburbs are now fully committed in student places for 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I return to the theme of truth and honesty in politics. I am conscious of your ruling but I want to put some matters on the record tonight so that they will be there and at some time we will get an answer to them. On behalf of hundreds of thousands of Australian Home owners I ask: Did the Treasurer (Mr Keating) appear on the national television program Sunday on 4 November last year? In the course of that appearance I ask whether the Treasurer of Australia made this categoric statement in relation to interest rates:

SPEECH.PARA: We have a further interest rate step fall ahead of us.
I ask further whether the Treasurer of Australia on that Sunday program on 4 November 1984 said:
I am sure that there are further declines in housing interest rates ahead of us.

That is the first point. Did the Treasurer appear on the television program? Was he seen by millions of viewers and did he make those statements? The second question has to be: Did he believe those statements when he made them? Did he believe that they were true? If he did so believe, I publicly challenge the Treasurer to bring into this Parliament the material upon which that belief was formed. If the Treasurer did not believe those statements when they were made, on behalf of hundreds of thousands of Australian first home purchasers I believe I am entitled to demand-not ask, but demand-that the Treasurer come into this Parliament and admit that the statements he made on that television program, Sunday, on 4 November 1984 were not in fact true. It is a very serious matter.

I have had correspondence sent to my electorate office in Hobart and here to Parliament House. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and other honourable members in this chamber who deal with ordinary people know that many young people entered into contracts to purchase houses towards the end of last year on two clear commitments. The first was a promise by the Treasurer of Australia that home interest rates would drop in 1985. As I have pointed out, they have in fact gone up. I say in passing: Does the Treasurer stick by his prediction? If he does, when in 1985 will they drop? We are running out of time. Has the promise been deferred to 1986 or 1987, or is the promise now non-enforceable?

TALK.START.PARA: —Like his tax cuts.

—Exactly, he is a great man for breaching promises. The second promise, upon which many thousands of young Australians were enticed into entering into contracts to purchase homes, was the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the official opening of the Australian Labor Party campaign seeking the re-election of the Hawke socialist Government. What did he say? He spoke in glowing terms, as the honourable member for Mitchell has referred to in earlier speeches in this Parliament, about the success of the first home owners scheme. Let us be quite blunt: It has been an outstanding success. What did the Prime Minister say to the people of Australia? He said: `We intend to keep it as it is'. So we have the Treasurer saying that interest rates will come down and the Prime Minister saying about the first home owners scheme: `We intend to keep it as it is'. That second promise of the Prime Minister will be entered in the Guinness Book of Records as the first election promise dishonoured by this Government within 16 weeks of its election. The first home owners scheme has been slashed. It has been chopped and the chops have fallen hardest on those least capable of affording them.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the home owners of Australia, old and new, I say that it is about time the Prime Minister came into this Parliament and admitted that he broke a solemn election promise. It is about time the Treasurer, who dives into his hole like a ferret every time he is asked about interest rates, comes forward and admits whether he was telling the truth on 4 November when he told the people of Australia clearly and categorically that home interest rates would drop in 1985. That statement has now been proven to be untrue. That promise has now been dishonoured like a bad cheque. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer stand condemned in the eyes of decent Australians who believed them and who will never believe them again on these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, more in sorrow than in anger, to draw the attention of the House and of people in South Australia to a regrettable appointment that has been made in my electorate of Kingston and which, in my view, leads to a very serious conflict of interest. SPEECH.PARA: The conflict of interest arises because, at the same time as this appointment is being made, Mr Chapman, who was the defeated Liberal candidate for Kingston in 1983, is also the Liberal State candidate for--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I do not believe that it is consistent with the Standing Orders for an honourable member to attack a former member of this House on a personal basis, as is currently happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on a matter that was raised by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) during Question Time in this place today. I noted with interest, too, the comments made earlier in this debate by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) in relation to the first home buyers scheme and interest rates. At the heart of what I have to say is a comment I made in my first speech in this place, when I spoke on the economic philosophy and expertise of honourable members on the other side of the House. At the time I said that members of the Opposition were `bereft'-bereft of expertise, bereft of a philosophy and bereft of policies. What we have heard tonight from honourable members opposite simply reinforces that view.

SPEECH.PARA: My complaint in respect of the privatisation principle that the Opposition is now espousing is that it is irresponsible. It is irresponsible in that our economy is just recovering from a recessionary period that honourable members opposite created through economic mismanagement. There are very few people, particularly from the other side of the House, who understand the depths to which our economy degenerated during that recessionary period. The skill and expertise that was necessary in the resurrection of that economy has been shown. Put in the most simple terms, those who mucked it up would implement a new policy on privatisation, which would muck it up again.

Let us have a look at some of the points that honourable members opposite espouse. They believe that by selling off government enterprises-they are talking about successful government enterprises only-they would in some way save government costs. That misses the whole point of the issue of recurrent costs versus the ownership of assets and capital expenditure. It comes as no surprise that those who espouse this approach do continually miss that point. Another interesting aspect is the question of taxes. The Opposition is putting forward a theory that if those enterprises were to be owned by the private sector they would make more profits and, therefore, would pay more taxes. Looking at Budget estimates and past financial results, it is quite evident that the company sector is not the sector that pays a substantial proportion of government taxes; it is the pay as you earn wage and salary earner who pays those taxes. In fact, over a considerable period the Opposition has devoted much of its efforts to providing a tax avoidance industry with the mechanism to minimise the payment of tax by the private sector. So the theory of `let us hand government enterprises over to the private sector so that they can become more profitable and pay more taxes' is laid to rest by the fact that the Opposition has put its energy into helping its mates to minimise the amount of tax they pay, creating the burden that this economy and ordinary wage and salary earners have had to bear.

Every time the Opposition introduces in this House the fable about increased tax revenue we will continually point to the fact that its mates are the ones who do not carry their share of the tax burden; their mates are the ones they are trying to assist with these sorts of proposals.

I refer to the time when the private sector espoused these sorts of philosophies and made an offer to buy an operation such as Vic Rail in Victoria which, of course, is a railway enterprise completely funded by the public sector and which is run at an enormous loss because of establishment over a long period-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to relate to honourable members the plight of veterans in the electorate of Flinders. Today we have the first adjournment debate this session, and what is brought up by government backbenchers yet again? It is some more muck raking whilst veterans in my electorate are suffering the brunt of the Australian Labor Party's assets test and its general attack on the elderly in my electorate.
—Oh, come on. Prove it.

—I will come to the honourable member for McMillan in a moment. One of the great lies that has been perpetrated in the last 12 or 18 months is that only 2.6 per cent of all pensioners have been affected by the iniquitous assets test. That is not the situation in my electorate and I believe that that is not the situation in many other parts of Australia. Such is the sensitivity of the Government that when these figures were released by me not so long ago I put them to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). He wanted to argue about the analysis of the figures so I said to him-I had the consent of Bruce Ruxton of the Returned Services League in Victoria-`If you do not like these figures why don't you face the people who are suffering from your assets test and answer them face to face'. What was his response? He was too busy but he said that he would send me a departmental officer. That was very big of the Government and typical of its response to some of these problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get to a few of the facts because when it all boils down it is the facts that hit honour-able members on the other side really hard. My word they are sensitive as their responses tonight show. Let us take some of the rural areas, areas that were formerly the responsibility of the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham). I refer to them because they are typical of many parts of rural Australia. Take an area such as Loch Krowera. It may not be known to honourable members but I can describe it as typical Australian rural countryside and an area where not only are people suffering under this assets test but also they are suffering from a downturn in the dairy industry. The percentage of veterans affected by the assets test in Loch Krowera is not 2.6 per cent but 41.93 per cent. Four out of every 10 veterans in that region have been affected by the assets test. I think that is an absolute disgrace.

We have people who are prepared to face death on behalf of their country in order to maintain the democratic institution that we have in this country, yet this is the sort of treatment handed out by the parties on the other side. I say `parties' because it is an increasing fact of political life of this country that we no longer have factions on the other side but parties within parties. However this problem is not just in Loch Krowera. I take Clyde, another area on the northern part of my electorate where 20 per cent of veterans are affected by the assets test. Take another area, Poowong-great dairy country-where 25 per cent of veterans are affected. On the Mornington Peninsula up to 57 per cent of veterans are affected by the Labor Party's assets test. When the Herald ran a campaign earlier this year on Anzac Day it ran a case of Wilma Hattiy, the widow of a Gallipoli veteran. The honourable member for McMillan was quick on the telephone asking `what can I do to help?'. About two weeks later, these backbenchers on the other side, who were worried about their seats, came to Canberra to face an opportunity-
